one_reviews_text: Long time vive user, sold my vive and decided to try the rift, this is visually way better in my opinion (less screen door), I also prefer the controllers, much more natural and it feels like a new experience all together, oculus VR software once your in is pretty sweet, weight of headset is nice and light, doesn't feel clunky like the vive, integrated headphones a bonus. Once you get it going it's nice...but.... be prepared to be frustrated. This thing takes hours to get going and the initial setup software I find to be very unstable. Be prepared to spend extra on good usb 3.0 extension  cables, a good usb 3.0 controlller,  extra sensors... It's not an out of the box room scale experience like the vive which you can have up and running quickly. In the end it costs more than the basic vive with all the the stuff you need (if you don't have all the ports etc). Tracking with 2 sensors is nowhere near 360 room scale like the vive. Vive wins in ease of setup and initial tracking. Waiting to see how good 3 sensors will be. I'm still definitely happy with my purchase but would have rated at higher if it was an out-of-the-box 360 room scale vr experience and easy to set up. If you're getting this for someone for Christmas make sure you set it up a week before and get it running.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on November 28, 2018
review_title: Beats vive, pain to setup and get going.

one_reviews_text: I have seen the future and it is amazing! Not specifically this product. VR in general. Though this headset is great. It's easy to wear and simple to use, and surprisingly easy to set up. Get it when it is on sale though, don't pay full price. This is an early-ish gen product and I wouldn't spend so much if it weren't for it was on sale and had come down a lot since I last looked. Ignore the Vive unless that is on sale too. But new versions of both headsets are probably coming out soon so depending on when you are looking make sure you aren't going to buy just before it gets outdated. But still, this is really fun! It's great exercise, gets me moving compared to sitting and twiddling my thumbs with my XBox. And the immersion is just so much greater than anything I've ever experienced before. that is until some of the less comfortable games make me barf. That is a genuine issue until you get used to VR. But you can stick to more comfortable games first and work upwards.Warning! If you wear glasses check to make sure they fit (goes for any headset really), mine don't fit so I'm going to get a cheap new pair or some lenses and 3D print a mount to hold them in my Rift. Anything less than 12mm (or there abouts, please check Oculus faqs) should fit.Oh, fair warning, since you may be plugging and unplugging this from our GPU often get a short adapter if you haven't already gotten an extension cable (two, one HDMI, one usb 3.0). This is especially true for some Asus cards like mine. The pins on the rift's HDMI connector are pretty tight and pushed the loose pins on the gpu's port inwards to where they don't work anymore. MY card is fine except for an HDMI port. Now I have to use an adapter, and I consider it Asus' fault for making a flimsy HDMI port. But regardless, use an adapter so that will get damaged instead of your GPU.But seriously, check if  new headset from any of the manufacturer's are coming out soon. THis is still an early gen product and even if the next gen is completely the same but without the cable (as Oculus hints it will be), it'll be 100 times more worth it. The cable is tolerable but annoying and I'd pay to get rid of it. More peripheral vision would be nice too.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on March 3, 2018
review_title: This is the most fun I've had gaming since I was a kid. (But make sure a new headset isn't coming out soon before you buy).

one_reviews_text: This is a keeper. I know they will reduce the price and the cameras will get better. But this is still a keeper. Firstly, the free applications are in the Oculus store and you get it after you register. Secondly, take your time to set up a good sized play area ( more than 6 x 6 ft): worth. Once you put the visor on, you are immersed in an alternate reality. Your eyes tell you your brain that you've moved to another world but your ears will still hear the door bell. You might get tired of the exercise, make sure you've got access to a chair.Yes you can watch movies: try an IMAX movie or one which fills the entire 180 or 360 area around you. This will take you close to the  IMAX experience.Bear in mind, the camera resolution is not the best. I understand that the Vive is better. But your brain will fill in the gaps and you will hardly notice it unless you are looking. But this is partly the limitation of the medium rather than the Oculus cameras. Once the price comes down OR this becomes a must have, the cameras are going to get better and the rendering resolution is going to improve.The material is very well made for a Chinese product. The cables could have been braided instead of the plain plastic sheathing.The visor is very comfortable and I had none of the barn door effects that the others have. I tried with and without glasses and both were surprisingly comfortable.I am going to try actual videos/photos from my own astro and underwater collection. Plus videos from others (like the ISS, ESA and Woods Hole Oceanographic). Imagine swimming with a blue whale in your den.Anyone for tennis, hoops or chess? And...while we're on two person sports....
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on September 16, 2017

one_reviews_text: Bought a new Asus ROG gl702vi laptop with a GTX 1080. Installation was simple. Unit worked for about 5 minutes then the display shut off. Audio still worked. Simple research online results in so many possible issues it could be. Could never get the display to come on for more than a few seconds. After dozens of attempted solutions, either the unit is defective or there's an issue with the laptop. Could be a bandwith issue with the USB 3.0 ports. Returned for a full refund and bought an HTC Vive that has never had an issue. A cousin recently purchased an Oculus Rift and it works fine for him.While there are many VR solutions out there at the moment, the best choice really comes down to an Oculus Rift or HTC Vive. The best choice would be a Vive Pro if you have the money but we'll ignore it for this review. The main differences between the 2 are price, controllers, sensors, connections, and scale.Rift requires multiple USB ports with many being USB 3.0. The cameras are connected to your computer so room scale setup is difficult. You need 3 USB ports and an HDMI port available. The Touch controllers are much nicer. A third camera is recommended for room scale (plus USB extension cable) and that brings the price up to the Vive level. Room scale is smaller than the Vive 1.0 sensors.Vive has wireless sensors instead of cameras that you can mount on the walls. Only an HDMI and USB cable connect to your computer. Room scale setup is a breeze. The Wand controllers are not as nice to use and feel large and clunky. The upcoming Knuckles controllers look better. Deluxe audio strap is almost required and costs extra. Room scale is larger with 1.0 sensors and almost double that with 2.0 sensors (may need the Vive Pro for 2.0?).
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on December 3, 2018
review_title: Did not work. Could be any number of problems or a defective unit.

one_reviews_text: Shipping was fast but it was through Puroilator who are extremely rough on packages and their mail outlet is in the slummiest part of my city and the store doubles as a cellphone repair store. The entire pickup process was incredibly scary looking when 90% of the store is tailored to cellphone and laptop repair. They kept my $3,000 pc sitting on the floor on the consumer side of the counter right next to the door to leave the store. I literally took the day off work and sat in a chair at the entrance to my apartment for 5 and a half hours waiting for them because I didn't want to to both wait 24 hours to pick up, and have to go to their scary mail depo to get my riftAnyways on to the product, The Rift came sealed and in seemingly new looking condition but upon inspecting the lenses, there are very noticeable glue smudges under the lens from poor construction. I did some research and other amazon buyers have had this problem, only to return it several times for a replacement that also ends up having some lense smudges but in different places. It looks like everyone us just giving up and accepting their damaged lenses instead of the headache of sending things back and forth with replacements. Compared my lenses to my friends and his are completely clear no smudges under the lens. The smudges make my peripherals very blurry at all times.. The main point of VR is visual so if you can't see things properly, it's worthless.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on March 5, 2019

one_reviews_text: The product had a film or residue on the lens so it went back to Oculus support under warranty which sent me a replacement refurbished unit.  This unit was in far worse condition then what I sent away as its lenses were scratched up.  This happened 2 more times.  That is correct 3 refurbished units sent my way all with damaged lenses.  Since January I have only had the unit in my possession for roughly 30 days, the remaining 60+ it has been in transit or I have been waiting for them to send replacements.  I am completely dissatisfied with the customer service I have received as they are now claiming the scratched lenses on the refurbished units are my own fault.  The only mistake I made was purchasing the unit through AMAZON!  Because I bought it through them I am unable to get a refund on the purchase.  Overall this has been the most negative experience I have had purchasing anything.At this point I will never again purchase an Oculus product and am seriously reconsidering my purchasing habits using AMAZON.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on April 16, 2019
review_title: Would give Oculus Rift a 0 if I could

one_reviews_text: Pros:- amazing tracking- controllers are the best: capacitive touch sensors, feels damn good, has analog sticks- feels good on head, not too heavy- the headphones are just amazing, sounds deceptively good- works great on GTX 1050 TICons:- needs at least 3 to 4 USB ports, 1 of them needs to be USB 3.0- small sweet-spot comparison to Vive. Kinda blurry too- Oculus app is not the best, sometimes crashes too even during setup- setup is flaky, never consistent- guardian setup is absolutely not intuitive- horrible for people with glasses, at least I couldn't wear one at all, just wouldn't fit normal sizeOverall, it's not bad. Obviously these generation of VR headsets are not future proof and pretty much test product until Oculus Quest or something better, mainly because they're not practical (not wireless, need good gaming pc, 3 sensors, etc.)
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on January 13, 2019
review_title: It's alright, VR still needs work

one_reviews_text: A lot of people are writing reviews that try and say this VR system is the best thing since sliced bread.Reality check:1. Video is blurry. The "screen door" effect makes everything look blurry.2. There is no room for you to wear your glasses, no matter how small they are.3. The lenses are constantly fogging up because4. The lenses are so close that your eyeballs are almost touching them. I can feel them every time I blink,5. Your eye lashes will contact the lenses.6. There are NO instructions included with this $450 device. The only option you have is, immediately upon opening the package, go to their website for all instructions.7. There web site will have link that says "is this you first time setting up the rift?", and when you click it, it takes you to another page, and on that page is a link that says something like "First time users, click here to see our easy setup guide", which, of course, brings you back to the first page you were on.Here is the best instruction you can get: Download the driver and install it and follow the instructions, ignoring anything on their website.Once installed:The VR effect is pretty good, but in my opinion it doesn't make up for the blurriness overall. You do get a couple of free games and some other software, but after the initial cool factor the novelty wears off pretty quickly.There is a Steam VR game called Overload based off of an old PC game called Descent. It was an excellent game at the time, and the people who developed it are doing Overdrive, but it's unfinished. It has single player and PVP, but that's it. You can't have multiple people in missions (co-op).Many VR games don't support the Oculus controllers, which can be a big disappointment, and some apps only support the Rift Remote Control, which doesn't even come with the rift. How dumb is it to only support a controller that no one has?There is some free educational software that's pretty good, and some space walk software, and ISS software that's also free, but the good stuff costs bucks.There is software that will let the Rift work with games that don't support it, but it only gives you a 3D view, not VR, and makes them look like you're playing them on a huge monitor.I'm a huge Star Trek online player, and they don't support the Rift at all. In fact, from what I hear, it used to work in 3D and then the devs did something to prevent the rift from working. Some games work very will in the 3D mode (like Diablo 3).I'm not going to return this because it's not bad and I'm hoping they are going to finish Overdrive, but it's no where near the awesome experience some people make it out to be.EditDon't get ripped off. You can get this same set at Best Buy for $469 Canadian last time I looked. That's the same price I paid for it when Amazon had it in stock. The Rift is not worth $1000. You're better off to go with something else rather than be overcharged by $500.If you don't need PC compatibility, I recommend getting the Oculus Go. It's actually better than the Rift, it's under $300 for the 32GB version, but it's stand-alone Android. It will not work for playing your PC games.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on February 10, 2019

one_reviews_text: Pros:-Comes with free games-Excellent packaging-The two sensors work well for 360 tracking. Followed a Youtube tutorial on 2 sensor room tracking.-  Many free and inexpensive VR games on Steam. Works with Steam VR.-Many more fun applications than simply gaming.-Climby and SuperHot VR are a legitimate workout - I’m actually grabbing velcro resistance weights to make it even more legit.- Runs most games at full frames well with only a 1050ti and 6600K (more about this in cons)Now onto the headset itself:Pros:-Amazing build quality-Easy set up-Lightweight-PPD slider for different eye pupil distances!-Extremely immersive, with very little lightbleed.Cons:You’ll need a better rig. I’m actually building a new PC so it’s not an issue, but The Forest VR will make you nauseous as it’s not going to hit optimum framerate.-Screendoor effect - Though it is far less noticeable in some games. Anything that has writing seems to be blurry and low res. With this being said, this is Oculus’ first consumer implementation of VR and I’m excited to see what’s next.-Visible condensation on the inside of the mask when playing a session of superhot.Final thoughts: I wish that Oculus had a mounting system like in the Windows Mixed Reality and PSVR headsets that simply flip down.VR is incredible and has rekindled my joy of technology and gaming!
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on August 29, 2018
review_title: Rekindled my joy for gaming and technology. Absolutely incredible.

one_reviews_text: I'd only used the HTC Vive prior to making the purchase. Really it was the cost difference and a few write-ups on performance that made the decision for me.I bought a third sensor and it definitely makes a difference so assume you'll have to do that but the experience-to-price ratio is awesome and I'm very happy with the purchase. Read up on the HTC however and make sure your'e making the choice that's right for you.  They both have their pros-and-cons and it's worth the research.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on January 11, 2018
review_title: Pretty much what you'd expect ... awesome :D

one_reviews_text: This is an awesome VR headset. You will need a proper PC to run it tho. I have a 1070ti and a Ryzen 2600 and it’s perfect. I have solid 90fps.I tried this and the HTC Vive and for the price, you can’t beat the Oculus. While the HTC Vive has slighty better tracking, the Oculus is just as good if you get a 3rd sensor. Also, the Oculus controllers are just natural and amazing. Years ahead of the HTC Vive controllers. The oculus is also lighter, so it’s more comfortable for long periods of time.While the Oculus cable is a little short, it’s managable. You can always extend it with an Hdmi extension and Usb 3 extension.So if you want to get into VR, this is the best deal. It also comes with a bunch of cool games.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on December 4, 2018

one_reviews_text: I’ve used this for about a month now, everything came in a very nice box that can be repurposed for storage or transport. Came in 2 boxes + the box for the unit itself so there was zero damage to rifts box. Set up was fairly easy and quick maybe 20 minutes till i was downloading my first game.I’ve tried it on my gtx 970 and gtx 1080ti. The 970 for me didn’t give me a good experience it didn’t have enough power for everything to be smooth like the 1080ti is butter smooth. It fits snuggly and tight to your face (without glasses) and is comfortable to wear for a few hours at a time or till your tired and need to take a break. Some cons would be the “god rays” noticed them mostly on dark backgrounds and bright words or pictures. And the “barn door effect” it’s there but not overly noticeable unless you look for it. Some thing make it more visible then others like a white loading screen but when playing games I don’t notice it at all.I would definitely buy this again without a doubt just make sure you have a decent graphics card I’d recommend a 1060 or better and a play area where you can take a step in every direction from the center plus a bit of room it move your arms should you end up there I know I’ve hit my desk a few time going threw there guardian barrier without realizing.If you do end up getting one, one thing to remember is you will sweat playing these games standing up so remember hydrate and use the controller safety tether
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on November 6, 2017

one_reviews_text: Had some difficulty finding the "sweet spot" at first but after watching a few youtube videos I realized I was wearing the HMD wrong. It is very important to loosen all straps and pull the rear of the HMD down to base of skull and then pivot the front of the HMD down. When looking at screens it almost seems like you are peering about 3/4 of the way up instead of in middle.Only issue I have is with the foam, it does make you sweat more and can be irritating against your skin after a while. I have ordered a replacement from VRCOVERS and looking forward to it. Games are awesome, RoboRecall is what VR is meant to look like and very engaging and fun.Got it when on sale this past summer (last day pulled the pin). Definitely worth it when on sale.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on September 25, 2017
review_title: When looking at screens it almost seems like you are peering about 3/4 of the way up ...

one_reviews_text: First of all it depends on your pc. I have GTX1060 which is good enough for me. I feel no lag at all playing VR games on the oculus rift. And compared to PS4 VR in case you are choosing between these two like I did, I would say buy Oculus instead. It has better performance than PS4 and higher resolution. PS4 is not bad by any means but Oculus is just better. Also a really important factor is Windows VR is basically an open source platform unlike PlayStation. For games like Beat Saber, you will ONLY be able to add custom mods and songs(which you WILL absolutely want to) if you’re playing a PC version.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on February 27, 2019
review_title: Coming from a PS4 VR owner

one_reviews_text: Work well till it started to have loose connections with the wire inside the headset just reminds me of the old XBOX controller trying to get it to work but these controllers were fine they were better the vive for me ..BUT the headset is crap just before the month ended it starts to flash up in and out.. iv made sure its plugged in right run a GTX 1080TI  with a I5-6400 intelcore and 16GB HyperX ram. 750wat power supply... it should not have a problem with the quality i game on 4K i dont want to deal with stuf that will break down id rather wait for a new Gen wireless one instead of wasting 500 bucks
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on January 10, 2019

one_reviews_text: Really amazing experience.  Finally there are better games coming out for VR so this is truly worth it.  I've had one die on me already, but Oculus did a warranty replacement on it which was nice.  They even sent an extra set of headphones, facial interface and cable since they don't make you return your originals if they still work during an RMA.  I have 2 of these now in case one goes down, but I'm glad to know the warranty will pull through.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on July 30, 2018
review_title: Really amazing experience. Finally there are better games coming out ...

one_reviews_text: It's pretty cool, but I'm one of the lucky souls who gets motion sickness. Before making a purchase, I recommend giving it a try if you can. For me it only happens on first person games where you walk instead of teleport.I also find a lot of the games are still quite limited to standing and shooting. If you own Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice, you automatically can download the VR version for free. So that's nice. Still, I'm hoping to see a lot more extensive content over the next year.I did have an issue with not getting the six free games that are supposed to be bundled with it. I contacted support and had a reply within minutes! After I gave them all the pertinent information, the issue was resolved by the next day. Superb customer support.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on January 13, 2019

one_reviews_text: VR is legitimately amazing, it really feels like you're in another place. When you sign up with your new Oculus + Touch you also get a couple Oculus Exclusive Games free - hooray. Also didn't realize that it comes with headphones attached already (which i think the base Vive doesn't?)For optimal performance you're going to want a third sensor, though apparently you should be able to operate with two diagonally positioned. Also had to purchase a powered USB hub (tp-link powered USB 3.0 hub) because my new computer couldn't handle the sensors and the headset. so i have two in the hub, one on the front USB and the headset plugged into the back.The touch controllers are really comfortable to use, at first I thought they were awkward but using them they're generally more ergonomic and intuitive to use than the 'egg holder' style of the Vive.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on August 14, 2018
review_title: It's amazing, though it can fog up quite easily on warm days or with any kind of intense activity.

I'm sadly quite motion sickness prone (can ride any roller-coaster or amusement park ride without problem, but VR is another ball game, I've learned. After 15min I need to stop for the day, sadly). My boyfriend can play for 2 hours without even taking the advised breaks...We love it, already own about 10 games. Got it on sale and it was very much worth it!

review_title: works great! I'm sadly quite motion sickness prone (can ride ...

one_reviews_text: I loved the original headphones that came with my rift, because they are good quality and conveniently built-in.  When my 15yo sister had friends over, they got their hands on my rift, and afterwards the headphones didn’t work.  I figured it was because they pulled wires or were rough with the HMD itself, and nothing I tried fixed the problem.I decided to order these in-ear headphones to see if that would fix it, figuring that I could return them if not, and they work like a charm!  So while, unfortunately, my original headphones don’t work anymore, my rift wasn’t damaged and, as someone who doesn’t usually buy any IEMs for under $100, I can assure anyone looking at these that the quality is as good or better than the headphones that come with the rift, with the same convenience.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on November 14, 2018

one_reviews_text: Crashes constantly, programs will start one day but not the next, sensors constantly complaining about usb ports, computer crippled, random reboots..Replaced motherboard, processor, ram, power supply, graphics card, added usb3 expansion cards, various cables, reinstalled windows, reinstalled all rift software and games 3 times, updated bios, went through a half dozen driver versions for the graphics card AND IT STILL WOULDN'T WORK RIGHT.After many, many hours and over a thousand dollars in supporting hardware I have gotten nowhere..

one_reviews_text: It looked amazing and was very comfortable but I had to return it, sadly, because it wasn't compatible with my Alienware 17 laptop (because my graphics card was not connected to the HDMI port). Everytime I connected it, the integrated Intel graphics was the default (and only) setting for HDMI so I couldn't connect the HDMI to the Oculus Rift. Another alternative is to buy a graphics amplifier but that will cost you quite a bit of money :/My fault and not theirs :(

My first one broke after less than a month... after receving my second one i got some  problems with the sensor for finally making a full refund, thx to amazon for having such good return policies .  I love Vr game but i dont want to waste my money either. For a full experience you need to buy a third sensor, some extension cable and there a lot of game to buy on top of thats so prepare your wallet!

one_reviews_text: Original rift . Poor quality graphics new units much much better . Got quest after this still poor graphics . Quest two and new gen of Vr much better graphically but wait for true 4 k per eye in a standalone type like quest . Hate wires and don’t like having to need pc . Few more generations will be awesome .
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on October 23, 2020

one_reviews_text: I got this for DCS World after a friend showed me their setup, and it opened up a whole new world to me. I hadn't played with flight sims in forever because it never felt very immersive -- just staring at a flight, narrow screen, even when the graphics were amazing like in DCS or FSX. But having the ability to look around and actually feeling a bit of vertigo the first time you bank the plane after takeoff is an unreal experience. This is probably as close as you can get to the experience of flying without actually stepping in a plane (or an expensive commercial sim).That said, this version of the Rift still has the grainy "screen door" resolution and a relatively narrow peripheral vision. I think the updated version is better. For my money, i'll happily spend this amount annually to get a more and more immersive experience.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on January 10, 2020

one_reviews_text: The Rift is a great system, it's a value VR option with more bang for the buck with better controllers than the Vive (for now), I was mainly planning to use it for art (Tilt Brush, Medium, Quill, Gravity Sketch), the touch controllers are great for content creation but the headset was too small and the face mask was putting too much pressure on my cheekbones. It's a great system but you'll have to look elsewhere you if you have a larger than average head.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on December 8, 2018
review_title: The touch controllers are awesome but go for the Vive if you have a large head.

one_reviews_text: i really wanted a htc vive but, man, how rich do they think we are? so i compromised my principals and bought a rift. what a great toy. i had an installation issue that the oculus tech helped me solve very quickly. the vive support took days to answer my question but these guys are fast. i'd still like a vive but i think at those prices its never gonna happen. if you gonna buy this get a stand and lens protectors too. the case it comes in is good enough for a few trips. take note htc.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on February 12, 2019
review_title: best thing i ever bought since my first motorcycle

one_reviews_text: Just beautiful. The display is awesome, I don't notice any SDE and the god rays aren't that bad (but they are there frequently). The touch controllers fit like a glove. The tracking is surprisingly good for room scale with only 2 sensors. 3rd sensor on the way now, because what's another 79$ when the HTC Vive is over twice the price to begin with.ORDER USB 3.0 EXTENSIONS 6-15ft! You can definitely get by without them, but it will make all the difference.The actual headset cables are pretty decent in length. Probably best to buy another 6-10 ft for a big room though.Everything runs silky smooth fantastic!i5-6600k OC 4.4Ghz16Gb Corsair Dominator Platinum 3000MhzMsi Krait 3Xkracken X61EVGA GTX1070 FTW - factory overclockWD 1Tb HDSamsung 120Gb SSDEVGA 750W PSU
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on August 18, 2017
review_title: BUY IT... Buy it NOW. Mind blowing fun!! Hard to be disappointed!

one_reviews_text: Having your hands in VR makes an overwhelming difference. It is a bit disappointing that so many games don't use the thumbsticks for movement, making these feel a little too much like a stopgap for true gloves. That said they are incredible comfortable to hold, robust (I have smacked them into my walls full force a few times) and only take a single AA battery each. The cost also makes a little more sense when you consider that all the buttons, triggers and even a few selected blank spots are touch sensitive, giving the illusion that it's tracking your fingers.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on May 30, 2017
review_title: Slick tech that can take a beating.

one_reviews_text: This adds so much to the Oculus Rift experience, it really is a must buy for anyone who owns just a Rift HMD. The controllers are very comfortable in the hand, much better than the HTC Vive controllers. I much prefer the design of the 'grip' button over the HTC Vive's as well. They are quite durable as well, having punched my wall with them a number of times (Echo Arena and Gorn) and they did more damage to the wall than the controller.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on February 3, 2018

one_reviews_text: I think the VR stuff is great but there is not enough good content to really make you want to use it.you can fit small glasses inside but it can still be a pain and fog up can happen. It would be nice to have a focus feature so the user's do not need to wear glassesThe cable is connected to the headset and can get pull quite a bit I see this being something that can break it. extensions do not always work. They need to make a bluetooth version
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on August 3, 2018

one_reviews_text: I had the Samsung gear vr and this is SOOoo much better, the gear only allows for head turning and point/click/aim with remote controller, but the rift supports your actual movements, tracks if you stand or kneel or move around. Much better interactivity and the hand controllers let you do more things like grab thing. review_title: At first I was hesitant to buy it, but ...

one_reviews_text: Other than the HTC Vive that i tried for 20 minutes in a Microsoft store demo, I'm totally new to the VR world of entertainment. So i did my research on the Rift: other users complained about how difficult it was to setup and configure because of their system hardware, while others complained about not being able to get Rift to work at all and how Oculus tech support is completely useless. My system has the MSI 970A Gaming Pro Carbon mobo with 16 GB of RAM and I'm using the AMD R9 290 Video card (3 yrs old at this point!). There's enough USB v3.0 and v2.0 ports to support the Rift requirements. All of the hardware is running at stock speeds, nothing is over-clocked. Installing the Oculus s/w was simple... trying to get the s/w to detect the sensors and headset was a nightmare... I was experiencing the same problems that other users had. My mobo uses the VIA USB eXtensible Host Controller and Oculus says that this is incompatible... i guess they're right! So i bought the StarTech PCI-e superspeed USB 3.0 card... still no luck and after 4 hours of f***ing around with everything I said the hell with it and plugged EVERYTHING into the USB v2.0 ports and Rift works absolutely perfect (go figure) under Win 7 pro and Win 10 pro (i'm dual booting). I don't know why they say to use USB v3 because the sensors seem to work perfect and fast enough... i haven't experienced any lag or slowness under USB v2.0! Getting the sensors placed right took some time but eventually got it! I am totally and completely blown away by the Rift VR experience that i would buy this again and would recommend Rift to anyone! You have to try Robo Recall and Google Earth VR... they're both amazing!! Want to mention too that I bought the extra sensor for that 360° roomscale... it makes your VR experience completely immersive!
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on May 25, 2018
review_title: You really got to try this!

one_reviews_text: By far the best purchase I made last year. I purchased it to play with a flight simulator Il-2 sturmovik. There’s plenty of oculus reviews I’ll just focus on the pros and cons for the game I bought the headset mainly for.Pros: The immersion is far better than I expected. The best feature surprised me, which was that you have depth perception like in 3D movies. The only way I think this works is because you have two separate eye screens which makes telling distances completely intuitive. I actually find leading aircraft easier in VR than on a screen.I had to fly carefully for my first 10 hours or I’d get sick looking down at the ground below. After 15 hours or so Im doing loops and rolls and never feel sick.Cons: Spotting aircraft is a little tough in il-2 due to the screen door effect (lower res) but the VR zoom feature helps a lot. Requred a new processor and some graphics settings optimization to keep Il-2 running at 60-90 FPS.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on January 24, 2019

one_reviews_text: I purchased a computer particularily because it was VR ready. I had a very difficult time to get it to connect up and when I did finally get the visual working on the head set, I was not impressed with the dropout on the image with a slight side to side eye movement. With a head rotation at all, the picture completely collapsed and was very slow to recover. The computer would crash completely and require a total re-boot to get the monitor to come back on. Ran through this pain a few times and returned the system for a refund. Should have bought a cheap computer and left VR to someone else to learn about. I would have thought VR was around enough to be okay, guess not!
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on January 27, 2019

one_reviews_text: These controllers make all the difference in VR.I'm still amazed how cool it feels to have your hands in the game world with you. Wiggling your finger at another player, or giving someone the thumbs up after they score is such a cool feeling. I did an air guitar gesture after a goal in Echo Arena and another player was like "ha, love the air guitar!"Anyway, these things are amazing and totally worth the money. I whacked a few walls and ceilings with them and they still work perfectly.

review_title: Touch controllers are a necessity for VR, and these are very durable and perform excellently.

one_reviews_text: Well lets start this review off with the positives but the negatives are VERY important.relevent system specs: win10, AMD R9290x i5-3690kPros: interesting novel feel of being "inside" the game.Extremely fun for non competitive and BVR aerial combat (slighly nauseating dogfighting in WW2 airplanes)Extremely fun for rally driving sims (dirt rally) as you get 3D depth perception making driving feel more realistic.Cons:Even though my video card supports the oculus rift you need to make sure your GPU has atleast 1 Available HDMI slot that is not occupied by your main or secondary monitor as you need to have your main display AND Oculus rift (OR) plugged into it simultaneously. (costed me 20 bucks for a VGA cord and my main monitor now uses VGA :(Lenses fog up constantly for about half an hour into your game session (probably depends on your local climate as not everyone experiences this.Low Resolution: Resolution is quite low so in war thunder simulated battles you only see a black dot without a visual indicator of what type of vehicle it is until its within 1k, with your monitor you can zoom in and tell via silhouette from easily 8+ km away what plane it is. Also textures tend to look much worse in your sim games (almost like there is no anti aliasing and your screens are very close to your face so you can see individual pixels.You tend to see a bloom affect from lighting due to the design of the lenses so you are frequently finding yourself fiddling with the device trying to keep it as centered as possible on your face to reduce obscurities. (this tends to take you out of the "zone" that VR has the tendency of getting you into.Many games get frame stutter and i'm not entirely sure if this is the device being poorly optimized or the fact that your GPU MUST display the game on your main display + 2 albeit lower resolution images (1 per eye) on the rift. This means a game you are normally displaying just once must now be displayed 3fold instead of 2fold.On December 14th a REQUIRED update that was unannounced or optional (also released Friday night due to inexperienced development company) bricked my device for the weekend. There is no way of rolling back my software for the device to use it for the weekend. (this isn't the first time this has happened either, march 2018)This device (and it would seem these devices) are meant for extremely casual gamers who spend enthusiast bucks and rich people who want the novel experience. I am neither.  For me this product is a clear 0-1 however i do see the point in its existence and think a 2 is fair.User results may vary.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on December 16, 2018
review_title: Horrible technology. 2 day shipping took 7 or 8 buisness days.

one_reviews_text: Works even better than I expected. You definitely want to have as much space as possible. As for the 6 games they give you, 3 of them aren't really games. They're more artsy stuff like drawing and sculpting. But the 3 other games are pretty awesome for being free. The Robot one is basically full fledged VR game. The zombie one is fun and has online multiplayer. And Lucky's Tale doesn't necessarily need to be VR but it's surprisingly still really enjoyable being VR. Set up is pretty easy and straight forward. The cord is decently long but I ended up buying another 6 feet extension (HDMI and USB 3) just so I didn't have to worry. Might eventually buy another sensor for the full 360 tracking but it doesn't seem too important yet. My only concern is that Facebook owns Oculus now and I don't trust Facebook...

one_reviews_text: I got this at the $550ish price range so I am thoroughly pleased.  Some key things to keep in mind:  A) You need a VR-capable video card / machine.  That's not cheap.  B) You need a large enough area to make this work well.  10 by 10?  Doable but tight. Bigger really is better.  C) You are not going to like the resolution.  It's okay for now, but we're all holding our breath for the next gen with higher res.  Years? Maybe.  D) The hand tracking is amazingly well done.  E) The 2 sensors are good enough if you can get them high and in opposite corners of your play space.  FINAL) If you have / can afford all the other dependent things, and have been waiting for VR since you were a kid and love everything about it, go for it.  It's a blast.  Otherwise?  Visit someone who has one.  Have some fun.  Eventually, the novelty will wear off.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on August 19, 2017
review_title: Love everything about VR? Do it.

I've found dickin' around in Oculus Medium (which is a fantastic program!) or working out with Soundboxing to be my calling. There's plenty of decent content to keep you interested, and the games that come with the system are testaments to that - Robo Recall is prolly one of the best FPS in VR.For this price, it's an amazing piece of technology and will blow even the most skeptical away. Buy!

one_reviews_text: The touch is a pretty awesome addition to the rift VR experience, if you can get it all to work together that is.Positives: hardware works greatWhen it works correctly the touch tracking feels spot on, and works very well.I've tested the beta roomscale setup, it kind of works, I can get a 360 play area about 5x5ft in size that works reasonably reliably. For a beta feature it works quite well, and since it's in beta still I'm ignoring any oddities with this setup until they fine tune it a bit more.Negatives: Driver/software issuesBiggest issue I've had with these is terrible driver/software issues. Getting all 3 devices to detect as USB 3 (rift and 2 sensors) appears to be next to impossible. (if anyone is wondering I am using the oculus recommended USB 3 pcie card with the Fresco logic chipset).Frequently one of the trackers or the rift will re-detect as a USB 2 device, which causes it to stop responding for 10seconds before it comes back again.  Just having the items plugged in and not in use, you can hear them disconnecting and reconnecting all day long. Oculus needs to look at this. Nothing is more nauseating than completely losing your head tracking while moving. These issues happened before the touch controllers were added, but now its much more frequent. I was originally going to buy a 3rd tracker for roomscale VR, but I'm going to hold off, hopefully they can figure the drivers out...My recommendation:If you already own a rift, buy the touch.The trackers do add a lot to the immersion, and they are worth buying. The touch ergonomics are great, and they are very intuitive to use and get used to. It's probably worth the buy even if you have to suffer through the driver issues.If you don't have a rift yet, consider the vive instead.I don't say this lightly as I've been an oculus fan since day one. But after my experience with the now whole experience, the HTC Vive is the better package. Their software supports the hardware very well. I've used my friends vive on countless occasions (we both took it to a friend's place and set the systems up side by side). I fiddled with mine for over an hour working on camera placement and angles,  he had his setup in about 15 minutes. And no USB da-dunk noises coming from his setup. The vive just works, the rift needs  'some encouragement' to work, and then it still complains once in a while.Update: January 26, 2017A quick update on the USB driver issues. After searching for a solution to the HMD or sensors dropping out randomly I got directed to Windows USB selective suspend. It's buried under the advanced options of the windows power profile settings. I made a new profile which I called VR, and disabled anything relating to USB and power savings. After this tweak, I'm happy to say my USB disconnect  issues are a thing of the past! I hope Oculus can find a way to get their software to override that setting somehow down the road. But for now this works for me.  Bumped up to a 4 star rating.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on January 1, 2017
review_title: Cool addition to Oculus, needs some tweaking.

one_reviews_text: Ok before I get into the product I'll just say something about VR in general. IT'S AMAZING! I've been a gamer for 35+ years now and I haven't been so floored with a video game experience since I first tried 3D gaming with Mario 64! Aside from enjoying some portable gaming on my Switch, I've had a hard time going back to non VR gaming on a standard monitor. (and I have a high end liquid cooled PC with a 1080ti etc). I bought a 3'rd sensor and set things up for room scale and I've had no issues with tracking.As for the hardware itself, the headset feels nice and seems to be high quality although I've read about a lot of people eventually having issues with the sound on the right ear piece over time. I've also heard people say that there is a rubber piece in the trigger(s) of the touch controllers that are known to come off and cause the feel/tension of the triggers to change for the worse. After owning my Rift for only 1 month, the index finger trigger on the right touch controller sounds squeaky, like there may well be something going on with that trigger, although the feeling itself of the trigger remains the same, so far anyways. In regards to USB ports, I have tons of USB 3.0 ports but I kept getting notifications every few days that a given sensor was not tracking well or some such, and would redo the setup and have them be detected as being plugged in a USB 2.0 port although they were in fact in USB 3.0 ports. It bugged be enough I eventually bought a dedicated 4 x USB 3.0 port, 4 x USB Controllers, USB PCIE card and haven't had any issues in weeks since then.While I have yet to deal with customer service as my unit is still basically fine, (aside from the right touch index trigger starting to squeak) I've read a LOT of Rift related Customer Service horror stories on Reddit and the general consensus on Rift related CS seems to be that it is fairly bad. I find this somewhat surprising since the Rift should have all that FaceBook money to support it; It's not like it's backed by some little startup.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on October 2, 2017
review_title: VR is amazing. The headset is pretty great, the controllers are comfy but apparently customer service is rather lacking.

one_reviews_text: I did go to a local store where you can rent both Rift and Vive for 1 hrs each. Even if the Oculus were more expensive I would still choose Oculus over Vive. Both headset are awesome, tracking is perfect for both... But the Vive controller are a joke compare to the Rift. With the Touch you get the perfect immertion, you forgot that you have a controller and think you use your real hand in game. Vive controller are just non natural huge stick. Maybe the initial setup is a little bit harder on Rift, but do yourself a favor and buy wall mount  like this one https://www.amazon.ca/gp/product/B06WRWV7RT/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 ... Once correctly set, you will be done forever with setting and enjoy awesome immertion.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on August 20, 2017

one_reviews_text: The touch is a pretty awesome addition to the rift VR experience, if you can get it all to work together that is.Positives: hardware works greatWhen it works correctly the touch tracking feels spot on, and works very well.I've tested the beta roomscale setup, it kind of works, I can get a 360 play area about 5x5ft in size that works reasonably reliably. For a beta feature it works quite well, and since it's in beta still I'm ignoring any oddities with this setup until they fine tune it a bit more.Negatives: Driver/software issuesBiggest issue I've had with these is terrible driver/software issues. Getting all 3 devices to detect as USB 3 (3 sensors) appears to be hard.A solution to the HMD or sensors dropping out randomly I got directed to Windows USB selective suspend. It's buried under the advanced options of the windows power profile settings. Disabled anything relating to USB and power savings. After this tweak, I'm happy to say my USB disconnect issues are a thing of the past! I hope Oculus can find a way to get their software to override that setting somehow down the road.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on January 13, 2018
review_title: Getting all 3 devices to detect as USB 3 (3 sensors) appears to be hard.

one_reviews_text: Room scale works flawlessly with 3 sensors. Excellent build and solid with many ways to adjust for comfort. Very light and tracking is super accurate. I have been a gamer since the early 80's and this is by far the most amazing piece of hardware I've ever bought. Games are more fun than ever, thanks to this. I have high end screens and don't mind this not being 4K. I don't even notice it since it's so much fun and the graphics are still impressive especially if you can super sample with your rig. Don't let the price or the talk fool you, this IS currently the best headset on the market! It is light, you can read text with it and has superb sound from the built-in headphones. (I'm rather picky about sound too) The controllers are just amazing and you get six good to excellent games. Just get it.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on November 28, 2017

one_reviews_text: Great product. Beats the HTC Vive hands down. I tried both before I purchased and there were no questions after. It sits on the head in a balanced way. I haven't had tearing or disconnect. Can't go wrong with the Oculus!  I do wish they offered compatable extension cables and a third sensor through the company instead of having to hunt them down.

review_title: Great product. Beats the HTC Vive hands down

one_reviews_text: ...and so the VR wars start.  People going on which system is better...  The Rift is great,  never tried the Vive, so I can not compare.  I used the Rift mostly on games such as DCS World and Elite Dangerous.  Both cockpit based games.  Changes a lot with the experience , even if you're using a TrackIR or something similar.  FPS games are completely different than just using a mouse and keyboard.  Instead of clicking a button to aim down the sights, you move the weapon to your eye.  If you shoot rifles in real life, you may find it very awkward to use them in VR.  Not having a stock to put in your shoulders, or a fore-end to hold weird.  One handed weapons, such as handguns and knives are okay.  Bows are in between.  You trade off some visuals for an immersive 3D experience.  If Dead Space became a VR game, I would need lots of spare pants.  The number one thing do realize, is that VR is still in an experimental stage.  Spending over $500, on something you don't know if you'll like is a gamble.  I have zero regrets on my Rift, and can't wait when the 2nd gen of VR comes out.  I refuse to play any flight/space simulator anymore, unless I have a VR headset.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on November 1, 2017
review_title: Why haven't you bought this yet?

one_reviews_text: Its nice the graphics are OK up close but any distance is not great  head set is comfortable but sweaty as it gets warm about 20 or thirty minutes is all I can stand between the sweat in the eyes and nausea, flying games are OK but get too close to the ground and the stomach starts rolling  VR will be great soon I think but just not up to par yet, but looks promising it is an awesome experience even with the for mentioned things I didn't like, do not regret my purchase but for now just a novelty as I still do  %90  of my gaming on conventional monitors.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on September 30, 2017

one_reviews_text: Although it is a fantastic product, my standards are higher than the average consumer when it comes to video games. Although this provides a fantastic experience when playing something that doesn't have fast movements from side to side, it's not that great for racing games. The resolution is too blurry to see the dashboard gauges and when looking to my side to see another car, there is a double image that hurts my eyes.Apart from the headset, the touch controllers are amazing. Very comfortable and light and easy to learn. When you get this product, make sure to try Robo Recall and Echo Arena (possible motion sickness at first but you'll get used to it).This is a quality product when it comes to VR, only get this if you have the money for it and absolutely need it. If you are a gamer into higher end gear, wait for the next generation.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on May 9, 2018

one_reviews_text: We love the Oculus. It's so much fun. There are games for the family, games that make you sweat and provide a great workout. It's truly amazing. The future of gaming for sure. Just a warning to people looking at buying it. Read the limited warranty. They only provide you with a refurbished device if you have a hardware problem. We ran into a hardware problem 1 month in and they are telling us they are sending us a refurbished unit. Not okay. They only have email support and it takes them days to reply. You will never speak to a live person. Common occulus, get with the times, everyone has online chat support these days. I'm not saying don't buy the Oculus. I think for price, it's an amazing product. Just research before you buy. Look at the other VR competitors and see what their service is like by reading forums, and find out what their warranty period is before buying. We can't wait for A headset to be returned. We've grown to love it and have had so much fun with it, in the little time we've had it.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on April 10, 2018
review_title: Hours of fun but research before you buy.

one_reviews_text: If you are on the fence about VR this setup is amazing. I looked into it a bit before buying and bought the 3rd sensor and any extension cables required for true roomscale and installed it like that. Blew my mind. Its so great. Ive never used the conpetitors hut will say this. Occulus is all about the user experience. They want smooth gameplay and a good experience, so sometimes wont put features in even though it might say look better but could end up causing stuttering or small jerks. This means in general an occulus experience will be a good one. I highly recommend. Hard to play normal pc games after this. Something as simple as google earth is amazing in vr, flying around, frombsitting on the top of mount everest to watching the sun come up over mount fiji. Its feels like you are there, and you just dont get that feeling in normal google earth.  I have zero regrets about this purchase. My wife's hardly into pc  or console games and she just loves beatsaber, plays it almost daily.

one_reviews_text: I was honestly a bit disappointed when using the Oculus Rift headset on its own. I never felt immersion, being able to look around a space was interesting but not really worth the low resolution of the headset.After getting these everything changed. I feel much more immersed in games, shooting and picking up objects with my real hands provides gameplay experiences I've never experienced before, and I don't even notice the low resolution anymore because I'm so immersed and most gameplay with these controllers involves interacting with objects close to you.If you are interested in VR, these are essential to the experience. They are a bit expensive but feel worth the price. They do not need a USB port, once you insert the AA batteries into the controllers and press a button, your Oculus app should detect them automatically. A lot of effort was clearly put into the design and ease of use of these controllers.

one_reviews_text: The hype is real. If you haven't tried a VR system from one of the three main players - Oculus, Vive, and Sony - and think it's not worth looking into, you're clearly missing out.I've tried Sony's PS VR last October launch and was floored on how "real" it can seem. From the get go this was the poor man's choice. For under a grand (including the console), you have a great VR system.Fast forward to three months later and Oculus finally improves their VR system in December 2016 with the release of their Oculus Touch. To date these are hands down the best VR controllers you could ever use. No dorky Sony Move motion controllers with a big ball of light at the end. No gamepad devices needed at all. And that's the point of this Oculus bundle - to prove once and for all who is the best at making a VR system.This bundle takes pre-existing hardware - the Oculus Rift, 2 x Oculus Touch devices (for each hand), and 2 x Oculus Sensors - and packages it into one big box.So unlike the earlier days where you get a "free" Microsoft Xbox One controller with the package (simply because they didn't have the Touch then), now you can kiss the gamepad goodbye and rightly so. Using the Touch is so comfortable after an hour of actual play and the device becomes natural to hold and the resulting buttons become second nature.GET READY:1. You'll need a PC that meets minimum specs. If you're not a techie and don't know or understand what you have, all you need to do is download and run the Oculus Compatibility Check Tool.If you have an older machine and would like to take the opportunity to upgrade, I would highly suggest looking into their Oculus-ready certified computers from manufacturers such as Asus. If you're a techie, then you probably built one yourself and at this point more than meets the recommended requirements.2. In that PC you will need the following extra outlets:- 2 x USB 3.0 ports for the two Oculus Sensors (not USB 2.0 ports on this one)- 1 x USB 2.0 port for the Oculus Rift hardware for power and digital audio- 1 x HDMI port from your video card which effectively makes the Rift a second (or third) monitor depending on your current set up.- optional (1 x USB 3.0 port for the third Oculus Sensor for true 360 degree of play)GET SET:From unpacking the bundle, you can get a head start by already downloading the Oculus software. This application is essential and walks you through connecting the devices into your computer, to getting you up and running by positioning the Sensors correctly and creating room boundaries, to finally explaining how their VR works in conjunction with the Touch controllers.GO:The same Oculus software installs the actual application that runs the Oculus hardware. Whenever you wear the headset, it sends a signal back to the computer and launches the application, if it isn't open already. This is the gateway to running everything that feeds into the Rift controlling the Sensors.The software is also where you purchase and download games and movies. After having set up and registered your Oculus Touch this is where you check which free games (if included) you can download as well.Most of the games/videos are around 1GB in size so not only will you need a fast internet connection, you'll definitely need a very big hard drive as it fills up fast.REALITY OF VIRTUAL REALITY:You'll want a computer system that runs on the recommended specifications. This ensures zero lag. Remember, your world is now 360 degrees and your computer processing needs to keep up with you as you interact in the VR world in real-time. When you look, up, down, left, right and all the way back, everything needs to be rendered and there for you instantaneously to interact.First-time users can also expect to have motion sickness. It does take getting used to in having your senses adapt to the VR world.So why choose Oculus?For one, comfort. The headset isn't heavy, but it's not light either. They have created one that is very easy to wear and very easy to make adjustments. The velcro straps for the left, right, and top bands are easy to move about. This is important especially while wearing and when sharing among different users.There is one long cable attached to the headset and onto your computer which splits into an HDMI and USB port. This is unlike HTC Vive's more awkward cable set up. The least you can do is try to have cables including the headset itself be unobtrusive as you immerse yourself into the VR world. In the future when VR can finally go wireless, this won't be an issue.The Touch is the most comfortable and most intuitive gaming pad than the other two. It fits natural and feels like an extension to your hand. Where the Touch starts and ends is where you expect your whole hand to be. No extra length like the Vive and no glowing ball like the PS VR.There are exclusive contents between the three VR providers and that's the reality you just have to accept. Some of these exclusive contents do cross-over to the other platforms as the exclusivity ends unless it's co-devloped by the manufacturer themselves.And with Oculus, you can actually run Valve's games by enabling third-party support.I wouldn't hesitate recommending Oculus VR hardware and would buy two if this was possible in one PC. It's the best combination out there for 2017. And with the Summer of Rift promotion, you can't go wrong. It's been a hit that supply couldn't keep up with demand. And in fact Sony followed suit and lowered their PS VR pricing as well.Don't hesitate. The hype is real for Oculus.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on August 11, 2017
review_title: The hype is real. Oculus Rift + Touch is the clear winner for 2017.

one_reviews_text: I thought I was just buying a fashionable pair of glasses, but turns out this is a magical device that will teleport you to a fantasy land, where you can shoot robots in the face, slice stuff with your katanas or fly around to the deepest Space in your spaceship.I removed a star because I smashed my monitor swinging my katanas around, but who cares about this stupid real world monitor when I can have a better, bigger one in the virtual world! Good bye work, girlfriend and responsabilities, Im gonna be sipping my drink on the beach of some random planet million miles away!10/10, would Ocule again.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on January 16, 2019
review_title: Is this the real world? Is this just fantasy?

one_reviews_text: You know what, I loved my Rift. It worked great and I loved the games and the 360 tracking and everything to do with VR gaming. Why the 1 star you ask? Oculus decided to drop the support on this product. After many hours of playing high action games my main cable started to lose contact somewhere inside. So now as I move around I get my picture cutting in and out. I contacted Oculus and they said they no longer carry parts for these and I should look into buying their new model! The Rift S! Are you kidding me? So I just throw this 500+ dollar investment in the Garbage?I just bought a new laptop that is VR ready and I was hoping to get a new headset with Inside out tracking so I can take it with me. Well It won't be an oculus product that's for dam'd sure!Oculus I love my Rift but if you aren't going to sell replacement parts for it anymore perhaps you should just pull the product all together!P.S. I pulled the cable appart to see if I could fix it myself. Dozens of tiny wires in the cable. No chance of finding the break.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on September 22, 2019
review_title: No More support or parts available for these DON"T BUY!!!

one_reviews_text: I bought this a year ago, very few days went by without me putting this thing on my face. I met a lot of peoples in Oculus home, VR chat etc. even made a few good friends. Some have the new rift S some have the GO and the Quest from what I heard from peoples who have them all or a few, the original Rift is the best, all of them have their plus and minus but even with the pain of setting up the sensors the original Rift seems to be the best bang for bucks. You definitely need a dedicated place to set it up once and for all and there's the cable but it's just awesome. Some peoples will b**ch about the poor resolution and that the other is better but believe me once you put this on the resolution is definitely not what you focus on. I don't have eagle eyes and that (for some) annoying "screen door effect" is not a problem for me, I just focus on the content like i'm supposed to do instead of squinting my eyes to look for the annoying things. I replaced the foam face thing with a VR cover(VR cover.com) The headphones on the headset broke after a while and I'm using a separate pair of headphones, no problems what so ever to replace. After a year and a few months i'm still happy I bought the original Rift
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on June 24, 2019

one_reviews_text: I find amazon hard to get customer service. Im am trying to find out if my Oculus Rift is defective?All the research that I have done suggests my PC is more than enough needed .My Video card is a AMD Radeon RX 580 4GB GDDRVAll Oculus test come back great other than video card. I purchaced a Microsoft Mixed Reality headset to see if it would work. Works great. I am very confused.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on January 22, 2018

one_reviews_text: When watching people play VR on YouTube, I assumed it was just like a game screen in front of your face where you controlled the look by moving your head...which sounded fun, so I bought one.Holy cow! When actually putting on VR it is much more realistic than just a game screen in front of your eyes, plus the graphics look different, less cartoony, more realistic.I wear glasses to see far away, I assumed that because I was putting a screen close to my eyes that I would not need glasses, but this thing emulates real life so well that I actually need to wear my glasses.I have a basic gaming PC that does not meet the minimum requirements, although I can still play some things, it is enough of a motivator for me to build a better gaming rig, but for now I can do enough on my current PC.2 Cons:1) I went to plug in my rift this morning only to find that the HDMI was not working, I tried another item in the same HDMI port and it worked, so I thought my rift was broken...Turns out I just had to unplug and replug where the cable connects to the actual headset. It would be nice if I was told to try this as I had to google a lot of articles, most telling me that my computer/rift was broken.2) After coming back to "reality" I do feel a slight wavyness, kinda like the feeling you get after you get off a rollercoaster, but not as intense. This lasts for about 5-10 minutes then goes away. It would be nice if they could somehow get rid of this side-effect.My favorite part of the VR experience is when things almost kill you, like in robo recall when the robots turn from good robots to bad robots and come at you, or when the spider robots jump and almost land on you, but you shotgun them before they damage you. These scenarios are actually terrifying yet so much fun at the same time.This brings gaming to a whole new level, you gotta try this thing! 10/10
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on October 20, 2018
review_title: Not At All What I Expected

one_reviews_text: I can't say much other than I didn't even try and use two sensors when I bought my Oculus. I ended up ordering a 3rd one from Amazon early and it was here a day before I planned to purchase my Oculus. (purchased Oculus Rift in store at Best Buy because Amazon would take 2 months to deliver.) Sensor works great. I'm using it with https://www.amazon.ca/gp/product/B01FJJ3Q2K/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 (light stands) and https://www.amazon.ca/gp/product/B0179LJV6Q/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1 (so I can adjust them). The box came with a 16ft 2.0 usb active extender by monoprice so don't do what I did and assume you need one and waste 18 bucks.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on November 8, 2018

one_reviews_text: I ordered this directly from Oculus during the boxing week sale and got it even cheaper with a referral discount. The packaging is awesome and I haven't had a better unboxing experience than this. Everything comes well secured and the sensors are even held into place in the box by velcro that's a part of the box. Everything came well protected and setup was quick and easy when you follow the instructions in the software. I do run a pretty basic full room setup for games like beat saber and superhot. If you want a proper full room setup you will need a third sensor at least and I plan on making it four. Love it and recommend it highly.

one_reviews_text: My friend purchased this and I got to use it. It's pretty much all I can think about! Completely blew my mind. My own computer isn't currently powerful enough to run an Oculus, but that's the only thing holding me back from buying one. You should check out the game, The Climb to see just how different and amazing the experience of VR is. It's an infinite screen - you can look in any direction at any time. The visuals are all LIFE size. And you can actually move around and see your hands in a virtual world! The only thing holding this back is the need for a more powerful computer, but that's only a few years away for most people, I think! VR is coming!

one_reviews_text: Excellent technology. The Rift Headset is amazing already.  The Touch controllers feel great in your hands, well balanced, with more options for interactions than the Vive controllers.  VR is the future of computer interfaces. Buying the Touch includes over 100$ worth of games and sculpting software too, such as The Unspoken, Dead and Buried, Robo Recall, Medium, Quill. Try Rec Room paintball as well, good fun.  It does need a bit of space to move around in and some tinkering due to some problems with USB 3 sensors not getting enough consistent power, so Oculus recommends getting an extra USB 3.0 PCI card (Inatek one on Amazon is ~ 30$) and disabling power management on USB ports.  I used a powered USB hub and that helped me.  So then there are also all the Steam/Vive games the oculus can now play because it is SteamVR compatible.  There is so much software/games now for it, that I can't get to it all. Sims, shooters, arcade, social, etc.  With the Touch, Oculus has completed their VR vision and caught up (and surpassed even?) to the Vive and once it is all working well, it is a marvel to play with.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on December 19, 2016
review_title: Premium VR, at its best. Includes many games for free!

one_reviews_text: [UPDATE vom 27. Januar 2019]Ich muss hier mal kurz was richtig stellen, da ausgerechnet die verlogenste und falscheste (Ein-Stern-)Rezension ganz oben als Top-Rezension gelistet wird.Sie ist einfach komplett falsch und zieht das Image dieses grandiosen Produkts völlig zu Unrecht in den Dreck.Erstens: "Spionage seitens Facebook"--> Man kann die Brille/Software komplett ohne Facebook verwenden und man muss sich nicht über Facebook anmelden. Das ist Fakt, Punkt.Eine einfache Registrierung mit ausgedachtem Nutzernamen, Passwort und Email genügt um die Oculus Rift in vollem Funktionsumfang zu nutzen.Zweitens: "10EUR im Monat für Batterien"--> Ich weiß ja nicht wo Sie ihre Batterien beziehen, aber für 10€-12€ inklusive Versand bekomme ich auf Amazon 40 Batterien, die etwa eineinhalb Jahre halten dürften. 30h Batterielaufzeit ist auch nicht wenig, sondern sehr viel.Ich benutze einfache AA-Akkus, welche ich etwa alle 4 Wochen (noch vor Entladung) auswechsle und auflade.Drittens: "Beschränkung bei der Sensoreinrichtung"--> Man kann die EMPFEHLUNGEN, die Sensoren anders im Raum aufzustellen GANZ EINFACH per "Weiter" überspringen und mit der Einrichtung fortfahren.Man kann die Sensoren aufstellen wie man möchte und es gibt keine Probleme.So...Und ich möchte nach ziemlich genau einem halben Jahr Nutzung nun nocheinmal sagen, wie zufrieden ich mit der Oculus Rift bin. Ich habe schon sehr viel Zeit in der virtuellen Realität verbracht und viele unvergessliche Spiele gespielt und Erfahrungen gesammelt.Weiterhin kann ich dieses Headset jedem wärmstens ans Herz legen.Es gab bisher wirklich niemanden, der zu Besuch kam, die Rift testete und nicht völlig von ihr gehyped war.Die Zukunft des Gamings hat begonnen![Ursprüngliche Rezension vom 21. Juli 2018]Ok ein paar Worte...Ich hatte zuvor die Samsung Gear VR mit der Oculus Home Software und das war schon ganz gut.Aber das hier ist einfach unfassbar geil und noch viel viel viel (...) besser!Habe mir das Rift Bundle inkl. zwei Controllern am Prime-Day für 399€ gekauft und ich kann nur sagen es war jeden Cent wert!Die Controller fühlen sich an wie die Verlängerung einer echten Hand. Das sorgt für perfekte Immersion.Übrigens reichen die beiden beigelegten Sensoren für ein 360°-Setup.Wenn man sie in die USB-3.0-Frontpanel Steckplätze steckt braucht man noch nicht einmal Verlängerungskabel.Ich habe mir dennoch 2x 3m Amazon Basics USB-3.0-Kabel dazugekauft um sicherzugehen, dass der Platz reicht.Jedenfalls muss man in der Kalibrierung einfach die Warnung ignorieren, dass die zwei Sensoren etwas zu weit auseinander stehen.Für ein optimales 360°-Setup sollte einer der beiden Sensoren von unten und der andere von oben auf den Spielbereich gerichtet sein.Desweiteren sollten sie genau 180° zueinander stehen, damit alles genaustens abgedeckt wird.Danach muss man wirklich keinerlei Abstriche machen - Es funktioniert perfekt!Wer bei 400€ nicht zuschlägt ist wirklich selbst Schuld.Günstiger wirds nicht. Habe mir wie gesagt noch 2x Kabel dazugekauft, sowie heute noch ein VR-Cover/Polster, da man beim längeren Zocken schon ein wenig ins Schwitzen kommen kann und dann dieser schwammartige Schaumstoff sich mit Schweiß vollsaugt.Allerdings kann man diesen recht schnell wieder mit einem Handtuch trocken drücken. Ein bisschen unhygienisch finde ich es trotzdem, weshalb ich mir das Polster bestellt habe.Angeblich soll 2020 die Nachfolgegeneration erscheinen.In zwei Jahren wird also aufgerüstet - Ich bin völlig verzaubert.Please take all my money!Danke.PS:Die Oculus braucht MINDESTENS eine Grafikkarte des Typs GTX970.Ich habe sie auch auf meinem Laptop mit der deutlich langsameren GTX970M betrieben, was akzeptabel funktioniert in anspruchslosen Anwendungen und Spielen. Ich empfehle jedoch dringend mindestens eine GTX1060.Selbst nutze ich eine übertaktete und wassergekühlte GTX1080 mit Power-Limit-Mod.Je besser die Grafikkarte, desto besser das Erlebnis! Das muss einem klar sein.
review_date: Reviewed in Germany on July 21, 2018

one_reviews_text: Stunning, absolutely stunning.I got a little bonus through work that significantly reduced the 'real' money cost of my picking up a Rift, which I had been mulling over for a while, so I pulled the trigger and bought it.  Had I known what the experience would be like, I would have paid full price a long time back.I last used a VR headset probably in the early 90's on an old arcade cabinet, and remember the screen chugging along to keep up with my head movements.  As my PC, while reasonably pokey, is getting on a bit in years, with a 980GTX powering it, I envisaged something similar.  Wrong.  When you put the headset on, every tiny movement of your head is replicated in real-time in your view through the Rift.  It can be quite disconcerting - one of the early things I did was a series of demos, one of which places you on a gantry hundreds of feet above a city street, which made my stomach back-flip with vertigo despite knowing I was stood in the middle of my office.But what about the games Snowy, I hear you ask?  £400 is a lot to put down just for a clever tech demo right?  Well there are some amazing titles.  Robo Recall - free with the Oculus Touch controller package - is great fun, shooting, punching, tearing robots to pieces.  Skyrim VR is quite breathtaking (although I had forgotten the giant spiders, which in VR are utterly massive and made this late-40's male reviewer make a VERY un-heroic squeak).  SuperHot VR makes you feel like Neo from The Matrix, grabbing weapons, hurling objects, all while avoiding incoming bullets and enemies.  Beat Sabre will become a party-game classic with it's rhythm-based lightsaber action.  I own but have yet to try Subnautica.The game that has wowed me the most though, Elite Dangerous.  I have played E:D since the beta, and always loved the scale of the game.  Played in VR it is a completely different experience though, as you are teleported into your ship's cockpit, and suddenly the scale of the world around you is breathtaking.  Space stations are immense, planets and suns look like...planets and suns.  Other spaceships can be huge.  Glancing at different screens within the ship lets you adjust things on the fly that would usually require extensive keyboard shortcuts, so I fly using my Saitek X52 setup exclusively.  Dogfighting enemy ships is a whole new experience, as you naturally head-track them, allowing you to fly that much more accurately and aggressively.  It really is mindblowing what a difference a new perspective makes.All told, this will not be a flash in the pan gimmick, it is a truly revolutionary experience.  If you are on the fence, take the plunge, you will not regret it.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 29, 2018

one_reviews_text: Alleine wegen der Spionage seitens Facebook, und wie aufwendig die Workarounds dafür sind gibt es bereits 2 Sterne Abzug, desweiteren Wird alles was man im Virtuellen Raum von näher als einen halben Meter betrachtet extrem verschwommen, was ein bekanntes Problem ist, ich hab mich darüber mit einigen Oculus und Vive Nutzern unterhalten, es ist ein Fehler seitens Oculus der selbst nach 2 Jahren nicht behoben wurde. Dann wären da noch die AA Batterien in den Controllern die ca. 30h halten also entweder 10EUR im Monat für Batterien ausgeben oder Akkus kaufen, und so oder so muss man die Dinger andauernd tauschen was absolut nervig ist und nichts im Jahr 2018 verloren hat. Einen weiteren Stern musste ich wegen der absolut lachhaften Beschränkung bei der Sensoreinrichtung abziehen. man muss mindestens 1,5m vom Sensor entfernt sein, Sie müssen Zentral aufgestellt sein, ich will sie verdammmtnochmal aufstellen wie ICH will, nicht wie Oculus es VORSCHREIBT. Dann hätten wir da noch den Preis welcher nach wie vor absolut übertrieben ist, dennoch werde ich bei all den Mängeln lieber 600 EUR für die Vive in die Hand nehmen.Fazit: Ich rate vom Kauf ab.Edit: Ich bezahle lieber mit EURO als mit meiner Privatsphäre. Ich habe jetzt seit einer Woche die Vive und bin glücklich damit. Und die meckert auch nicht bei der Sensoreinrichtung rum, bei der kann ich sogar hingehen und einen Sensor unter meinen verdammten Schreibtisch stellen, funzt perfekt, die Oculus meckert, mimimi du bist zu nah an den Sensoren, mimimi die Sensoren sind zu nah beieinander, mimimi sie sind nicht zentral, mimimi du musst einen nach außen drehen. Es ist ein krampf bei kleineren Räumen... Ach und bei meiner momentanen Nutzung wären es sogar 20 EURO im Monat für Batterien, NEIN DANKE.
review_date: Reviewed in Germany on November 2, 2018

Now the product is under warranty, and I am stuck in between; thinking whom to contact. Both are simply diverting to each other.Awaiting for resolution and its been 4 months so far. thanks!
