review_title: No support even after multiple follow-up

one_reviews_text: A lot of people with VR headsets told me this is the next best thing. That nothing can beat VR. There might come the day when that will be the case, but today is not that day. Here are the major issues with VR at the moment:1. almost all games/experieces are expensive gimmicks, meant to keep you interested an hour at best; some of them are only a few hours long;2. The best games out there, in which you manually move your character, produce nausea and need to be played in short bursts;3. easy to get caught in cables when using the headset;4. large playspace required for best feeling; best I can do is 1.50m x 1.50m and i can feel the borders;5. graphical textures are sub-par, resembling something of the 16-bit textures of the original Medal of Honor;6. all VR websites are, at the moment, gimmicks. fun to see once, maybe twice, but not exactly part of your daily feed;7. (Oculus VR specific) very finicky to set-up; had to look up online solutions since one of the sensors wouldn't install; you also need 3 (THREE) USB ports free and 1 HDMI port, which is a bit bollocks; at that price you'd think it could come with a USB extension;8. Gets EXTREMELY hot under the headset;9. If you have a big head and glasses, better get some contact lenses, otherwise it's impossible to wear them comfortably.It's not all bad though and when it hits, it hits home. VR is by far the most immersive experience you will get with a game; no-matter how bad the graphics are, you can't beat the "being there" feeling. Also some of the most fun games/apps to use with it are cheap or free and a few of the games the Oculus VR comes with are rather fun.But the main problem is that VR at the moment is a gimmick. A fun gimmick with great potential but still too expensive for what it has to offer (and that's just talking about headset price, without adding high-end PCs into the mix).If you are not rich and don't live in a mansion with your own gaming room, wait a few more years until the next gen of headsets come out. For everybody else, Oculus VR is currently the superior choice on the market but that's not saying much.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on September 18, 2018

one_reviews_text: I could just blow smoke up you know where telling you all about this and that feature and how great it is, however you will never know unless you try it yourself because nothing, and I do mean nothing can prepare you for what you'll experience in VR as the level of immersion is on an entirely different level.I've investigated spacial anomalies and rescued my captain as an AI robot, to exploring the depths of an ocean planet where I've crashed landed on. Driven cargo with a truck to flooring it through a dense forest in a rally car. Danced the night away slashing boxes with lightsabers to traversing creepy buildings or watching movies on a massive 50ft screen.After 7 months of use, I've just replaced the original 1xAA battery in each controller after light to moderate use since buying. At £349 when I purchased, this has been the single most best purchase in the last year. Do yourself a favour, invest in this piece of kit, you will not be disappointed.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on July 16, 2018
review_title: The way forward in PC gaming!

one_reviews_text: Since having the Rift for the last 2 years, I no longer have any desire to play anything on a 2D conventional monitor.For those who think VR is 'just a fad', think again.Absolutely fantastic.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 21, 2018

one_reviews_text: I owned the HTC VIVE previously before buying this, I must say I am very impressed by how this feels over the VIVE, if I was to compare on comfort alone this is in a different league! Feels much lighter and the build in speakers are perfect for what you need.Controllers feel much better than the weird VIVE wands too.On a slightly negative side you can easily see that VR still has a long way to go to being perfect, the god rays can be annoying and the resolution isnt anything to write home about.. however as a first generation its still very fun to play around in and id highly recommend buying one if you have a decent enough computer to run it, also Rec Room is probably one of the most fun games I have played.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 2, 2018

one_reviews_text: VR is not for everyone. Make sure you try it somehow before buying as it makes some people nauseous. If you can handle it, have a decent spec PC, a few square metres of space and the money to spare then this is a good buy. I use mine a lot. It's not just games, there are experiences to be had too. You can explore the world map in Google earth or see what astronaughts saw flying to the moon. There are horror movies you can watch that are immersive and creepy. The surround sound from the built in speakers add another layer of depth to any experience. The games range from amazing to very poor as is the case with 2d gaming but all games in the oculus store and on steam have user reviews so there's no need to waste money on the rubbish. Some games require more space than others but the oculus store will warn you before you buy so again you need not waste money. The kit itself is sturdy and well made. The touch controllers are intuitive and comfortable and well thought out. I love mine, it's nice just to escape the real world for a bit. It's also good for a bit of exercise. Games like robo recall and beat sabre will have you using your arms a great deal and you'll break a sweat in no time.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 31, 2018

one_reviews_text: I find it hard to give much credulity to all the gushing reviews about this product. I recognise that, in reasonable conditions, VR can be very stimulating and occasionally impressive. But once you get over the initial shock of seeing 2d images in 3d, you start to assess the woeful shortcomings of the Oculus Rift.Before that I'd like to comment on the setup process. If I go to a store and buy a monitor or tv, I pay the price, bring the box home, set up the device and it works. I do not need to go online and open an account. There is a manual which explains how to set the monitor up, and I certainly do not have to join Facebook to get it working.But no, Oculus forces you not only to be online, but also forces you through a ridiculous setup process which has little to do with helping you to actually run it with decent instructions, but is obsessed with you opening an online account, entering your payment details, and joining facebook. While you can opt out of some of these requirements, Oculus makes it awkward to do so. I DON'T WANT TO JOIN FACEBOOK just to run a visual device. I do not want to give Oculus my personal details so they can now send me endless emails urging me to buy more stuff. I do not want to give them my personal data so they can perpetually badger me to buy more - the device cost enough as it is.By all means give me a CLEAR OPTION, but the setup process is all about marketing, and very little to do with helping me run the Rift effectively.Coming to the Rift itself, I concede that the introductory setup 3d video is amusing, intelligent and a pleasure. The sensor setup is very fiddly and is aimed almost entirely at a user who wants to stand up and thrash around. But actuall, the vast majority of users want to sit down while viewing in VR and do not want a vast area to maneouvre in. But the Oculus setup doesn't like you setting a small, seated area and keeps rejecting any setup that is less than around six feet squared.The packaging is well done and the touch devices and headset at first glance look quite well done, but there are two major flaws with this device. The first is that Oculus claims that using spectacles is no problem. That is completely false. I need glasses, and I have several of them, for reading, distance viewing and other purposes and they are all different strengths. I also have spectacles that have the smallest possible dimensions. NONE of the glasses were wearable with the RIft, Even the tiniest glasses got jammed in the very small space between my nose and the Oculus lenses even if I pulled the fitting to its fullest length. Once you start wearing the device, the tiniest spectacles jam against the lenses, scratching them and also making it impossible to get the headset off with embedding my glasses in the sidewall of the device. That is an ergonomic disaster.Despite the impressive and well built sensors and touch devices, which work very well, the major letdown of the Rift is the lenses. They are of extremely poor quality, scratch easily, get clouded up at the slightest provocation and the horizontal adjustment is far too small. My eyes are an average distance apart but the somewhat tacky adjustment for distance between the lenses is FAR too wide. They need to have a much greater adjustment potential and I would guess that nearly everyone adjusts the lenses to be as close together as possible.There is a so-called "sweet spot" where Oculus claims the lenses come sharply into focus in the vertical plane, but this is also completely untrue. The amount of leeway between vaguely in focus and completely blurred is absolutely tiny. Just half a millimeter rotation up or down makes any detail or text grossly blurred.Now we come to the settings menu, together with the FAQ and so-called "guides" on the Oculus website. NOWHERE on the website or the instructions does Oculus tell you that there is a "debug" mode, without which you will not achieve anything near even vaguely acceptable images. Why is it called "debug" mode and buried away in a folder, unannounced, within the many folders in the Oculus directory? It is a VITAL aid to decent adjustment of many parameters. If you rely on Oculus to help you get to this debug mode, forget it. I only found out by researching away from Oculus's own website. How stupid of them!Not only that but there is no proper explanation of what various "debug" paraments do. The explanations are woefully inadequate.Coming to the resolution and quality or otherwise of the moving image, I have to say I am underwhelmed. I accept that resolution is low for practical reasons and I also accept there is quite a bit of screen door interference. But there is also a huge amount of chromatic aberration, colour mismatches, unwanted flare, washed out contrast, artefacts, etc, all of which point to the poor quality of the lenses, which are by far the most import component. While the packaging and presentation is generally good, the lenses are the one component Oculus have skimped on. They are not up to the job.I use the Rift mainly for flight simulation. Once you've adjusted to the at-first quite impressive and wondrous 3d world you are immersed in, you start to realise that the aircraft gauges are quite impossible to read unless you zoom in ridiculously close, but then the surrounding scenery turns into a mushy blur. It is not that the resolution is too low, or that the screen door effect is off-putting. They are by-products of an as yet unsophisticated technology. What I object to is that the entire image is poor, blurry, fuzzy and indistinct.3d videos do present much better and certain games and other sims just about make the cost of this device worthwhile, but there are so many basic flaws in this device I have to conclude this hardware is nowhere near the standard that could be described as useful in the long term.I recognise that VR is still in comparitive infancy, but Oculus has concentrated too much on nice boxes and slick looking components at the expense of the most important item, the lenses and the fitting of the headset. While it is a bit lighter than the Vive, it is not comfortable for more than around 20 minutes, and after 3 minutes the pressure on the nose support of spectacles is intolerable.I simply do not understand why this product has won so many five star ratings, and I'd be interested to read some long term assessments, which I suspect will starft showing irritation with the basic flaws in this device. While 3d is of course magical and stimulating, this product is nowhere near the sophistication in needs to be in order to use with much enthusiasm in the long term.I realise 3d monitors and Nvidia glasses are now old fashioned, but arguably they give a much better experience than donning a claustrophic device with very poor optics. So it's a thumbs down from me.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 11, 2019

one_reviews_text: This item is a must have for VR lovers. 360 tracking is smooth, fast and adds the extra immersion to the games you play. before I purchased the third sensor, I was almost unable to get the enjoyment I wanted out of games like Robo Recall and Echo arena. Having that extra sensor not only gives you 360* tracking, but it also allows your play space to be slightly larger and your controllers will not ever lose track when you are inside your play space. If you use the oculus and play games like Robo Recall, Echo arena, Lone echo, Rick and Morty: Virtual Rickality, Super Hot VR and any other 360* games, then the third sensor is something you wont regret buying. (Each sensor you purchase also comes with an extension cable that is about 4 meters in length).
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 27, 2017
review_title: I was almost unable to get the enjoyment I wanted out of games like Robo Recall and ...

one_reviews_text: As an 80's kid I grew up in the time of Nintendo NES, Sega Megadrives, Gameboys etc... It was great, and as a kid it all seemed kind of amazing... then it all became...well, a bit familiar and boring. Graphics have got better, games more complex but you never get that giddy wow feeling you did as a kid. Well Oculus Rift is like re-living that youth, it genuinely is the next big leap in gaming...and the first time you put it on I guarantee you'll be grinning from ear to ear.Although £399 seems expensive, it's an amazing bit of kit, and assuming you have the hardware already to run VR, it's a no brainer at this price. Everything is extremely well made, it looks and feels every bit of it's £400 asking price. Setup is relatively simple...it takes a while but you are walked through each step in the software.It is worth nothing my graphics card has one HDMI port and three DisplayPort's....this is quite a common setup and if you have your monitor plugged into the HDMI port, you need to move it. I purchased a 4K DisplayPort to HDMI adaptor... I tried it initially with the Rift but although recognised in the software, it displayed a blank screen. Easy fix, just swap your monitor/TV over to the DisplayPort and use the HDMI for the Rift.The bundle doesn't include the Xbox controller anymore, but to be honest, the Touch controllers are so superior you would never use it anyway. They feel very natural to use and don't really have any learning curve. Also the fact you can see and move your hands in VR is not only really cool, it means you can look and see where the buttons are. It also makes games very immersive and gives a surprising feeling of presence.The two cameras allow for room scale (virtually mapping out your play space so you can walk around it) and this works pretty well... it tracks perfectly with the exception of if you have your back to the cameras and your hands are out of view, it struggles.Games and experience are not cheap...although there are a good number of free options (Fantasynth a personal fave). I find I can only spend so long in VR, it's quite intense initially and expect some motion sickness. It also left me feeling very odd days after using it for the first week or two... hard to explain but just not quite "with it" and an almost floating feeling. Honestly Google it, I'm not alone, it seems a common thing for new users - just goes to show how powerful VR is.Only other thing to note is that once you've let your friends have a go...they'll never stop asking to play with it!
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on August 29, 2017
review_title: Probably the coolest thing you'll purchase for a while

one_reviews_text: Avete un pc che abbia le caratteristiche raccomandate per l'oculus? Avete 400 euro che volete spendere per videogiocare in un modo totalmente nuovo? Bene. Acquistate l'Oculus Rift.E la recensione potrebbe tranquillamente fermarsi qui, perchè finchè non lo proverete coi vostri occhi non potrete capire il livello di immersione, coinvolgimento e divertimento che questa periferica potrà regalarvi.Tutte le persone a cui l'ho fatto provare (me compreso) rimangono a bocca aperta la prima volta ed è davvero difficile cercare di spiegare a parole la sensazione che l'oculus genera.In questa recensione vorrei infatti semplicemente rispondere ad alcune domande che io mi sono fatto prima di acquistarlo e che magari ora vi state facendo anche voi:- il tracking com'è?Molto buono coi due sensori in bundle, perfetto con 3. Il terzo sensore potrete comprarlo direttamente sul sito dell'oculus a circa 69 euro.- e la risoluzione dell'immagine?2160X1200 pixel, che sono più di un monitor Full HD. I due schermi dell'Oculus sono molto vicini agli occhi e daranno un lieve effetto sgranato, ma nulla che possa compromettere l'esperienza.- giochi ce ne sono?Tantissimi. Moltissime esperienze brevi per testarlo e farlo testare ad amici e famiglia, e molti giochi completi. La maggior parte di questi ultimi nasce per essere usata esclusivamente con visori e garantiscono un'esperienza veramente diversa da qualsiasi altra cosa a cui eravate abituati.- è difficile da usare?No. Ha imparato ad usarlo mia nonna di 84 anni e si è divertita come una matta.- dopo un po' stufa?A un mese dall'acquisto lo uso ancora quotidianamente.- fa venire nausea/mal di testa/morte istantanea?Molto soggettivo. A me solo pochissimi titoli fanno venire un po' di nausea, ma normalmente lo uso anche per più di un'ora consecutiva senza alcun problema.- ma oltre a giocarci ci si può fare altro?Sì. Gli ambiti applicativi sono davvero tantissimi. Oltre a videogiocare potrete: usare maps VR per scoprire posti in 3d in giro per il mondo e visitarli, disegnare in 3d con alcune delle app di grafica, vedere qualsiasi film come se foste in un cinema (BigScreen), vedere film in 3d come se ci foste dentro, imparare qualcosa di nuovo tramite le numerose app di divulgazione scientifica e non (Body VR ad esempio), conoscere gente nuova attraverso le app social (e giocarci assieme) e potrei continuare.- quanto sono lunghi i vari cavi? Ho bisogno di extender/prolunghe?2.5 metri i cavi USB 3.0 dei sensori, 4.5 metri il cavo del visore.Io ho dovuto usare delle prolunghe per i sensori, ma tutto dipende da come li sistemate nella camera. Se vi dovessero servire comprate pure gli extender usb 3.0 di amazon basics che vanno benissimo e costano poco.- quanto spazio devo avere per potermi muovere e giocare decentemente?Io ho creato uno spazio di circa 3 metri x 2 metri ed è perfetto. Si riesce comunque a giocare anche con meno spazio, tipo 2 metri x 1.5 metri.- che scheda video devo avere? Processore?Io uso una RTX 2070 e viaggio senza problemi. L'ho comunque provato con una gtx 970 e tutti i giochi andavano comunque lisci come l'olio (abbassando ovviamente le impostazioni grafiche). Fate attenzione al processore, io ho un i5 6600k a 4.5 ghz e gira spesso tra l'80% e il 90% di utilizzo, credo che un i7 gestirebbe meglio la VR.In conclusione, come ho scritto all'inizio, è difficile spiegarvi PERCHE' dovreste comprarlo, ma fidatevi, se ne avete la possibilità è davvero un'esperienza unica nel suo genere, e questo è il primo passo per il futuro del videogioco.
review_date: Reviewed in Italy on December 3, 2018

one_reviews_text: I wasn't sure how much difference a 3d sensor would make but after giving a few games a try like In Death, Robo Recall and Superhot VR to name a few and I can honestly say it makes the vr experience so much better,  no more arrows saying face sensor no more lost tracking and you can turn round completely no tracking glitchs its great very pleased definitely recommend a must have for anyone who enjoys vr... .Setting up the sensor wasn't just plug and play you will need to run complete sensor setup and use the 16 foot 2.0 extension cable that comes free with this sensor!!I thought it would work better if I used all 3.0 cables but I kept getting a warning sign and an error message that says bad tracking fatal error and it will not allow you to finish the 360 setup, I tried many different USB 3.0 ports all came up with the same error even after a system reboot and driver updates, after few web searchsI found that 3rd sensor has to use a 2.0 connection, I quess that's why they provide you with a free 2.0 cable lol  :-)...
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 16, 2018
review_title: ... make but after giving a few games a try like In Death

one_reviews_text: While the Oculus Rift itself has been great with my brother very impressed with it compared to his PSVR this product relies on the software/games it provides and the service provided around that software. One of the very first game purchases I made through their website was mistakenly for the Oculus Go (which I don't have), I asked to be refunded. I promptly received a reply back saying that they would make an exception just this once and they gave me a refund. I thought that strange that they felt they needed to make an "exception".Busy at work on Black Friday an email comes in from them with their deals. I take a quick look not wanting to miss out, click on a link, scroll down reading the game descriptions and buy a couple of package deals. Wanting to get the download going so they would be ready when I finished work, I went to the app to find they weren't there. Yes again, I bought for the Oculus Go by mistake.I immediately emailed Oculus to ask for a refund which they declined as they had already given me a one off "exception" despite me not even being able to download or run the games.With a product that is so focused around the software it runs and the service it provides in delivering that software I feel that Oculus has fallen short in their policy.While I can recommend the physical product itself, as an entire package defined by including the service of delivering the software, I cannot recommend the Oculus eco system.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 26, 2018

one_reviews_text: Top quality VR for a good price. Complete with Touch controllers and two sensors. These controllers are very good ergonomically. The sensors are quite versatile in their setup and can cope with awkward shaped rooms (it takes practice). There's even an "experimental" setup to get 360 degree tracking using just the two sensors (which works). There are good built-in headphones and mic so no need to wear another headset on top (they are detachable if you want though). Pixel density is only behind that of the HTC Vive "pro" version which is about three times the price and has its own cons like weight.The nature of VR at the moment is that your eyes are near to the screen and you will notice pixels if you look hard enough. Just like games played on a monitor, some look a lot better than others and bad anti-aliasing is very noticeable. Some games more than others induce motion sickness, especially if walking using smooth locomotion. There is also a cable to trip over, and you are wearing a mask at the end of the day. I found wearing glasses uncomfortable and ended up getting a Widmovr prescription lens adapter (you can get them with blue light protection). Oculus says frames up to 142mm are ok but I got fed up of using a plaster to relieve  bridge pain :D You only really need glasses if you're short-sighted and objects are too blurry about 2 m away. Remember to blink now and then to lubricate those eyes!What's it like? Well take Steam VR for instance. Instead of looking at a flat dashboard you're in a room that you can furnish and entertain in, etc etc. As far as VR goes, believe the hype. Look behind you using a monitor and you see your wallpaper; look behind in VR and you see another world. In fact you don't just see another world, you're in one. And it's full-sized.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on September 20, 2018

one_reviews_text: Product recieved and I would love to give this a 5 star review yet I can't as the product just doesn't work. Was working perfectly the first day I recieved the product, set it up and bam in vr. Next thing I knew I was going to be late for work so I unplugged the headset after closing down robo recall and turned off my pc. Next day, wen't to use the headset, hmm whats this, an orange led instead of white. Must just need to open up the oculus app. Nope still orange, hmm let's just google it. First support page, says to make sure connections are fully connected both in the pc and in the HMD done that, still orange, okay next forum, restart your pc, obvious sollution that I missed, still orange, okay next, reinstall oculus app, did that, still orange. Next tip, downgrade graphics driver to a more stable version e.g 388.31 as suggested by many others. Still orange. What next, change hdmi ports and usb 3.0 ports. did that, still nothing, other than when connecting the hdmi to hdmi, it then says, hdmi cable not connected and led still orange. OKay really frustrated now. Contacted support. Obviously not going to hear back from them for a while. Next step, reset pc to defaults and remove everything for a fresh install. Still orange, great waste of time. Next step. Take out all redundant usb devices e.i webcam, headset etc. Still orange. Okay, now im really trying to not throw it at a wall here. Whats next. Nothing, literally nothing other than try using it on someone elses pc. Yes great now that means if it works it's my pc, yet it's not, as it was literally working 12 hours before. Oculus I'm very dissapointed in this product and the fact I paid over 300 pounds for something that worked for 1 hour and gave me nothing but 7 + hours of stress and mysery.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 8, 2019
review_title: Don't buy if your ready to spend over 7 hours figuring out why it's not working.

one_reviews_text: It's great fun experiencing Virtual Reality with an Oculus Rift, but it's more of a 3 days wonder. Then it gets boring. At least it did for me. The reason being that VR is still not there yet. Gamers are having the most fun when playing with their friends. For what they are, these plasticky VR kits are way too overpriced and only accessible to few. If VR is to take off and catch speed, it has to become more affordable. The more people get to experience VR, the faster it'll grow and improve.What you'll first notice when using an Oculus Rift are the annoyingly pixelated graphics. Transitioning from the crisp video quality of your 1440p gaming monitor to Oculus, can be quite upsetting at first, but your brain will get over it and choose to ignore this aspect eventually. I get that this is due to the lens magnifying effect, but it's 2019. It's time to step up your game, Oculus.The second aspect I want to discuss about is that, while objects that appear in the center are pretty well focused, everything becomes blurry towards the edge of the lenses. Then again, you get used to this too, eventually.I like the controllers, though. They're very responsive and ergonomically designed. A nice addition for the future would be GLOVES, instead of controllers. Gloves that will have individual sensors for each finger and also for the palms, so that we can control everything through hand gestures and not buttons on a controller.I also noticed that the video feed stutters hard when I turn my back to the sensor readers, which would normally sit in front of me.For the entertainment and the fun of it, I was willing to overlook the inconveniences and enjoy the experience. There are plenty of apps and games to choose from in the Oculus store or the Steam store, many of them free. However, for the premium VR feeling, you're going to have to dig into your pocket. And it doesn't come cheap.It is, overall, an unique experience, but it feels outdated and can't keep up with the current level of entertainment that PC and Console gaming has to offer. VR feels like the slow kid who's always trying to catch-up with the cool kids, but can't.It's time for improvements to be implemented and it's time for a serious price drop. Else, suffer the same fate of 3D TV's!
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 20, 2019
review_title: Unique experience, but feels outdated and overpriced.

one_reviews_text: If you are thinking about getting a VR headset, here is my view and some things to consider.If you have tried Google Cardboard or any of the other mobile phone headsets out there and not been impressed, You won't be.They are a not a true representation of "Proper" VR.  These types of devices track your head rotation only, there is no "translation" awareness, so you cannot move around (Forward, Backwards, Left, Right, Up or Down), you are fixed in position. You are free to "look around" only."Proper VR" has the ability to let you move around freely within your enthronement in all 6 degrees of movement, the extra ingredient that brings VR to life if the inclusion of your hands in the environment. THis give you the ability to interact naturally with object withing the environment. something a phone device has absolutely no way to provide.Personally I have an Oculus Rift, it has an isolated (zero-crosstalk) stereoscopic display which uses image distortion and fish-eye lenses to achieve an wide field of view. This is a big deal, it adds tremendously to the sense of immersion. You really feel like you are "inside" the virtual space, and have an accurate sense of where objects are in relation to you, depth wise. The hand trackers are so perfectly positioned, you do not, (And cannot), see them in the real world when wearing the HMD, but just moving your hand naturally to the position you see in the virtual world, you will be able to pick them up!  That in itself is impressive.The PC needed to power this headset also needs to be fairly substantial and requires a dedicated 3D graphics card, but then any PC game these days worth its salt requires that. the more powerful the better the experience though.  I think the minimum specification GPU is an Nvidia 960, but this will not run the most demanding games at their best graphic ability. I'd recommend a minimum an Nvidia 1080ti for the GPU.The "Elephant in the room" : Some experiences WILL make you feel sick. Its something they are working on. Some games have solved it, some haven’t.It all depends on weather the game or experience you are using has was is known a "free locomotion" or not. long with the frame-rate the graphics are delivered.Free locomotion allows you to "glide" around your environment smoothly just by pushing the hand controller joystick in the direction you wish.This sounds great, but in VR it is very confusing for you brain/vestibular system to correlate their differing inputs and as a result motion sickness can be felt.It does need to be said that this is a "beginner" symptom, and with regular "training" you will overcome this feeling and gain you "VR legs" so to speak!It's not a question of “Does a VR headset actually feel realistic?”.  The only question is if you are ready for such a jump in technology.This is NOT Nintendo Wii 3.0 or XBox X-5 or PS 5! This is NOT an updated console system or fun little gadget. This is something different.Something you have never experienced before. It's another dimension. The future of gaming and home entertainment.For me, its the most amazing thing I’ve ever had the pleasure of being a part of, and cant wait to see where this will go.When I first got it, the only way I could explain it to people was that its just blows your mind and is an absolute game changer in every way.No amount of watching YouTube videos of people using a Rift, or me saying "it is good", can't relay the feeling of of actually wearing and being in the headset.I read recently that 2/3 of the population still don’t know that VR even exists or think its just a gimmick and are reluctant to take that step into VR.To that I say, after Mark Zuckerburg was shown the Oculus Rift, he immediately offered $4,000,000,000, (Yes 4 Billion dollars!), to buy the company.Now that is a response!!Regarding the price of getting started with VR, people often say it is "too expensive". Depending on your needs, VR is not “too expensive”.If you have a relatively recent generation smartphone (last ~3 years or so), you can buy a Google Cardboard (or similar) adapter for as little as £1For a step up, you can get something like a Google Daydream or Samsung Gear VR. They both still need a smartphone, but they are both under £100.You can get an entry level all-in-one system like an Oculus Go for £200. Still not terribly expensive.Now all three of these systems are entry level, and as with all things in life you largely "get what you pay for."For someone that has never experienced VR, all three can deliver something exciting, but it is not "true", full immersion VR.Over the £200 price point, things get a little more interesting...You have Playstation VR for about £350, or less if you already have a PS4.After that, you get into things like the HTC Vive, Oculus Rift and Windows Mixed Reality. Those range from £200 to ~£600, but you need a pretty beefy PC to run them. The total cost is £1200 – £1800, which is starting to be expensive, granted, but not ridiculous. If you have a PC that can be upgraded (you can often just upgrade the graphics card) you’re looking at £500-£800 all in.For this amount of money, you get a top notch immersive VR system that can cover an area as large as 15′ x 15′ (4.5m x 4.5m), which is pretty big.You’ll be free to walk around that entire space within a virtual environment.VR can provide some escapism, exposure to new things, engagement, excitement along with everything else you can get from other media, books to a movie or video game. In my opinion, and according to the growing body of academic research, VR is more immersive than other media. In other words, you can, and will, get more engrossed in what you are doing when in VR.Estimates show about 6 million units have been shipped of higher end systems (PSVR, Vive, Rift, Windows Mixed Reality).At the other end of the spectrum, Google cardboard alone was over 10 million units!That’s comparable to a gaming console like Sega’s Dreamcast, and ahead of Nintendo’s Wii U. And we’re only a couple of years in to VR.Uses for VR at home span the range from educational/practical to pure fun, but many of those uses combine a little of both.On the practical side, there are a variety of things you can do in VR at home:Visit real places around the globe — see VR Travel: 10 Ways To See the World From Your Living RoomVisit real places on other planets — see Mars: Curiosity RoverImmerse yourself in a concert LIVE with NextVRHelp house-bound seniors deal with depression and isolation with Virtual Reality for SeniorsVisit museums with Amazing virtual museum toursExplore a new kitchen with Virtual Reality from IKEAWatch news feeds from around the globe with 360 video.On the fun games and experiences front, whilst there certainly is plenty of "shovelware" on Steam (and to a lesser extent Oculus Home), there are plenty of great experiences to be had from both stores.My personal favourite VR games/experiences which have given me many hundreds of hours of fun include:-Skyrim VR, Lone Echo, Arizona Sunshine, Assetto Corsa, Battlezone, Brass Tactics, DCS World, Dead and Buried, Echo Arena, Elite Dangerous, Lucky's Tale,Minecraft, Onward, Project Cars II, Robo Recall, Superhot VR, Willson's Heart, Google Earth VR, Farlands, Sparc.I could go on, but think I'm doing that already :-)I would argue that no gaming system in history has ever had a line-up so involving, exciting and physically jaw dropping at times, and the best is still yet to come :)I have played many games in VR but I have been extremely impressed by the conversion of the Skyrim from Bethesda to VR.Even though these are not perfect conversions, as they were not "built for VR" in the first instance, and you will run into bugs or oddities, they nevertheless convey a world you can get completely lost in. I regularly spend 8 or more hours per session, but it feels fleeting!You have a huge world around you that when you play in flat-screen is nice but its like watching a movie, now replaying it in VR it feels strange, almost like a religious experience at times. You stand on the top of a mountain and look out over the land and all its majesty, but its all just code, realistic looking code, you are left with a feeling like you are in the matrix.I am still awed and find myself sat with my mouth open, by the vistas presented in Skyrim (Modded to hilt of course).I am that Barbarian with a hunting bow in hand, crossing Tamriel in search of adventure ;-)All in all, it is the biggest leap forward in home entertainment since the Atari 2600!If you can, buy one, I whole heartedly recommend it, I guarantee you will not be disappointed.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 21, 2019
review_title: The best piece of Tech I have ever bought

one_reviews_text: I bought a GearVR for my phone and tried the games a few times and wasn't really that overwhelmed, yeah it was new but kind of wore off and got bored with it and left it alone but new that it had potential as I've always been into the idea of gaming in virtual reality but it didn't really immerse me the way I wanted it to.I thought I'd give the Oculus Rift a go as I had read many reviews and watched many YouTube videos of people playing it and seeing their reactions to it and gave it a gamble to see if I thought the same and yes a very expensive gamble to make but I'm glad I did.After setting it up which wasn't as simple as I had hoped with the setting up of the sensors giving me the most problem like it talking me I wasn't in the centre or I was too close over and over again I finally got it set up and then a demo started with a flying robot telling giving me floppy disks and to insert them into a disk drive and there I had my first wow moment.As with any hardware it depends on the kind of software you use to get the most out of it so with the Oculus Rift it depends on the games you play, I've tried many and a few seemed like tech demos to see what you could do in VR and then there are games like Lone Echo, Dirt Rally and Skyrim VR which really show that having the right games will really give you your moneys worth as these games were fun to play and gave me the experiences I was looking for and really immersed me into virtual reality.You do need a bit of space though as games I tried like Superhot do intend you to walk around a bit and without enough space you'll find yourself hitting furnature like I did with a chest of drawers but other games you can Judt stand there and have enough room to wave your arms around.One thing I did really like was the guardian system that enables you to walk around your room pressing down the controller button so you can map out how big your room is so if you go past it a kind of cage pops up to warn you if you're close to your boundary which I didn't do before I played Superhot so make sure you do all the set up procedure before starting the Rift as accidents can happen.Now having my Rift I can't understand why more people aren't gaming this way and that more developers aren't making games for it as for me this is the way forward and really hope that more games are to come which will take me away to another dimension to game like I never have before.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 15, 2019

one_reviews_text: 5 stars from me.Its abit hard to give stars though in its context as its a new experience.My advice is grab one and enter the rift (referencing the tutorial there)Set ups easy just make sure your pc is powerful enough, i have a 1070 and its fine.The resolution might concern you abit but dont worry too much.My 2 games i would advise to start out would be robo recall (should be free with bundle) and Vanishing Relms, its £15 and abit short but get it as a treat if you love rpg's

I've used the rift for about 40 hours total in that time and when not in use it is stored tidily.With even this limited use and being well looked after the headset cable has managed to kink at the point it leaves the headset via a small hard plastic clip. Not so bad i thought, i will order a new cable... how much could it be... £50 pounds it could be. Not ordering a new cable at that price and i would highly recommend not buying this product until they either fix the design flaw, package it with better cables or sell replacement cables at a more sane price.

This is a sensor and does it's just! If you want full room tracking then buy it while you can as Oculus are phasing out the original Rift products.

The fact that you are actually swinging the sword and aiming the fireballs adds a whole new dimension.This isn't the complete VR experience yet (we need tactile bodysuits still) but for the price it is the best you'll get right now.

After Oculus wasting my time they informed me I would have to collect an invoice from the 3rd party seller on Amazon - Electronic zone Wholesale Ltd - it would be fair to say they f*****d me, completely ignored all emails, ignored emails from Amazon directly and never provided any invoice or receipt, a task which would take little effort and time.Amazon, Oculus and Electronic zone Wholesale Ltd have not shown a single ounce of courtesy or respect, I will not be doing business with Oculus or Electronic zone Wholesale Ltd again and I will not be relying on Amazon for customer service in future. Disappointed, Vive all the way!
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 1, 2020
review_title: Worst customer service I have ever experienced.

one_reviews_text: Bonjours, ça va faire une semaine que je suis en galère à cause de la gâchette de mon Touch droit qui reste bloqué assez souvent ce qui est extrêmement gênant pour tous les types de logiciels/jeux. (Mais bon, première ça arrive...)Je fais donc un retour chez Amazon, que le site me confirme.Deux minute plus tard je reçois un coup de fil pour Amazon qui me dit de contacter par mail Oculus. (C'est pourtant Amazon qui m'a vendu la chose non?)Je contact donc via le mail donné le support Oculus, pas de réponse, je décide donc d'aller sur le site.Sur leur site, ils me demandent de leur envoyer une vidéo du problème... Bon, ok, je tourne le tout sur mon portable et j'envoi le tout sur leur support... Mais le fichier est trop volumineux... Une vidéo d'à peine une minute.Je leur demande donc qu'on se balance ça via mail. (Et en plus il faut penser à partager avec l'interlocuteur la vidéo via W10 et Google Mail...)Pour eux ils ne voient pas le problème, obligé de leur rebalancer deux vidéo hier, j’attends toujours une réponse de la part d'Oculus.Ça fait une semaine que je galère pour me faire remplacer un produit défectueux entre deux boîtes qui se renvoient la patate chaude, ça commence à bien faire, j'en ai ma claque!REMPLACEZ-MOI CE TOUCH QU'ON EN PARLE PLUS!Il m'aura fallu une semaine pour pouvoir me le remplacer, enfin.Sinon emballage nickel reçu dans les temps annoncés, pour une première expérience, sans tenir compte du SAV c'était franchement génial, le design des Touch sont vraiment bine fait (Par contre faites un effort pour la qualité par pitié.), et malgré la pixellisation on est tellement dedans qu'on parviens presque à oublier ce qu'il y a autour de nous.La boîte est toute belle, le poids de la bête est très correct.La bonne idée qui dois rester sur des casques VR, c'est le système de branchement des écouteur, qu'on peux enlever avec un tour de vis, ça, c'était bien vu, par contre pas de micro, donc de facto le casque est totalement inutile (Pour moi.), même si pas mauvais du tout.Qualité où défaut à vous de voir, ayant une petite tête, il me suffit de regarder en bas pour voir en dehors du casque, ce que je trouve assez pratique.Défaut pour moi, j'ai découvert cette merveille en août et outre le fait de transpirer dedans, les lentilles ont tendance à s'embuer assez rapidement surtout sur Robo Recall (Bon défouloir au passage.^^).Dommage par contre qu'on ne puisse pas se balader dans les environnements d’accueil du rift, mais le Steam VR le fait bien.Conclusion: La VR DOIT se démocratiser, c'est vraiment un support génial, les défaut de conception du début finiront par être gommés, par contre améliorez votre organisation de vos SAV Amazon et Oculus, ça vous fera pas de mal.Allez je rajoute deux autres étoiles pour soutenir le support.
review_date: Reviewed in France on August 17, 2018
review_title: Autant de galère pour un Oculus Touch... Sérieux?!

one_reviews_text: Using this with my Oculus Rift Touch, it came with 2 tracking sensors, but I found that to get perfect 360-degree racking, a third sensor places behind me allowed for much better tracking. You also have to be careful what type of USB extension you are using and the ports you are plugging into, but once it is all set up it provides a great VR experience.

one_reviews_text: I got exactly what I expected, one of the best high end virtual reality headsets currently on the market with by far the best controllers currently available. This bundle contains everything needed to play almost any virtual reality games and although the tracking may cut out at very specific areas because there are only two sensors included in the package, I think it is one of if not the best VR packages out there. The set up part is very easy to do and rarely needs to be re-calibrated.Things of note:beware, you will need to buy a fair amount of games because most of the current games are pretty short, I would recommend buying the VR essentials bundle from steam and Elite Dangerous if you have a joystick available.Another thing to note is that you will need a good computer for this to work without getting VR-sickness after longer play sessions, I can play for hours on end with my high end computer but with lower frame rates this gets harder to do as I noticed when I brought this over to one of my friends and everyone there got a little sick with only about 30 minutes of playing.Yet another thing to note is that the cables on the headset are VERY short and if you intend on having your computer stationary as you play you will pretty much have to buy an extension cable for the HDMI and USB cable don't skimp on these cables either as that might have an influence on your experience.

one_reviews_text: Me había tardado en comprarlo gracias al precio, que usaba un control de Xbox, no tenia una PC que lo corriera con facilidad, etc. Ahora que bajó de precio, hay mejor disponibilidad en México, sustituyeron el control de Xbox con los “Touch Controllers” e incluyen muchos juegos, sentí que subió la relación precio/beneficio y decidí comprarlo. Estoy más que impresionado.Lo bueno:- El efecto “screen door” si es aparente, pero solamente cuando se están cargando los juegos y no estas jugando, después ni te das cuenta de que existe.- Funciona muy bien con 2 sensores y perfecto con 3, especialmente en cuartos grandes.- Los “Touch Controllers” son fenomenales, son los mejores controles que he usado en mi vida.- El nivel de inmersión de mover la mano y agarrar una pistola, dar la vuelta, apuntar hacia un robot y dispararle es algo fuera de lo real.- El visor es de muy alta calidad y muy ligero, todo se ve increíble. 360 grados en 3D, es el futuro.Lo malo:- Está conectado por cable, esto reduce un poco la inmersión.- Se calienta un poco y puedes sudar un poco, el material del visor se puede humedecer y no es muy cómodo.- Al ser tecnología de primera generación no hay tantos juegos que aprovechen bien el estar en VR. Cada vez hay más.Todo se resume en la primera vez que lancé mi mano a mis hombros buscando una escopeta para matar al robot que se aceraba a mi mientras jugaba Robo Recall. Solté un grito de emoción y no conozco a nadie que al hacer lo mismo no quede totalmente impresionado. Cómpralo, úsalo y nunca mires atrás!
review_date: Reviewed in Mexico on September 6, 2018
review_title: El futuro de los juegos es hoy!

one_reviews_text: Ciao a tutti, dopo circa un mese di utilizzo di Oculus Rift mi sento obbligato a dover lasciare una mia recensione e una mia opinione generale sul prodotto. Saltando la parte dell'imballaggio ottimo come al solito, partiamo direttamente dal visore in sé.Oculus Rift permette all'utente di entrare in un mondo virtuale e di provare emozioni veramente grandi. Il visore è veramente ben costruito, unica nota particolare sulla costruzione di esso è il posizionamento in testa. È molto leggero ed ergonomico (quasi non si sente), ma per vedere al meglio e senza sfocature bisogna fare un buon settaggio delle regolazioni. Mi riferisco a tutti quelli che si sono lamentati dicendo di vedere sfocato eccetera, è tutta una questione di regolazione del visore. Assicuratevi di allargare tutti gli strappi prima di indossarlo, solo dopo averlo fatto indossatelo e muovetelo su e giù, destra e sinistra davanti agli occhi finché non avrete la migliore visione possibile, chiudere poi gli strappi. Tracking perfetto, performance molto buone anche su PC discreti (1050ti). Consigliato per vrchat.Reputo questo visore attualmente il migliore avendo anche provato htc vive e Windows mixed reality. giá solo per il fatto che Oculus ti permette di muovere le dita per dare comandi (e il suo prezzo onestissimo) fa capire chi comanderà il mercato VR nei prossimi anni.
review_date: Reviewed in Italy on December 19, 2018

one_reviews_text: Anfangs war ich skeptisch mir überhaupt schon VR zuzulegen. Ich wurde jedoch eines besseren belehrt. Mit VR eröffnet sich eine vollständig neue Spielweise. Sehr unterhaltsam allerdings ein Zeitkiller 😅Die Auflösung lässt in dieser Generation zwar Wünsche offen aber nach einiger Zeit fällt das kaum noch auf. Sobald Prozessoren und Grafikkarten nachziehen denke ich, dass kommende Generationen von VR Systemen durch die höhere Detailtiefe nur gewinnen werden. Zur Zeit spiele ich mit meiner GTX 1060 3GB und meinem i7 7700, dem 16 GB Arbeitsspeicher zu Seite stehen Elite Dangerous in Ultra Settings und kann mich nicht beklagen.Das Tracking funktioniert auch mit zwei Sensoren in 360° Setup ziemlich gut, allerdings sollte man bedenken genügend Kabel bzw aktive Hubs zu besorgen wenn man eine genügend große Spielzone aufbauen will. Unter Umständen ist hier ein dritter Sensor sehr sinnvoll. Falls ihr sowohl im Sitzen als auch im Stehen in die VR wollt, müsst ihr entweder probieren wo ihr die beiden Sensoren am Besten positioniert oder euch einen Dritten zulegen. Entsprechende Tutorials gibt's im Internet bzw. bei YouTube zu Hauf.Man sollte unbedingt darauf achten ausreichend viele USB 3.0 Steckplätze (root hubs) an seinem Rechner verfügbar zu haben (einen je Sensor und einen weiteren für die Oculus selbst). Eine Erweiterungskarte für PCI Express ist hier, je nach Mainboard-Ausstattung, zu empfehlen.Wandhalterungen für die Sensoren empfehle ich sehr.Falls eure Spielzone entsprechend groß ist, solltet ihr auch in Verlängerungen für das Kabel der Oculus investieren (USB und HDMI). Achtet hier auf gute Qualität, gerade bei HDMI Verlängerungen geht viel Datenrate aufgrund von schlechten Rohstoffen des Kabels verloren. Sucht nach Testberichten von vertrauenswürdigen Quellen. Manches ist einfach schlichtweg Wucher.Ansonsten bietet das bundle interessante Spiele damit ihr einmal testen könnt, wie euch VR gefällt. Ich bin jedenfalls begeistert.Eins noch: Wenn ihr verhindern wollt, dass eure Kabel euch im Weg sind, besorgt euch eine Kabelführung zur Deckenmontage.Kabelmanagement: https://www.amazon.de/dp/B06XFMY8G9/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apa_9NFwBbA565BE4Wandhalterungen: https://www.amazon.de/dp/B0782RYF81/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apa_QPFwBbE7DABE4
review_date: Reviewed in Germany on July 26, 2018

one_reviews_text: Son básicamente increíbles, la manera en que te sumerge en los mundos virtuales es inmejorable, el sonido básicamente es perfecto. Al principio creía que no daría buena calidad de sonido, pero me equivoque. Los Touch están ergonómicamente pensados para cualquier mano, y los botones están bien distribuidos. La única pega que se le puede poner sin dos cosas, la resolución, y la interfaz que tiene el visor, que es de esponja, pero eso recurriendo a las vrcover se soluciona. Y la resolución, es que, al utilizarlo en juegos preparados para monitor, hay letras que sin difíciles de leer. Y en otros casos, es óptima. En fin, un producto con un buen acabado, para disfrutar entre toda la familia

one_reviews_text: Das beste Spielzeug, das ich je hatte! Gott sei dank bin ich offenbar nicht mit der berüchtigten VR-Reisekrankheit geschlagen, am ersten Tag war mir nach schnellen Bewegungen kurz etwas schwindelig, aber schon am zweiten Tag fühlte ich mich in der virtuellen Welt sehr zu Hause. Ich muss dennoch etwa alle Stunde eine Pause einlegen, erstens weil die Brille bei Schweißausbruch zum Beschlagen neigt, vor allem aber ist das Spielgefühl sehr immersiv. Alles fühlt sich so echt an, dass ich einfach eine Pause brauche!Natürlich könnte die Auflösung noch besser sein (und das Headset noch leichter und billiger und und und...), aber zusammenfassend kann ich sagen, dass ich kein 2D-Computerspiel mehr angerührt habe, seit ich die Oculus Rift mein Eigen nenne. Für alle Simulations- und Ego-Shooter-Spieler, die das Geld und vier Quadratmeter Platz haben und die sich immer schon gewünscht haben "mitten drin, statt nur dabei" zu sein, muss ich die Kaufempfehlung dringend aussprechen. Der einzige Nachteil ist die immer noch recht übersichtliche Auswahl an Spielen, aber ich habe für mich drei - vier Titel gefunden, welche meine Zocker-Träume haben wahr werden lassen.Vorteile:1. Immersives Spielen wie noch nie. Der gefühlte Unterschied zum Spielen ohne VR-Headset ist kaum in Worte zu fassen.2. Flüssiges Tracking, ausgereifte Technik sorgt für intuitives Raumgefühl, 3D-Sehen "wie in echt".Nachteile:1. Nicht ganz billig2. Man benötigt etwas Raum3. Der Aufbau der Sensoren kann sich kompliziert gestalten, bis das System mal zu Frieden ist.4. Für manche Menschen auf Grund von Reisekrankheit ("VR-Sickness") wohl ungeeignet.
review_date: Reviewed in Germany on October 27, 2018
review_title: Das schönste Spielzeug, das ich je hatte!

one_reviews_text: Also Preis ist war ordendlich aber immer noch billiger als die HTC vive. Die auflösung ist auch um einiges besser deswegen haben ich mit auch mich für die rift entschieden.Positives: - Das ingame gefühl ist wirklich cool und macht auch extrem spass  - Die touch Controller funktionieren gut und gibt noch das gewisse etwasNegatives: ( Zu beachten ist das das Positive viel stärker ist )  - Nach einer gewissen zeit wird mir übel ( ist bei jeden anders und man gewöhnt sich langsam daran )  - was schlechter entgegensatz zur vive ist die Verbindung vom sensor zum Controller( hinter dem körper verliert er die verbindung.Fazit : wer keine achtenbahnen ( reallive) verträgt sollte sich das gelt sparen ) und wer genug geld hat kann sich das auf jedenfall leisten, bin immer noch zurfieden nach 8 Monate gebrauch und würde es für etwas geld weiterempfehlen

one_reviews_text: La primera vez es brutal la experiencia e inmersion, no lo boy a negar,cada juego que vas probando te sorprende mas y mas,pero eso se termina a los dias de uso,despues de probar los juegos gratuitos no te quedara de otra que comprar los juegos mas populares de oculus,y creeme no son nada baratos entre 20 y 40 dolares,tu decides.Despues de una semana de uso te acostumbras a la experiencia,y llegas al punto de aburrirte con ellas,ya que la jugabilidad en cada juego casi siempre es la misma,el visor suele calentarse muy poco,pero es suficiente para hacerte sudar tras unos minutos de juego,tendras que limpiar las esponjas y lentes cada vez que los utilizes de nuevo y es algo tedioso,los controles tienen un fallo muy conocido entre la comunidad VR,y es que el gatillo pierde suavidad despues de los dias de uso,y se escucha un click algo molesto al presionar,recuerda que son controles de 200 dolares y eso no tendria que pasar,tu decides.Por la inmersion que ofrece vale la pena,sin embargo ten en cuenta todo lo anterior ya que te vas a topar con ello,tu decides

one_reviews_text: Heut kam sie an, die Oculus Rift. Nach einen 4,4 GB Download der Software ging es los mit dem Einrichten der "Anlage". Dies gestaltete sich einfacher als befürchtet.  Man wird Schritt für Schritt durch das Setup geführt ohne das ich mich überfordert fühlte als VR Neuling. Vor allem ging es ziemlich fix. Danach startete die erste VR Erfahrung mit dem Titel "First Contact". Tja was soll ich sagen... sehr beeindruckend.  Will da nicht zu viel verraten. Ab der ersten Sekunde war ich überzeugt von der Technik. Die Bedienung empfinde ich als leicht zu lernen und intuitiv.  Habe jetzt ca 1 1/2 Stunden mal alles probiert (die kostenlosen Spiele downloaden leider noch) und mir ist ein bisschen schlecht. Puh... Das wäre auch der einzige negative Punkt bis jetzt.  Ok... und ich hab ne bessere Grafikkarte gekauft.  Mal schauen ob es einen merklichen Unterschied gibt. Hatte bis jetzt eine GeForce GTX 780 ti mit 3GB und ersetze diese durch eine 1060 mit 6GB. Ich berichte dann mal die nächsten Tage.Update: Also die neue Graka hat jetzt nicht wirklich spürbar etwas verbessert.Positiv ist allerdings nach mehrmaligem Nutzen der Rift das Schwindelgefühl/leichte Übelkeit verschwindet. Ich kann locker mal 2 Stunden zocken ohne "Nebenwirkungen".
review_date: Reviewed in Germany on November 8, 2018

one_reviews_text: Lo consiglio vivamente a chiunque sia appassionato di videogiochi, e che vuole giocare a qualcosa di nuovo ed esclusivo.Il rapporto qualità prezzo, l'oculus rift è decisamente imbattibile rispetto agli altri. La prima esperienza è stata fantastica, la prima sessione di gioco era assolutamente entusiasmante; poi però come qualsiasi altra cosa diventa sempre meno entusiasmante, è naturale. Io personalmente l'ho amato e lo consiglio. Vi farete una sessione di gioco da un paio di ore ogni 3 o 4 giorni, ne vale la pena!Ovviamente ci sono anche i contro, le lenti si appannano molto spesso, soprattutto quando si fanno giochi in cui bisogna essere veloci. La visione a zanzariera di cui tutti parlano è quasi impercettibile, bisogna davvero farci caso di proposito per notarla. Una cosa importantissima che dovete sapere è EVITATE I giochi in cui si cammina o in cui si è trasportati da una macchina o un apparecchio come le montagne russe, a me personalmente ha causato una forte nausea in meno di 10 minuti di gioco, e mi sono dovuto sdraiare al letto per un paio di ore. Ho il motion sickness con  tutti i giochi in cui la telecamera non è spostata dal mio corpo ma da un comando del joypad, per fortuna la maggior parte dei giochi li fanno con spostamento a teletrasporto, altrimenti non sarei riuscito ad usare il VR.A parte questo, ci sono molti giochi gratuiti, tra cui Robo Recall che è bellissimo, e altri che ne vale la pena giocare.Io sono rimasto soddisfatto!
review_date: Reviewed in Italy on December 4, 2018
review_title: Impressionante: recensione dopo circa 20 ore di utilizzo

one_reviews_text: Nachdem das selbsterklärende Setup der Sensoren abgeschlossen ist, kann es auch schon mit der ersten Einführung los gehen. Wow! Einfach atemberaubend! Die Nutzung der Touchcontroller geht sehr leicht von der Hand, nachdem man die Gesten erst einmal verinnerlicht hat.Auch das Spiel RoboRecall macht sehr viel spaß, bevor es anfängt monoton zu werden.Nun zu anderen Spielen.Für mich war Elite Dangerous (ein Game, das von Grund auf mit für VR entwickelt wurde) der Haupt Kaufgrund der Rift.Auch hier war das Spielgefühl erst absolut überwältigend! Insbesondere mit einem HOTAS-System hat man eine nie dagewesene Immersion im Spiel. Man fühlt sich, als sitze man tatsächlich im Raumschiff. Einen guten Beitrag leisten auch die Lautsprecher der Rift, die trotz ihrer geringen Größe einen außerordentlich guten Sound abliefern.Schnell stellt man allerdings auch fest, wo die Probleme der Rift (bzw. aller aktuellen VR-Headsets) liegen. Die Auflösung ist einfach noch nicht hoch genug!Feinere Texte sind unscharf, bzw. muss man mit dem Kopf "näher ran", damit die Texte größere und entsprechend besser lesbar werden.In einem Spiel wie Elite Dangerous ist zudem der Kontrast ein riesen Problem. Es gibt viele helle Elemente auf dunkeln Hintergründen. Da zwischen Bildschirm und Auge eine Fresnel-Linse liegt, treten hier starke Reflexionen auf (lt. Tests soll dieses Problem bei der HTC Vive geringer auftreten, dafür ist die Schärfe dort ein noch deutlicheres Problem).In dem angesprochenen RoboRecall gibt es eine durchweg homogenere Helligkeit, daher fallen die Reflektionen hier kaum auf.Meine Bedenken bezüglich der Leistungsfähigkeit meines PCs (Intel Xeon 1230v3, 16 GB DDR3, GTX 970) lösten sich schnell in Rauch auf. Alles, was ich angespielt habe, lief butterweich. Zwar teils nur in geringen bis mittleren Grafikeinstellungen, das ist aber fast schon nebensächlich, da man in der VR weniger darauf achtet bzw. z.B. schlechter auflösende Texturen durch den Fliegengittereffekt einfach nicht so stark ins Gewicht fallen.Als Brillenträger ist die Rift ungeeignet! Die Brille passt zwar unter die Rift, allerdings drückt sie unangenehm auf den Nasenrücken und die Rift sitzt nicht mehr so gut und wackelt bei Kopfbewegungen stärker.Ich habe daher immer Kontaktlinsen genutzt.Persönlich habe ich aufgrund der besagten Reflektionen in Verbindung mit schlecht lesbaren Texten die Rift wieder abgegeben.Ich bin allerdings auf die nächsten Generationen und Weiterentwicklungen gespannt.
review_date: Reviewed in Germany on January 14, 2019
review_title: Immersion Gigantisch, aber Technisch noch nicht ausgereift.

one_reviews_text: Avendo acquistato il suo rivale  HTC VIVE. che dopo 2 mesi incominciava a darmi problemi .. fino a chiedere il reso x un bag sul display che non si riusciva a togliere .. oltre ad essere molto pesante e nonostante fosse collegato a un 1080ti -11gb v-ram la qualità erano veramente fastidiose.. poi tutto un botto ho comprato Oculus rift  molto + economico leggero affidabile le immagini sono+ chiare niente sfocature veramente perfeto  superiore al HTC VIVE in tutti i sensi.. per i giochi non abbiate timore  la compatibilità è garantita.  Un altra nota favorevole sono i controller alla quale potete inserire delle batterie e in se per se sono molto comodi e leggeri . Il secondo oculus rift è attualmente colegata su una macchina non molto prestante parliamo di un i5  a 3.9 con 16 gb di ram a 2.4 con una gpu 8gb rx devo dire che va benissimo nonostante il pc sia di fascia media .
review_date: Reviewed in Italy on February 4, 2019

one_reviews_text: Ich habe lange überlegt ob ich mir eine VR Brille kaufen soll, habe es in diesem Fall jedoch nicht bereut! Die Brille ist genial, lässt sich gut an den Kopf anpassen und ist auch nicht all zu schwer. Man sollte sich etwas spielen mit den Einstellungen des Headsets, je besser man die Brille auf die Augen einstellt desto besser das 3D Erlebnis. Die Gratis Spiele auf der Oculus Seite reichen für einige Stunden an Spielspaß!Einziges Manko für mich ist, dass die Kabel der Sensoren sowie der Brille etwas zu kurz sind, könnten ruhig noch nen guten Meter länger sein.

one_reviews_text: Inizialmente avevo dato 2 stelle perché mi ero basato sulla mia esperienza personale ma il prodotto merita cmq 4 stelle perche di per se è perfetto e non presenta difetti. E poi amazon ha una attenzione al cliente eccezionale! La confezione è stata ben imballata es il pakeging è ottimo. Ma ora parlo della mia esperienza che ripero è personale. Ho acquistato questo prodotto con tutta la buona volontà di tenerlo per un bel po prima di cambiarlo con la prossima generazione ma... niente da fare. fin da subito ho avuto difficoltà di posizionamento e di messa a fuoco ed ho notato i fastidiosissimi God Ray che danno un fastidio cane soprattutto nelle scene ad alto contrasto. scordatevi di usarlo in modalità desktop perché vi fondete le pupille cercando di leggere i testi che risultano sfocati per l'effetto zanzariera. Visione ottimale solo al centro e quando dico centro dico centro perfetto perché più sposti gli occhi per guardale ai lati più si intensificano le aberrazioni cromatiche che sono brutte da vedere ed alterano le immagini in modo non accettabile. Quindi sei costretto a mantenere lo sguardo al centro e spostarti con la testa per guardare qualunque cosa e la cosa può stancare. L'effetto wow c'è ma solo all'inizio e dipende molto dai titoli. Se quardi le cose "lontane" ovviamente appaiono sfocate e poco definite e questo è a stretto contatto con la risoluzione che non è abbastanza per rendere l'esperienza "vera" e ti sembra tutto sempre poco dettagliato e quindi la realtà ne risente...insomma per tutti questi motivi ritengo che cadano bene per chi non ha l'occhio allenato e quindi per un giocatore occasionale, se invece siete dei giocatori con esperienza o dei grafici con l'occhio sensibile a risoluzione e realismo lasciate perdere e attendete la prossima generazione puntando su dispositivi con risoluzioni maggiori. Ritengo di non acquistare più cuffie virtuali che non abbiano almeno 8k di risoluzione, ovviamente la scheda video deve essere adeguatamente potente e si parla di RX 2080 altrimenti non se ne fa nulla. Il sistema touch è perfetto e difficilmente sbaglia un colpo... molto ergonomici e migliori della controparte HTC VIVE. Spero che questa recensione possa essere utile a qualcuno che pensa di acquistarli e che si attende il prodotto definitivo per la realtà virtuale... il mio consiglio è di attendere ancora un po... restituiti ad Amazon, che come sempre è ineccepibile, in attesa della prossima generazione.
review_date: Reviewed in Italy on December 1, 2018

one_reviews_text: Wanting to take my first steps in VR I decided to purchase the Oculus Rift. The convenience of the bundle and the price tag were the main reasons to choose this instead of HTC products.I bought the Oculus to experiment with VR ArchViz and flight simulation. Being a seasoned IT professional, nowadays little or nothing is capable of amazing myself. The VR experience blew me away. The potential of the technology is endless, both for professional and recreational use (including games).I tried the Oculus Rift with IL 2 Battle of Stalingrad and the sense of immersion was breathtaking, and vomit inducing too :)Google Earth VR is pretty amazing too just to name a couple .
review_date: Reviewed in Germany on January 31, 2019

one_reviews_text: VR ist definitiv nicht für jeden was. Und ein entscheidender Punkt, weshalb das so ist, ist der Preis. Das muss einem klar bewusst sein. Die Rift an sich ist relativ teuer und dann braucht man zusätzlich dazu noch einen leistungsstarken Rechner, da VR Anwendungen immer mehr Rechenleistung benötigen als vergleichbare nicht-VR Anwendungen.Wenn einem das klar ist, und man das in kauf nimmt, hat man mit der VR ein meiner Meinung nach sehr beeindruckendes Erlebnis, was man garnicht so richtig mit anderen Spielen vergleichen kann.Erstmal zum Gerät an sich:Ich hatte bisher mehrere Cardboard VR-Brillen auf (Handy-VR), die HTC-VIVE und eben auch die Rift. Von denen hat mir die Rift mit abstand am besten gefallen. Zum einen weil Handy-VR halt irgendwie nix halbes und nix ganzes ist, aber auch im Vergleich mit der VIVE gefällt mir die Rift besser, zum einen ist der Preis deutlich besser. Außerdem fühlen sich meiner Meinung nach die Controller einfach besser an, auch wenn die Form erstmal gewöhnungsbedürftig ist. Aber auch vom reinen Tragekomfort, die Rift ist gefühlt deutlich leichter als die VIVE, was gerade wenn man vor hat, mehr als ne Stunde zu spielen doch ziemlich wichtig wird. Was die Bildschirme und die Trackingqualität angeht ist mir kein gravierender Unterschied aufgefallen. Ich hab allerdings nur die normale VIVE und nicht die VIVE Pro getestet.Was das Tracking angeht ist wohl die VIVE vorne, da sie einen größeren Spielbereich abdecken kann.Ansonsten wirkt alles solide und stabil. Die Controller sind auch schon das eine oder andere mal aus der Hand gefallen und auf dem Boden gelandet, haben dabei aber keinen schaden genommen.Software und Einrichtung:Das war der meiner Meinung nach nervigste Teil. Ich musste ein bisschen Geduld aufbringen beim installieren der Oculus Software und auch das einrichten war ein wenig friemelig.Teilweise wurde ohne erkennbaren Grund einer der Sensoren nicht richtig erkannt, weshalb das Setup nicht fortgesetzt werden konnte. Also hin und herprobieren, USB Stecker hin und her wechseln bis es irgendwann funktioniert hat.Ich habe alles an USB 3.0 Ports angeschlossen, die Sensoren werden allerdings teilweise trotzdem nur als USB 2.0 erkannt. Keine Ahnung, woran das liegt, scheint aber keinen erkennbaren negativen Nebeneffekt zu haben.Auch das einrichten des Spielbereiches war ein bisschen nervig, da man sehr oft milimeterweise die Positionen der Sensoren nachjustieren muss und jedes mal kurz warten, dass alles erkannt wurde.Das VR Erlebnis:Je nach Spiel variiert das ganze natürlich und ist mal mehr und mal weniger immersiv.Das Reine umsehen in der VR ist schonmal ein Erlebnis für sich. Wer das nicht kennt und eine ungefähre Vorstellung davon haben will kann sich ja mal mit Google Cardboard vertraut machen, dazu muss man nicht so viel Geld ausgeben.Die Touchgesten und das Greifen hat man schnell verinnerlicht und sie werden zu einem natürlichen Ablauf, sodass sich das interagieren mit der Virtuellen Welt sehr natürlich anfühlt.Das bewegen ist leider jedoch mit Hindernissen verbunden. Es gibt im Wesentlichen drei Arten, sich in der VR zu bewegen. Das eine, und auch das, was sich am besten anfühlt ist das bewegen innerhalb des Spielbereichs. Das ist der Bereich, den man vorher eingerichtet hat, der unterschiedlich groß ausfallen kann, was dann aber wiederum an die Fläche gebunden ist, die man tatsächlich in dem Raum zur Verfügung hat. Wenn das Zimmer also sehr vollgestellt ist, oder Möbel im weg sind, fällt dieser entsprechend klein aus. Innerhalb dieses Bereiches ist dafür aber ein uneingeschränktes Bewegen möglich.Die zweite Möglichkeit, die im ersten Moment sehr unnatürlich wirkt und die Immersion ein gutes Stück abschwächt ist das Teleportieren in der VR. In vielen Spielen ist es möglich, sich mit Druck auf eine der Tasten auf dem Controller einen Bereich vor sich auszuwählen, zu dem man dann teleportiert wird. Das ist ein Kompromiss, den man halt leider eingehen muss. Die dritte Möglichkeit ist das Laufen innerhalb der VR mir den Analogsticks. Mein erster Gedanke war, dass das doch viel besser sein muss als das Teleportieren. Ist aber nicht so. Dadurch dass du die Controller als Hände und die Rift selbst als Augen bzw. Kopf benutzt möchtest du auch deine Beine zum laufen benutzen. Jetzt mit dem Analogstick zu laufen sendet deinem Körper widersprüchliche Signale, was bei mir schon nach wenigen Minuten zu derart heftiger Motion Sickness führt, dass ich aufhören muss zu spielen. Es fühlt sich einfach richtig ekelhaft schwindelerregend an, sich so durch die VR zu bewegen. Aber ich schätze das ist auch Geschmackssache. Gewöhnen kann bzw will ich mich daran allerdings nicht, das ist mir die Übelkeit nicht wert.Man muss aber sagen, dass die meisten Spiele, die ich gespielt habe das ganz gut gelöst haben mit einer kombination aus dem freien Bewegen im Spielbereich und Teleportation.Lieferumfang:Die Rift kommt mit den beiden Controllern und zwei Sensoren für das Tracking, sowie einem kleinen Werkzeug mit dem die Kopfhörer abgenommen werden können.Was hier ein bisschen schade ist, ist dass die Kabel meiner Meinung nach recht kurz ausfallen. Ich habe mir zusätzlich noch ein USB 3.0 Verlängerungskabel, einen USB 3.0 Hub und ein HDMI Verlängerungskabel kaufen müssen damit alles funktionierte.Sonstiges:Leider ist VR noch nicht so verbreitet, weshalb es auch eine überschaubare Menge an Spielen gibt, die dann auch noch häufig recht teuer ausfallen.Außerdem muss man damit rechnen, dass man evtl bei den ersten 2-3 Sessions in der VR eine mehr oder weniger starke Übelkeit empfindet und sich erstmal daran gewöhnen muss. Sobald man sich allerdings dran gewöhnt hat kommt das eigentlich nicht mehr vor.Scheinbar gibt es ein Paar Probleme für Brillenträger, die ich persönlich aber nicht so ganz nachvollziehen kann. Die meisten Brillen passen nicht unter die Rift, man muss sie also absetzen. Einige meiner Freunde, die die Rift benutzt haben und Brillenträger sind haben sich beschwert, dass sie teilweise sehr unscharf sehen. Ich bin selbst auch Brillenträger und hab keine derartigen Probleme. Allerdings hab ich auch eine relativ schwache Brille, vielleicht liegt es daran.
review_date: Reviewed in Germany on March 28, 2019

one_reviews_text: J'adore !!!! Pas trop lourd (c'est ce que je craignais), pas trop chaud sous le casque non plus. C'est vraiment une expérience unique qu'il faut tester au moins une fois. Par contre attention au mal de mer. Dans l'idéal testez plutôt chez un ami ou en salon avant d'acheter, certaines personnes ne supportent pas. Et, quoi qu'on en dise, vous pourrez vous dire "j'imagine ce que çà peut être", dans le bon sens comme le mauvais, non, je vous assure que non. Vous ne pouvez pas imaginer tant que vous n'avez pas tester ;)Vérifiez bien la configuration de votre pc avant. La petite bêbête est très gourmande en ressources.
review_date: Reviewed in France on July 16, 2018

one_reviews_text: Muy fácil de configurar, el visor da una muy buena sensación de inmersión y los mandos te permiten usar tus manos virtuales con bastante realismo. Con los dos sensores incluidos se puede hacer room-scale y moverse con bastante libertad pero es recomendable un tercero si queréis ampliar vuestra zona de juego y mejorar el reconocimiento de los mandos cuando estáis de espaldas. Importante recordar que el visor utiliza un puerto HDMI de la tarjeta gráfica además de el que utilice el monitor del ordenador y que necesitaréis por lo menos 3 puertos USB 3.0, yo he tenido que comprar un HUB y un adaptador de displayport a HDMI.
review_date: Reviewed in Spain on December 28, 2018

one_reviews_text: After a small misunderstanding everything was hooked up and installed and updated super fast just as it should. Wearing the head piece is comfortable and the view is very good with great depth perception and great tracking as my head moved. The controllers are a bit small in my hands but once I start using them I got use to the feel of the controls. The first problem I've had is that the lens seem to fog or get smudged after a couple of hours and need to be cleaned and sometimes they require cleaning more often. The last is that I find my forehead starting to sweat along the cushioning material and during play have to stop and wipe my fore head and the cushion dry with a towel. And MAKE SURE YOU HAVE ROOM, just as the video showed I moved around and touched a light but realized before it was knocked over and then took the extra time to make my play area larger.
review_date: Reviewed in Germany on March 16, 2019

one_reviews_text: Faccio questa recensione qualche mese dopo il mio acquisto, in quanto ho voluto provare per bene il visore Oculus Rift prima di dare il mio giudizio.Personalmente sono sempre stato un appassionato di tecnologia e di Videogames, quindi appena usci questo prodotto ero entusiasta per quel che prometteva e per quelle che erano le possibilità offerte, nonostante ciò però ho deciso di aspettare che il suddetto prodotto scendesse a un prezzo ragionevole prima di fare il nuovo acquisto, quindi ho aspettato qualche anno e quando il prezzo era diventato finalmente ragionevole ho deciso di fare il grande passo, I visori per la realtà virtuale sono una tecnologia rivoluzionaria, perché ti permettono di immergerti all'interno di un esperienza virtuale, che può essere un videogioco, un film oppure anche altre esperienze di vario tipo,ad esempio visitare un luogo dall'altra parte del mondo, oppure guardare dall'alto verso il basso dalla cima di un grattacielo. Qualsiasi sia l'esperienza che vogliate fare è completamente immersiva e vi sembrerà tutto estremamente reale, certo ancora vi è il lieve effetto zanzariera (ovvero in alcune occasioni potrete notare la griglia dei pixel sullo schermo), ma per come è immersiva la realtà virtuale non ci farete nemmeno caso. Ho fatto provare il visore a un gran numero di amici e parenti e anche quelli che all'inizio erano un po' dubbiosi dopo ne sono rimasti completamente affascinati e stupefatti e alcuni di loro hanno deciso anche di voler comprare un visore, chi per playstation chi proprio l'oculus.Nonostante io scriva questa recensione a mesi dall'acquisto devo dire che non ho mai smesso di usare Oculus Rift e che sono ancora entusiasta del mio acquisto. Non posso che consigliare a chiunque di dare un'opportunità a questa nuova tecnologia, che sono sicuro, presto diventerà di massa, si tratta solo di dare occasione alla gente di provarla più spesso e alla fine molti rimmaranno entusiasti di questa tecnologia e decideranno di acquistarla.
review_date: Reviewed in Italy on March 24, 2019
review_title: Oculus rift è un' esperienza rivoluzionaria, modificherà il nostro modo di vivere l'intrattenimento.

one_reviews_text: Wer bisher nur die Handy VR Spielereien gekannt hat, wird hier in eine völlig neue Welt katapultiert. Zwar gehört die Oculus Rift noch zu den VR Pionier-Projekten, sie zeigt aber wohin der Zug in den nächsten Jahren fahren wird. So ist mit der aktuellen Technik sicher nicht alles perfekt, z.B. das erkennbare Fliegengitter oder die wenig komfortable bzw. nicht vorhandene Anpassung an Brillenträger, dennoch bietet die Rift jetzt schon ein Erlebnis, welches sich mit nichts vergleichen lässt.Die ersten Gehversuche mit den freien Spielen sind auf jeden Fall schon mal ein guter Einstieg in das Thema, wenngleich sich die allgemeine Erfahrung und Begeisterung natürlich nach einiger Zeit leicht abnutzt. So definieren die Anwendungen und Spiele fortwährend die Qualität eines VR-Systems.In meinem Fall sind das Tennis und Tischtennis Spiele, von denen es insbesondere zwei gibt, die alleine schon die Anschaffung der Brille wert sind: "Eleven Table Tennis" sowie "First Person Tennis". Für VR sind beide Spiele perfekt, was beim Tennis ein wenig überrascht , da man nicht mal eben 10 Meter laufen kann in der eigenen Wohnung. Über verschiedene Bewegungs-Optionen, insbesondere einem Auto-Slide Modus, kann man aber sehr gut und vor allem sehr realistisch Tennis spielen. Nach ein wenig Eingewöhnung spielt sich der Simulations-Modus beim "First Person Tennis" sehr gut und mit ausreichend Gefühl für Schläger und Ball. Die Motivation steigt stetig an immer mehr Turniere zu gewinnen und technisch immer besser zu werden.Besagtes Fliegengitter sieht man bei der Rift auch irgendwann nicht mehr. In jedem Fall ist die Rift erst der Anfang, man darf gespannt sein wie realistisch das Erlebnis erst wird, wenn Technik und Spiele noch einmal einen Quantensprung machen, was mit Sicherheit in den kommenden 5 Jahren der Fall sein wird.
review_date: Reviewed in Germany on February 23, 2019
review_title: Die erste brauchbare VR Generation, die mit den Anwendungen wächst
