one_reviews_text: Bought it for room scale. Works great and came with an extension cable. What's not to like?Setting up room scale with the Rift can be a bit fiddly but the software shows you which sensor to move or rotate if needed. You also need to make sure you have the USB bandwidth to accommodate the third sensor. This should be a USB 2 port as putting a third sensor on a USB 3 port is too much for a single USB 3 controller. The difference being that the sensor sends raw data to the PC when plugged into USB 3 and compressed data when using USB 2. In practical use for me the room scale tracking seems to work very well in the approximately 12x10 foot area I have defined with 2 sensors on USB 3 and one on USB 2.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2018

one_reviews_text: I've spent almost 200 hours in VR using this headset, and I plan to spend many more. Rift is an experience like none other, and is well worth the price of $400 IF your PC can run it. I started out using only a Ryzen 3 1200, and I had serious performance issues. I upgraded to a Ryzen 7 1700 and all my problems disappeared.The headset display is clear and screendoor effect is hardly noticeable. If you get sweaty, your lenses MAY fog up a little, but that's to be expected. When that happens, put your headset down, dry your face, and keep playing in a few more minutes.The controllers are incredibly comfortable and you hardly notice them after a few hours of playing. They feel very natural.If you are interested in VR at all and have the equipment to run it, GET THIS HEADSET! You won't regret it!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2019

one_reviews_text: Tell you what, folks don't know how cool VR is until they try it, no matter what they say. I was a skeptic 'cause of how trendy the concept suddenly became in yuppie circles, but then my buddy got one and now I'm a big believer. Anyway.Get your uncles and aunts and parents to try it while everybody watches the computer screen and heckles. That's my new favorite family game. Anybody can drop right in and enjoy this stuff. I recommend getting Office Simulator right away through Steam; it's a super-casual first-encounter type experience, and it's got heaps of fun stuff to do.Eventually, when you've gotten used to it, get some of the big titles running - Robo Recall is like a full-body arcadesplosion, and you'll get legitimately winded with the physical exertion of dodging and jumping around like an idiot with a bucket on your head. And it's free with the headset. Highly recommend.Never buy a console again; if you've got a decent computer, just get this bad boy.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2018
review_title: Works like a champ. Great at parties.

one_reviews_text: Overall, the Oculus Rift has been a pleasure using. I love how many games are available and the sense I'm really in another place. The Touch controllers are very nice and the two added cameras really do give a great experience in tracking and moving.My only complaints are the screen resolution and the placement of the screen. If I don't wear my places, everything is very blurry. Even when I do wear my glasses, things aren't as crystal clear looking like with the Gear VR.While it is also immersive, this can reduce a bit by the under nose cut. I am able to see a bit of light (even strapping it tighter) and if I look down I can see the floor just a bit.These things shouldn't discourage you from the overall experience. The Tiltbrush app alone is enough to buy this (it's truly an amazing 3D art app). Everything is fluid and you won't find such immersive apps that give you hours of entertainment anywhere else. The price is truly unbeatable for getting into the VR experience. It's really like another computer system, just on your head.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2018

one_reviews_text: This just adds to the room-scale VR that I tend to favor. Helps for the one direction that seems to be the one that I can't face.This sensor might not be necessary if you face the two sensors you already have, facing each other across from each other from the center of the room.The only problem I have had is how the Oculus recommends where to put it. It wants me to put it right behind me but since I can't, I have to just ignore the warning it gives me. Nothing wrong with that anyways, I just don't know for sure if my area of the room is totally optimal or not for room-scale VR games.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2018

one_reviews_text: For early adoption mainstream VR I am very pleased with the build quality and overall experience of the Rift. At $400 with free games if you have a graphics card that can run one (I used GTX 1080), you wont be disappointed. While the library of games is still missing the system seller, there are a lot of good experiences to be had. The biggest gripe is going to be screen resolution and the subsequent "screen-door" effect, but given that graphics cards are still a ways out from easily being able to support dual 4k+ screens at 90hz+ this is a worthy early console, sort of like the PsOne was for 3D graphics (sans the great game library) it sold me that VR will change gaming eventually.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2018
review_title: A Great Console for the Early Days of Proper VR

one_reviews_text: I purchased the Oculus Rift before Touch was available. Using the Rift with either the Xbox controller or the little remote got very boring quickly. After buying the Touch controllers, my love of the Rift has returned. Being able to see your hands in VR is really what makes VR. There are several games that support the Touch controller and are a blast to play. Robo Recall comes free with Touch and that game is amazing; it's exactly what VR is all about. I definitely recommend clearing a sizeable play area before stepping in. I've lost count of how many times I've hit my chair, desk, couch, ceiling fan...
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2017
review_title: A must if you have an Oculus Rift.

one_reviews_text: I held back on buying one for a long time, but decided to go for it in order to escape the reality of 2018.It was very easy to set up.  I had run the Oculus compatibility program and had identified that my USB ports were not compatible, so I bought a separate card.  Plugging in and setting up the cameras was very easy.  I was up and running within half an hour.  The packaging and unboxing experience felt like a well thought out product, rather than just another PC accessory.The experience is great.  I had a Samsung VR Gear and thought it would be the same based on the screen resolution, but the full Oculus is a much better experience.  A PC produces much better graphics and that comes across in the games and experiences available.  It's not absolutely sharp and clear resolution, but in a fast moving game, you don't notice it.  What comes across is the feeling of space and being there.  The objects you interact with have a sense of presence that makes the experience unique.  Two titles that stand out for me are Robo Recall and Space Pirate Trainer.  Using the headset for more than 30 minutes did not give my neck a strain, nor was it uncomfortable both in terms of wear and vision.The headset itself feels well made.  The headphones are clear and do not distort at higher volumes (I had set the headset at 70% and it was too loud for me).  The touch controllers are comfortable and feel intuitive.  I'd like to be able to use them for all my non-VR games if I could.Unlike the Samsung Gear VR, you can adjust the lenses to take into account the distance between your eyes.  This gave me a much sharper image than the Gear.  If you wear glasses, though, you're probably going to have a problem.  There's very little space for those (I have seen workarounds online).  There is no focus setting, which the Gear VR has, so you can't take off your glasses and adjust.The Oculus Store and Steam VR seem to have a decent number of games.  Not sure if content will keep on coming, but what's available right now is entertaining enough.I'd like to add that I've used the Vive at a demo station and I find both VR experiences and visuals to be about the same.  I'd have considered the Vive if it was around the same price and its sensors were easy to set up.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2018
review_title: Every technophile should experience this.  A polished and well thought out system.

one_reviews_text: My kids liked the VR arcade at the mall a bit too much. It made sense to purchase a quality VR set.  I did extensive research  into VR sets before selecting this one. The main reason I selected it is because it’s an all in one set. Many of the other VR sets require add-ons to function properly.  Only thing I added was a third sensor. All the reviews I read said it works best with three sensors. So I simply skipped the delay and bought three sensors. It’s very easy to set up. I was very intimidated but it worked fine.  You can buy mounts for the wall to make it best for you. As you can see I chose to wedge the sensors between and on top of household items.  I watched a homemade YouTube video on the best location and height for placement for the front two sensors.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2019
review_title: Great set. Easy to set up and nice quality.

one_reviews_text: I went with the Oculus over the Vive because the Oculus has access to the Oculus store and Steam VR, where the Vive can only play Steam VR games.  That's all good, except they don't tell you... The controls are terrible in Steam.  Throwing and other quick actions are just not tracked well right now.  It's a known issue, check out the Reddit.The controllers are also not as user friendly as the Vive.  Vive controllers feel more natural because of their weight and length.  Button position is not nearly as convenient on the Oculus. It's a little nitpicky, but for the price...I get to be.Also avoid the over priced Oculus sensor mounts. Tape em on a wall or mount a shelf. People are price gouging, crappy 3d printed hunks of plastic that you tape on a wall
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2018
review_title: Boasts Steam VR and Oculus game library access - not as simple

one_reviews_text: If you have a computer that meets the specs, BUY THIS!! You're welcome.I tried the OG and found it wasn't any different than a cell phone brain box. The Oculus Rift is incredible! It will not disappoint.--UPDATE--I've had the Rift for three days now. On day two the headset and senors began repeatedly disconnecting and reconnecting to the computer (after a restart). I tried to restart multiple times and eventually had to go online to find a lengthy solution that I *hope will resolve the issue. Apparently it's a problem for a majority of Oculus Rift headsets.The experience is still so cool that I won't return it, and I'll work through the hassle however, Oculus should fix connectivity issues. It seems like an elementary requirement that they should have spent more time developing/improving for a headset that requires computer access.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2019
review_title: Amazing - don't waste money on the Oculus Go

one_reviews_text: If I could only give it a Zero Star. Do a search, and read all the HDMI issues with the Oculus! I wasted much time trying to get this to work, and had to return it. I couldn't find any Support phone numbers either, just a notice that they will contact you in 2 days. I am no novice to computers either, and my PC, is plenty capable.It was the price and ability to use the xbox controller that lured me in, or I would have gone with the HTC Vive. So now I will wait for the new much better HTC Vive Pro to come out. And yes, I reverted my Drivers back to the 4X's old ones, (as if, I wanted to do that so my non VR games wouldn't be optimized) that Oculus, recommended in bold red letters on their support site, after I wasted so much time trying to figure out why it would not work. Swapping out display-port adapters, hooking direct to hdmi, different cables,etc etc. No matter still couldn't get the headset to work. Also, the room space had to be smaller than I preferred, for the 3 sensors to lock in (bought the extra one). I guess many had much luck with the Oculus, I was not one. My recommendation would be to look elsewhere! I really tried to get it to work, but with lousy support, and much frustration, I opted to send it back.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2018

one_reviews_text: The technology is a little young yet.  Had trouble getting it running and spent a while getting the right connectors and adapters.  Had to work around issues with getting my graphics card to send a signal out of both HDMI ports at once (workaround was to use an adapter to use 1 HDMI and 1 DVI port).  Required a re-install of the software (as a last ditch attempt to get the device to show a picture) after all of the port corrections / adapters were connected.  Beware - chaining HDMIs may run you into issues as the HDMI port may not have enough power to drive it the longer distance.Spend some time planning your connections (2 x USB 3 and 1 HDMI in addition to your normal computer display) and make sure to run the Oculus compatibility tool before purchasing.Once we worked through the issues on setup then it was pretty cool to play with.  Expect to have some difficulty getting it to work correctly with your individual games (unless you're just using the Oculus store) but Steam and Oculus are coming along a bit faster in this area so it was less problematic than the initial setup.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2018
review_title: Young Technology but once it works it is cool

one_reviews_text: These really do block outside noise, which increases immersion quite a bit. I use my Oculus almost exclusively for sim racing. General audio fidelity is high. Bass is adequate, I don't really notice a difference from the original headphones, although I do have a Buttkicker mounted to my sim rig which would mask any bass loss. Generally I think this con is overblown.Putting on the headset and taking it off is a little more cumbersome since you have to nestle these in/out of your ears, but it's not a big deal. I do find myself using virtual desktop more as a result, which I now think is a positive change.The only real con for me is that it's kind of gross if you want to share the headset with your friends.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2019

one_reviews_text: Incredible technology.  I am hooked! Took quite a bit of work but had it up and running on two different, fast computers with high end graphics cards.  Most of the work was updating the Windows computers since I mostly use Mac products. The immersive quality of the product exceeded expectations.  Used the unit on Sansar and it frequently crashed.  When it worked I could see the incredible possibilities.  It will take time to get these VR applications stable.  Apollo 11 is incredible and the games were great.  BUT as I activated a trial of a very large 24 gb game the unit stopped working. The touch controllers disappeared and the headset went dead.I rebooted, looked at my device manager and the headset still was not on or recognized. I tried it on the other computer and it was still dead.  Contacted support and have not heard anything back.  Other reviews show that Oculus will not replace with any new devices. I always feel safe since amazon will take the items back.  I am ordering a new unit and returning the defective one. It has gone down 50 in a week and I am getting the Square trade warranty.  I planned to buy a second unit for gameplay.  I will give it some time to see if the new one lasts.  From others experience it sounds like the extended warranty is worthwhile Many reviews state the units quit frequently.On any technology purchases, Amazon has been the best.  If something is defective out of the box they take it back. Customer service at most technology companies do not understand customer service. Amazon is your ally against them. I do not know how amazon will continue to afford to do this. Time will tell.  I will update after the replacement unit arrives.Update:  Simple fix, The cable at the headset had come unplugged. Interesting that I could not find the fix easily online. Customer support finally responded.  Raised my score. This thing is amazing!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 11, 2018
review_title: Love it.....  Sorry it died. Thank goodness I bought it through Amazon.

one_reviews_text: I have a rather old, but beefy server I built on the Xeon platform.  It is dual cpu with 12 cores total and I have 96 gb of ram.  I have two radeon 480 8gb gpus running in Cross Fire mode (both GPUs acting as 1) and the software still tells me my setup doesn't meet Oculus performance reqs.  This wouldn't be a big deal to me all the games and apps started up in spite of that notification.  Luckily, all my favorite ones, like Beat Saber, Table Tennis, and Marvel all start up, but epic roller coaster and others I purchased won't start up.Oh, if you don't have USB 3.0/2.0 available on your box together, make sure to buy the extra cards/extensions necessary to do so, if you want to use extra sensors.  I still have to add a 3.0 port card in to support that.  It works fine without the 360 sensors.  And, you need both 3.0 and 2.0 USB to do 360 degree.  You can only have one sensor plugged into 3.0 at a time, apparently....Another issue I have is that, like other comments, the HDMI cable does not always get recognized and can cause lots of frustration.One last frustration is that, if you have multiple users of different heights, as in our house, you have to go through the whole sensor set up process, including resetting the guardian system, to reset the height for the user.  Poor user experience, in my opinion.It is still SO worth the purchase and frustrations.  The experience is like no other.  I am an adrenaline junkie and love the feeling I get standing on the virtual heights in the games.  One of my favorites is the sample promo for Spider man Homecoming, where you sling up to the top of a crane and swing down from the top.  When I look down to the street below, I get that vertigo feeling I love without the danger of falling to my death.  My other favorite is the space walk outside the ISS.  It is incredible to see the actual sizing of the space station and its parts. It virtually fulfills a dream of mine to walk in space and see the earth from that perspective.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2019

one_reviews_text: This system works very well with the  Alienware AW17R4-7345SLV-PUS 17" Laptop (7th Generation Intel Core i7, 16GB RAM, 1TB HDD, Silver) VR Ready with NVIDIA GTX 1070 that I purchased from Amazon also.  I took of one star because I have had problems with the sensors not calibrating correctly and it wants you to configure it standing.  I got the Oculus Rift over the HTV because I wanted a sitting VR experience to start.  I am still working on the configuration and playing with settings.  So far I have gotten it to work but have never gotten a perfect calibration of the sensors which makes it hard to use the controllers that come with it.  I also have not been able to get it to work with steam VR as of yet.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2017

one_reviews_text: The Rift was so much fun. Right up until it stopped working.I spent a lot of money on this thing, and a ton on extra bells and whistles to really enjoy my VR system, and because of all that money spent, I took extra special care of my headset and controllers. It sits safely on a stand, with no natural light around, and wrapped in thick, black cloth. None of that mattered. On Sunday, I spent my day off in and out of VR. Monday and Tuesday, I did not have time. Today, Wednesday, I decided I wanted to spend a little while with the headset on. Not gonna happen, cause suddenly my left screen doesn't turn on and my right screen is just a bunch of color lines of red and green. I did the checks. Cords, ports, software, GPU software and settings and so on...Luckily I am still within my return window and will be doing so, if the headset will not be replaced.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2019

one_reviews_text: Its a great VR headset IF your computer is built right and you don’t need glasses or contacts. My significant other and I bought this after designing out own computer to exceed its desired specs and it works phenomenally. However, while he can play it for hours at a time I can only play for so long before the blurriness gets to me. I just can’t seem to adjust it to match my glasses. That being said it is alsp poorly responsive in games like tiltbrush if you only have the two sensors that come with it. It’s recommended that you buy either a third or fourth for the best experience. But dropping another $60 per sensor isn’t everyone’s ideal time.Ultimately its a great sensor just not astigmatism friendly.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2019

one_reviews_text: OH man where to start, This headset so far has totally changed how I look at gaming and PC home entertainment. I have usd both the Vive and now this headset and I will admit that the vives tracking is a bit better at stock but for the most part it is almost the same and the controlers are bar none better on the rift than any other headset you can buy for the next year at least until the knuckles release. The resolution of the screen is fine and I dont see the screen door effect unless the image is a solid color like black loading screens so that is not an issue unless you really try to look for it. For its base price at 399.00 USD I cant find a reason to not grab this over the other options out there. The vive and vive pro are simply way too expensive for what you get as of right now seeing as you can buy a rift with a 3rd sensor and result in the same tracking and room scale as a vive and save 120 ish $ in the processs. The set up was really easy, idk why some people have said its hard. You plug everything into the USBs and the HDMI in and run the oculus set up app and it just kinda does it all for you. The "hardest" part is moving the sensor cameras around a bit till it says hey that is a good spot for good tracking and you move on. Took me anout 15 min from unboxing to logging into VRChat. This, unlike the vive comes with everything at stock and does not try to throw anything at you as addons later down the road such as the head phones being built in and the controlers being stock over the wands. Vive will be selling the pro soon and the kuckles shortly after as seperate items to buy at VERY high costs that simply turn me off to that platform completely. This headset is also far more comfortable and does not plug my nose or cut into my face frrom the pressure like other headsets do. The controlers are so damn nice to use they feel so natural and fit the hand so well. My GF and I have both main systems for VR, Vive for the top end best of the best at the expense of being way too much $, and now the Rift for being comfortable and easy. We both agree that the Rift is better as a user. She actually almost sold her vive for the Rift but I convinced her to just keep it for the new addons coming later. If you are on the fence about this I say pick this headset hands down. Esp of you can get a good deal or rebate on it or use the amazon trade in to save some money it becomes such an amazing value. I traded in my xim4 PS4 Kb/m converter, since i sold my PS4, and it cut 80 bucks off the cost of this headset making it 310$ USD which imo made this hands down the best value headset you can get period.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2018
review_title: This headset is hands down the best experience I have had.

one_reviews_text: Easy to install, full VR with roomscale. With 2 cameras that come with it I get nearly perfect tracking up to ~300 degrees around me. It won't work if I'm facing straight behind the cameras - I suspect I'll need to buy the 3rd sensor for that. I think the 3rd sensor is definitely worth it for more intense games like Robo Recall where you're literally running around and dodging for your life. But for casual games not really needed. The touch controllers are extremely comfortable and feel natural to use.Also, the touch controllers are virtually indestructible. This is sort of a bad thing, because literally punch a hole through your wall.I was also able to get steam VR up and running with minimal difficulty, so I get the best of both the Oculus store and steam. Really glad I ended up choosing this over Vive. Not saying Vive was bad when I tried it - but they are basically very similar to each other, except that Oculus is half the price and gives a higher quality feel over the Vive...win win.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2017

one_reviews_text: Bought for my son's birthday. He has been using for over a month and he loves it. He paired it with an Nvidia 960 graphics card and it works great. I can only imagine how much better it would be with a high end card. What I personally like the most is how committed Occulus seems to be in making their headset a mainstream computer peripheral. Once you enter this VR world you immediately notice how far they have come in the last year. The company had a major software glitch recently and they were on top of it in a flash, apologizing everywhere. My son was not even aware of it, but they reached out to him. My son got $15 towards a game he really wanted, all for a little down time he suffered through. Now that Occulus is owned by a major company I feared that they may disappear or lose their drive to be the best. My fears have been put to rest.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 29, 2018
review_title: Works great with top notch support

one_reviews_text: My husband purchased the Oculus and Beat Saber for me earlier this year. Since I’ve been playing, I haven’t gone back to console gaming. VR is way too much fun! It’s been a great way for my teenage son and I to spend some quality time together and compete on expert levels. It’s also great cardio! I had the in-laws try it out too recently and they were hooked! They really enjoyed Robo Recall.My husband and I took my son and his friend to a VR Arcade with the HTC Vives. We definitely prefer the Oculus. The controllers are lightweight and ergonomic, and the headset isn’t big and bulky like the Vive. The vives also had a gym locker smell, and it didn’t matter how many sanitary wipes were used on them.We also got a little frustrated with the tracking and freezing on the Vives. I’m not sure if it was due to the sensors being mounted above, or the computers, or if it was the vives. We still had fun at the arcade but we are thankful to have the Oculus, it’s been 6 months with zero issues.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2018

one_reviews_text: This thing is insanely awesome and is probably the best gaming peripheral I've ever bought! I started out in VR with the Samsung Gear VR so I had expected the Oculus Rift to be a bit of a step up in terms of quality of the games and overall fidelity. Once I tried the Oculus Rift, I was completely blown away. Not only it is leagues and leagues more immersive and clear, but the games themselves are at a whole other level.The main takeaway for people is do not overlook the Oculus Touch hand controllers that come included in this package as a gimmick. In my opinion they are more fun than the headset itself! They are crazy accurate even down to finger position! Being able to wave, picking things up, shoot gun, pull back bows, and throw objects is just astounding.Don't forget you also get 4 free games in this bundle. Please try Robo Recall!!! It is a masterpiece in terms of how they geared every little detail of the game for VR.This is an amazing package and is well worth the money in my opinion. It is both fun and it gets you on your feet and physically moving around. Don't be surprised if you work up a sweat in certain games, you will move that much.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2017
review_title: Hands down the best gaming peripheral I've ever owned! Insanely fun and immersive, with the bonus of physical activity.

one_reviews_text: I have used the Oculus Rift way back when all you could use as an input was an Xbox controller or the simple Oculus remote. It was still a very impressive experience-- with stereoscopic 3D to really make you feel like you're there, and built in stereo speakers to add to the ambience-- but something was truly lacking. And what it was lacking is the Oculus Touch. Without it, the Oculus was just a gimmick; it was just a glorified way of controlling the camera with your head/viewpoint. And only interacting with the virtual world with a traditional controller just felt like a shallow experience. But the Oculus Touch does such a stellar job at giving the impression of hand presence. It's an incredible piece of hardware: intelligent placing of buttons to give the impression of grasping an object and to fit the shape of the hand superbly, fantastic motion tracking, vibration feedback, and touch sensors, so the controller has input based on the positioning of your hands, and not just the buttons themselves. It's a must-have to get the most out of the VR experience.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 2, 2019
review_title: A necessary component to enjoy VR

one_reviews_text: We decided to put this headset on our wedding registry and I'm SO glad we did. It's hard to describe how awesome VR and this headset are without having someone try it themselves. Every friend and family member I've told about says "Oh, that sounds pretty cool." Then when they come over and actually try it, they are blown away and want to play the entire time they're visiting (including the non-gamers like our parents).We did end up buying an extra sensor for the best possible tracking (we didn't try it without the extra sensor so I can't say how much it helped), and a leather face pad to replace the stock foam one because the included one gets sweaty and seemed unsanitary when we have people over.The included games were honestly an after-thought but I figured I'd try Robo Recall just for the heck of it and that game is AWESOME. We've found so many great games that anyone who comes to try it out can find something they like (it's also a pretty safe bet that anyone will like Beat Saber).It is expensive but, to me, it's totally worth the price. There was minimal frustration with the initial set-up (we weren't able to connect one of the Touch devices right away but it worked out), and once we set it up we've had no problems with having to reboot or adjust anything.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2018
review_title: You just have to try it

one_reviews_text: If you're on the fence about getting a VR system, look no further. The price is very cheap now and it really immerses you into the game. Is freaking fantastic for flight syms, tanks syms, and just about anything else you want to play. Being in aviation, I can tell you how realistic it looks. Obviously they can't help you with the G-forces, but the visual effects are top notch. Back in the 90's I drove tanks for the Army. The tank play in War Thunder i exactly like the real thing from a drivers point of view. If you want to experience the real thing without joining the military or going to flight school, this is the closest you can get...and IT IS CLOSE.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 25, 2019

one_reviews_text: They are very well made.  The headsets are solid and lite. The hand controllers are comfortable and easy to get use to.  Easy to install and calibrate.The headset cable seems to get the way for some games and it looks we’llhave to extend it (both of course hdmi/usb3).We were a little hesitant  about our graphics card  (MSI Radeon RX 570 8gb) not able to handle it but it does without any issues.Robo-recall runs flawlessly and so does SuperHot.Our system:Intel i732gb RAMSSD driveWindows 10 HomeGraphics: MSI Radeon RX 570 8gbThe 2 oculus sensors are connected to 2 usb 2.0 ports. The headset to an hdmi and usb 3.0 port.The graphics card has 3 DisplayPort outputs, 1 hdmi and 1 dvi.On the graphics card the Oculus connected to hdmi port and a viewsonic 144mhz monitor connected to 1 of the Display-ports.Most likely we’ll extend the headset cable by 6-10 feet. For the hdmi a regular extension should work. For the usb we need an “active” extension cable (sold here for like $14).All and all it’s lots of fun and good quality product.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2019
review_title: Solid fabrication, good quality, lots of fun

one_reviews_text: I have been wanting an Oculus ever since before it came out and I finally bought one after building my computer for it. A lot better than I thought, looked up issues like: god rays, FOV, sensors, screen door effect, etc. I've come to the conclusion that I basically forgot about all that once I put the head set on. It was my first time ever playing on a VR and was nervous about spending $400+ on something I've never tried before. Thankfully no regrets. One thing that was tricky though was getting everything from Steam setup, few Google searches fixed it though. All in all, good buy
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2018

one_reviews_text: Likes: it’s easy to use and set up. Long cables, the touch controllers are amazing and use only a single AA battery in each.Dislikes: not the most comfortable. If you are a glasses wearer then you will need to purchase an extra attachment to add more space in the goggles. You get a lot of lens flare do to the screen and the glass angle something that is much better with the S model. You must connect to the HDMI port that is directly connected to the GPU, and be sure to run the oculus compatibly test. With laptops contact the manufacturer to see if it can play oculus rift. Some laptops that read VR ready and have specs that can run it well doesn’t count oculus (HP Omen). Some compatibility issues with steam and the oculus store can occur as well.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2019
review_title: Lots of fun, go for the S though.

one_reviews_text: The touch controllers, absolutely amazing, great feel. The headset, fits but the pixel fade is delayed, you can see a pretty noticable blur that is somewhat distracting. The default face isnt comfortable and soaks up sweat so you will want an aftermarket face rest... it also loses tracking often, and struggles to keep up with fast paced gameplay. If you are in the market for this, you probably already understand the setup required to get it working outside the oculus home for steam, but if you aren’t aware please do your research. It isn’t a bad product, but I recommend the vive over this, spend a few hundred dollars more to get the most out of your money.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2019

one_reviews_text: Like you, I saw those YouTube videos of people freaking out in VR and thought, "They're really playing it up--it's not THAT big of a deal."  I'd also see clips of people playing on Twitch, and just watching it made me dizzy.  Between the two, I thought I knew what VR was.Then I experienced it.Just like the invention of television, pioneers tried to advertise TV on the radio but no one understood it.  Modern VR has the same problem in that you can't understand what it is until you experience it.  Worse still, people tried the "put your phone in this plastic box" and thought they knew what VR was, and have already made up their minds that it is a terrible gimmick.Find someone who has a Rift and try it.  For me, the Rift changed my perspective on gaming.  I find it difficult justifying time in the world of flat gaming in front of a monitor when I have the chance to dive inside and be part of it.  VR gaming is quite literally mind-blowing.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2018
review_title: Given the right PC, it will change your gaming life forever.

one_reviews_text: At first I loved the thing, but then I saw some flaws, and I am now deciding to return it for the Vive. It's OK, but it needs improvement. The tracking sucks, unless you want to fork over another $60-$120 for more sensors, then you are almost at the Vive. Also, more games are set up for the vive rather than the oculus, I have played a fair share of vr games from steam on my oculus, and some games that have vive controllers, and say they are meant for both, run poorly on my oculus. Unless you plan to play games that require you to constantly face forward, get the Vive.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2018
review_title: My advice: Go with the Vive, even though it's 200$ more.

one_reviews_text: I was blown away by VR when I first tried it.  The immersion is well executed with the rift.  I still enjoy playing VR whenever I can.  This thing changes the way video games are presented in a fundamental way.  Of course, the games that are out there for this thing vary from terrible to amazing but the immersion factor is generally always flawless on the rift.I guess one could criticize the fact you are anchored by a cord, however I wouldn't feel very safe if I had to be walking far with a blindfold on like this thing.  most games only require you lean or duck, step once or twice.Yep, you need a powerful computer to use this.  it's a well known barrier to VR.  you should also make sure you have a decent sized area to play without breakable objects near youThe setup took a bit of trial and error getting the sensors positioned right, but otherwise was easy enough
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2018

one_reviews_text: Absolutely amazing addition to the Oculus Rift. If you have one, you need these. I liked my Rift a lot before but once you get these in your hands, it's such an incredible experience. To have your hands be displayed so accurately in game and to actually interact with these environments is such a difference compared to using a traditional gamepad. I highly recommend Superhot VR, you'll feel like a movie star and you can have someone, who has never used VR before, hop in with ease and be blown away. The few people who tried it out at my house over various holidays parties won't stop talking about it/inviting themselves over. They fit in your hands amazingly and are so intuitive, especially compared to traditional controllers.While these downsides are not enough to lose a star, I will mention a few things that they lack, especially in comparison to other products like the Vive's motion controllers. First of all, these come with a single sensor to add to the one you already have for the Rift. Unlike the Vive however, both sensors are still designed to go in front of you, meaning no 360 degree coverage. While you rarely will have an issue with the Touch controllers being recognized in Oculus games since they are designed to be forward facing, 180 degree games, there are amazing games like Onward in Steam VR, that are designed to be roomscale experiences. As soon as something gets in between the sensors and the Touch controllers, like your body or arms, your hands will suddenly drift or stop moving. FYI, this is called "occlusion".I've gotten a third sensor directly from Oculus and use this one behind me in my setup to achieve roomscale. It's almost perfect coverage but when I face the one corner that I don't have a sensor in now, my controllers can get blocked by my arms or body and thats noticeable in games like Onward when you're holding a gun up. I've played the game on Vive before and I did not have these issues as much. Vive only uses two sensors as well so from a technological aspect, it's certainly possible for improvement from Oculus in this aspect. I should emphasize however, this is a rare issue and only occurs when I'm playing games and I face in one particular direction. Also, the Vive's lighthouse system was not perfect in my limited experience either so they both have some definite improvements they could use.As I said, this is all nitpicky and doesn't happen all the time or even in most games. The controllers are certainly a must buy if you already have the Rift.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2017

one_reviews_text: Been using this since March 2018 and it's been absolutely fantastic so far. I've dropped the headset plenty of times by accident from about 2 feet and I've seen no damage.  Base headset is very comfortable and I can barely feel weight of the earphones. Batteries in controllers last about a week if you use it daily for 6-8 hours. One problem is that one of my sensors wasn't able to update firmware after about 5 months so it made it useless (oculus requires all equipment to be up to date). I was able to get a refurbished replacement after emailing Oculus but they never gave an answer as to why my original sensor stopped functioning. But overall, this was one of the best investments I made.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 19, 2018

one_reviews_text: I had no idea what this was. My 21 year old son requested this for Christmas. After he installed it and showed us how it works... the entire family waits their turn to play!!! I suggest buying at least one additional sensor for best gaming. I purchased a third sensor not realizing it came with two. GLAD I DID!!! When turning away from a sensor, you can experience blind spots because the computer doesn't see your controllers. The extra sensors remove any blind spots. My son also purchased additional length cables since the purchase of the original system. YOU WILL LOVE THIS GAME SYSTEM!!!!!

one_reviews_text: It's best to hook them up, set up your room & sensors then let the thing update for a few hours depending on your internet and PC speeds. If you can afford a third & fourth sensor and a couple USB extension cable you will have limitless fun. Stay away from free games, most of them just suck. Try to avoid games with less than 70% positive reviews 'cause bad games with constant glitches & crashes will ruin the experience & take up valuable hard drive space. Wait for a good sale or just save up an extra week & get the apps that will bring you, your friends & family pleasure. Once you learn to accept these realities you can then change your reality in VR

one_reviews_text: I have enjoyed my experiences in VR since purchasing the Oculus Rift.  It is definitely still a bit of an infant technology, with most games and applications being little more than tech. demos that showcase the potential of VR, but those tech. demo experiences are insanely immersive.  I was far more impressed with the experience than I expected to be.All that being said, I seem to have a rather wide head and I wear glasses.  This presented some difficulties for me as most of my glasses simply do not fit inside the headset.  Unfortunately my vision is poor enough that not using corrective lenses is simply not an option for me.  I have a pair of glasses that are somewhat more narrow than others, but they barely fit inside the headset and I don't find the experience particularly comfortable, especially since these narrow frames already tend to ride a bit tight on my face.  When removing the headset, the glasses are lodged inside and come off with it.  This also presents the possibility of the glasses scratching the rather sensitive lenses inside the headset, which is always a concern when dislodging them from the headset.Moving on, the setup was fairly simple even though I did have to purchase a USB 3.0 PCIe card and a DVI-to-HDMI adapter to satisfy the required number of ports on my PC and allow me to leave my monitor plugged in.I do not have a lot of room, and I live in the upstairs of a very oddly shaped house (geodesic dome) so I have sloped, angular walls.  Despite this I was able to clear a small space of about 6x6 for use with the headset, but I do have to be very cautious of my boundaries so as not to hit my head and hands into the walls.  I do recommend clearing a larger space for use with this system.  Many of the experiences just can't be played in such a small area, such as the Rick and Morty VR game, which can be disappointing when you find one that you'd like to try but don't have the room for it.  Also be wary that wherever you are using this, the cable will be tethered to a device on your head and your, rather expensive if it's capable of running this device, PC.  Do not use in a high traffic area and sequester your pets and children before use.The Touch controllers are rather impressive, tracking hand motion accurately and even detecting when individual fingers are lifted off of them or gripped around them.  I found these to be one of the most impressive parts of the entire package.Overall I HIGHLY recommend experiencing VR to anyone and everyone.  Though it is still a new technology, the potential for some of the most amazing experiences you've ever had in the comfort of your home is through the roof.  In the coming years, this technology will only get better.  Imagine lighter, wireless headsets, with higher resolution displays, with adjustable corrective lenses built into the unit (one of the competitors offers this, but it does not support my prescription strength and is a unit for true hardcore techies- not for the newbie).The support for users with corrective lenses is insufficient, which is the only reason I knocked off a star, but if you've got good eyesight and/or contacts/laser corrected vision, you definitely want one of these.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2017
review_title: You need a lot of room, and be wary if you wear glasses- find a unit to try out locally before buying.

one_reviews_text: One of the controllers that came with my Rift was dead, so Amazon sent me another pair. I was pretty impressed by that, and it's just another reason to be a loyal Amazon customer. Oculus would have made me send it in then wait and wait for it to be fixed and who wants to do that when they just got a shiny new toy?! So Amazon was great.The controllers are incredible. Not only do they know when and were you are touching them, they know when you aren't as well. These things are quite intuitive, and it only takes a minute to figure out how to use them. There is a lot going on when you're in VR, you're getting a lot of data moving very quickly and having to fumble with the controllers would really break the coveted 'immersion'. These things deliver, I have zero complaints about them. They are brilliant.The only suggestion I might make would be to make them rechargeable, but that's really not a huge deal. I use rechargeable batteries in them anyway, and properly charged bats will last about a month. So it's really not a big deal.I strongly recommend using the wrist straps! If you don't, you have a 100% chance of eventually throwing your brand new, technologically advanced controller across the room. So just use the strap, lol
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2019

one_reviews_text: This came in this fancy box and all polished even though after a week of wall punching it looked more like my chins after a scooter whiped around and hit them. After the initial wow moment wore off I had a moment of buyers remorse until I bought Onward and Pavlov, both amazing games. While it should come with three sensors (2 for 360 degree and one on the floor so I can drop to the floor when I'm getting shot at) its fine if you get a combo of third sensor and USB extender. The overall look of it can bother some people, it does have god rays (whites really pop) and it does have the screen door effect. In the oculus software they make it really hard to boost the resolution above around 1500 and when in SteamVR you can scale up the resolution to almost 4K for both eyes. The screen door effect is then gone but the god rays only have 1 solution which is anti fog but they are still there even with that. The screen door effect is mainly caused by this being not meant for 2000$ systems and trying to get VR to the main stream so they made it optimized, so if you have a good enough PC go for 4K super scale. The tracking is worse then the vive but it is still amazing. The games are pretty great except for the fact that the singleplayer games are really short but multiplayer will get a ton of time from me. Everything flows and even with my 970 I feel like I have a equal experience to a Titan X. I have had a great time with my oculus and plan to keep using it on the regular.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2018

one_reviews_text: I already had the two sensors that are included with the Rift and Touch controllers, which work well, but you really need the third sensor to get a great setup for room scale. The third sensor takes care of any blind spots and lets you move around very easily within your space for the newer room scale games that are coming out (which there are more and more of lately).

one_reviews_text: The Rift is great. I didn't have any trouble with set up on the computer, but I did have to buy more ports because of the number of devices that need to be plugged in (PCI-E to Type C and Type A USB). Also, be ready to figure out how you'll free up the space in your house (apprx a 7 x 7 area is good).I like it much better than the HTC Vive because it is lighter and the hand controllers feel much more natural and comfortable in my hands. I use the 3 sensor set up which greatly improves the 360 degree experience. VR technology still has a long way to go and I'm looking forward to improvements in resolution. All told, this purchase was well worth it.

one_reviews_text: Its an Oculus sensor. It works with the Oculus rift (No, it does not work with Oculus Quest or Oculus Rift-S). They provided an extra long USB 2.0 extension cable with the package. Note that will make it impossible for USB 3.0 so if you want or desire a higher speed tracking get your own USB 3.0 extension cable. Despite it being USB 2.0 I do not have tracking issues, however I'd recommend getting a 4th sensor for the opposite corner of your room, or configure the sensors in a Y pattern for full back coverage and go against the recommended L pattern Oculus recommends in the setup.

one_reviews_text: This thing is wonderful. Just make sure you have a lot of space and if at all possible try it out before you buy it, and try a number of different games with different "comfort levels" and locomotion styles. This is so you can guage how succeptible you are to motion sickness. If it turns out you get motion sick easily you will be very limited in game selection and your rift may end up being a paperweight.At first the image will seem blurry compared to looking at a monitor and pixels will be apparent (often referred to as the screen door effect), but once you get engaged in playing a game that all fades away and it becomes incredibly immersive.If you are trying to decide between this and the Vive, here are the key factors that won me over:The controllers are just excellent. Very well designed and comfortable. The vive wands really don't appeal to me.Oculus has a number of games which cannot be played on Vive because the vive wands have fewer inputs than the oculus touch controllers. Meanwhile most vive games can be played on oculus (the ones that can't are mostly because vive has a larger maximum playspace, I can barely make room for my oculus as it is though).The oculus headset is lighter and less bulky than the vive headset.Oculus bundle is 100 bucks cheaper! But you need to get a third sensor for 360 degree room-scale with the oculus so it's not that much cheaper.Here are some games I've tried myself that I would highly recommend, depending on your comfort level:Lone Echo, Beat Saber, Elite Dangerous (HOTAS recommended), job simulator, robo recall, brass tactics, superhotOne more thing, I had a lot of trouble setting up my sensors for 360 degree room scale play because the setup wizard doesn't give a very good explanation. So here's a tip to help you out: your three sensors should be arranged in a right triangle, so that the front two sensors are to the right and left of the display in the diagram and your third sensor is straight back from either the right or left sensor. Oh also, I had trouble with the oculus software detecting all of my sensors and the headset properly. What worked for me was plugging all the sensors into USB 2.0 ports that are on separate controllers on the motherboard, and plugging the headset into a 3.0 slot. For some reason none of the sensors worked plugged into 3.0 slots and their data bandwidth is too high to share 2.0 controllers.Final thoughts:now that oculus has hand presence and room scale as well as a number of high quality games to play I feel like we are past the early adopter phase and I would highly recommend it to any game enthusiast with a powerful computer and a lot of patience and willingness to troubleshoot for hours. Also sharing the VR experience with your friends and family is great fun.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2018

one_reviews_text: I purchased a VR ready PC previously, so setup was a breeze. I don't have enough room for a room scale setup and this system works great. I was able to find a program (VorpX) that let me run 3D applications (like Skyrim and Borderlands 2). The touch controllers are comfortable and work with most applications  without any real setup. It works far better than my dad's Gear VR for his Note 8, but not quite as good as my friend's Vive. It has an onboard microphone and the included speakers were surprisingly good (a relief as they would be trickly to replace). A great deal in cost versus application

one_reviews_text: Adding a third sensor to your Rift setup eliminates most occlusion issues (i.e. when you're body blocks the view of a controller from the sensor), but it isn't immediately noticeable depending on how the other two sensors were setup previously. It goes from good to pretty much perfect roomscale tracking.Each sensor tracks up to about 3m before the quality starts to degrade (controllers/headset appear to wobble a bit after 3m), so an ideal Rift VR space using three sensors would be about 3x3m, but it can be stretched up to about 4x4m. Of course, it works in smaller spaces perfectly fine too.It also comes with a 16ft active USB 2.0 extension cable, so the cable is long enough to be out of the way after setting it up.

one_reviews_text: I'm happy to review this.  I personally think this is the best VR device.  It works a little unusually, (acts as a very unique display) but it's very authoritative about it's presence in your drivers and working with NVIDIA.  It has a great amount of compatibility and I find it able to run without -any- fuss.  The community is special.  Very kind and friendly.  The staff is very personable and interested.  The display is great, if you have enough power, you can make games look super crisp using Oculus Tray Tools.  It's not blurry as older systems or as some people may claim.  A couple of precautions:  Alot of vid cards that claim to be VR ready, only have one HDMI port.  Make sure your monitor has an adapter or use a different cable.  Just make sure you can accommodate both monitor and rift.  Add it to your order, you will thank me.  Nvidia 1060 is as low as I would go for graphics card.  It will work fine on that if you have a great CPU.  You will not be able to "squeak by" very well, and I pull for trying to.  VR games this year have been a little lacking, so if you want to take a year and upgrade your computer, that's a good idea.  You aren't missing anything incredible just yet.  It's just important your hardware can handle it.  I personally love it to pieces and I think it's great and I love the controllers.  They seem to have more resolution than my pen tablet which is awesome.

one_reviews_text: It's actually quite impressive how durable these controllers are. I've accidentally punched quite a few objects in real life while using these controllers, and they still function perfectly. Props to Oculus for anticipating that these controllers might get roughed up a bit during normal use and making them sturdy enough to withstand that sort of abuse.Functionality-wise, I can't recommend these controllers enough. If you have a Rift, the Touch controls are a must-have. Pretty much every decent game I've played requires them, and I don't think I'd use my Rift much at all if I didn't have these controllers.

one_reviews_text: I'm changing my past review as I was mistaken about USB 2.0 and 3.0 for a 3rd Oculus Sensor. USB 3.0 is better for the Oculus Sensor than USB 2.0. However, the Oculus manual says that you shouldn't have more than two sensors running with a 3.0 USB port at a given time. Thus, if you connect your two main sensors and this third sensor on 3.0, your sensors will not function properly. Having your third (rear) camera on 2.0 will work properly. I learned this the hard way. Keep in mind to ensure that your third sensor is no further than about 10-12 feet away from your front sensors.

one_reviews_text: II feel like I’ve been waiting for VR since the early 90’s when 3d accelerated games were taking over. It Just seemed like VR was the next obvious step. Well, it took another 20 years but we are finally there and so far I’m pretty happy with the technology.It takes a pretty powerful PC to push the Rift but, but not excessively so considering this is a niche market item at this point. The system pushes a lot of pixels to the small monitors in the unit but still you can easily see that VR in the future will need even more to rival smoothness of a high res desktop display. Presumably this experience is related to the fact that the VR simulated environment is covering almost all of your field of vision as opposed to just a small part of it like a monitor would.The price is a little steep relative to most gaming gear but, it's cutting edge. The price will come down. It's an early adopter product at this point but i have to say that as far as early adopter gear goes, it's been surprisingly robust. Pretty reliable software and a pretty polished product. The responsiveness of turning your head and immediately having the environment respond is impressive. I can’t detect any kind of lag. The unit is reasonably light, but does run a little warm. I almost always have the ceiling fan running when using it because I get warm.I haven’t experience any discomfort that related to motion in the games which seems to be pretty subjective. But so far I seem impervious.I’m an adult gamer so I only have a few hours to play but so far the Oculus (and their exclusive games) have been compelling. Kittypocalypse, Chronos and Project Cars have been my favorites. It’s impressive to see the variety of games on the system and to see that it’s not just first person shooters.Negatives:The only things that I don’t like are that Oculus made their own store. I can understand why they would have wanted to do that, but I hate buying games from a different place than all of my other games (Steam). Steam games do work on Oculus, but launching them is clumsy requiring you to take off the head set.

one_reviews_text: The Oculus Rift is an extraordinary virtual reality HMD that provides a stellar gaming and media experience.  However, in my time owning one I have come across a few road blocks.-USB Bandwidth  This is completely dependent on the power of your PC's USB 2.0 and 3.0 chips.I found that I had to plug my sensors into an external USB 3.0 A/C powered hub before I could play without issue.-Oculus Home SoftwareWhile playing in VR, be sure to occasionally monitor your resource usage in task manager, for some applications will bottleneck and cause Oculus Home to crash and restart, which more often than not, interrupts gameplay and causes a restart.  On some occasions, you can overload your GPU and cause your monitor AND headset to both black out for anywhere from seconds to minutes.  Remember that VR is very much still in development, and the way it interacts with your PC could be different than another.  That being said, always make sure you are following Oculus' guidelines on minimum specs.  (At times, this can be lifted for USB usage, for both the sensors AND the headset function on USB 2.0)Overall, the Oculus is not a flawless system.  The facial interface padding can often get hair caught in it, or build up sweat during intense gameplay. The onboard headphones included are rather prone to breakages in the plastic joints that keep them together.  Visually, after trying the WMR, Vive, and Oculus, I much prefer the rift as it gives you a crystal clear image with minimal screen door effect as well as providing a far wider sweet spot in clear sight as opposed to something like a WMR headset.As far as tracking quality goes, I do recommend investing the extra $60 ( as of February, 2019 ) into a third sensor.  This sets you free in the sense that you are able to play in a 360° space, rather than a forward facing environment.My summary on the headset is that it easily compares with the HTC Vive and can compete with its similar quality of experience as well as a price of $350 ( Again as of Feb 2019 ).  If you enjoy the concept of Full Body Tracking however, I would recommend that you give the HTC Vive a look-see as currently there is no such support on the Rift unless you're looking to drop $600 USD on the Light-house sensors and Vive Trackers. (Yes, you, VRChat user.)Otherwise, give this bad boy a spin.  Though it has its flaws, it has served me well thus far and I hope others will be able to enjoy it.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 25, 2019

one_reviews_text: This thing is radical departure from the everyday. The environments are very convincing, not perfectly authentic to the real world, but close enough for you to lose yourself. No nausea at all. Robo Recall is tremendous fun, and challenging. Raw Data is even more challenging. The downside is set-up--it takes about 10 minutes to arrange & calibrate everything from scratch. If you have a dedicated space for VR, that would be ideal & speed things up a bit. The cables are also a drag, but the new systems take care of that.  Build quality is excellent. I'm running this on an Alienware i7 with 8GB RAM & a GeForce 1080, so power hasn't been an issue.  The upside of course is that this will allow you to experience things that would be otherwise impossible. Travel the world. Travel in time. The technology isn't seamless & transparent yet, but it's good enough to invest in now.

one_reviews_text: This system is amazing.However, I have had it for about 7 months now and there is one major problem that I have noticed.The sound in the left speaker started to break up. Then it went out completely. I did send it in for warranty work. Customer service has been great so far. I say so far because the air freight company that handles UPS shipments here in Alaska has managed to lose my package. So it has not made it in to Oculus yet. Not the fault of Oculus, but there is more to the story.I have two units. I was playing Beat Saber last night, and sure enough the sound in the left ear is starting to crackle and cut out. My research of this problem reveals that this is a common problem with the unit. The sound for the unit comes out of the HMD on the right, goes to the right speaker, and then proceeds around the back of the HMD headband to the left speaker. Seems that the problem is in that passage around the back.I will most likely remain a Oculus user, but in the future I will most likely remove the speakers from their mounts and route the cables for my Turtle Beach Elite Pro headphones along with the Rift cables and use the TB headphones for sound and mic.Oculus, please find a fix.

review_title: This is an amazing product at a great price right now

one_reviews_text: Let me start by saying- I only have a GTX 1050 Ti and have not had any issues or lag in any game relating to FPS or graphics. I recommend you have a gtx 960 or above, but I have not had many issues.I have owned this product for about a month and I love it.There are so many things I love about this product but let me say this now.DO NOT BUY THE VIVE IF YOU ARE ON SOME SORT OF BUDGET!Let me run down the reasons of why I love this product, then I will get to why you shouldn't buy the HTC Vive over the Oculus Rift.-Great community with friendly people.-Touch controllers are great and ergonomic.-So many free games that will keep you playing for hours.-Comfortable on head, even if it gets a little hot.-Very adjustable.-Headphones are very nice and sound great.-Support is pretty good.Alright, here are some things to keep in mind.-If your headphones stop working, use the included screwdriver thingy to tighten them and you should be good.-Submit a support ticket as soon as you have an issue to make sure you can get a replacement.-There are tons of free games, so don't feel the need to buy a ton of extra games.-A third sensor will give you 360 degree tracking and roomscale, but it is $60.-If you have 2 sensors, mount one looking forward at medium-high level and one on a stand face slightly downwards to get coverage of the floor.-Make sure you face your sensors while playing games so you don't have immersion-breaking experiences.Why not to buy the Vive?Things that the Vive offers over the oculus--Better tracking out of the box-Better steam supportThings that Oculus offers over the Vive--$200 cheaper-Better controllers-More games including some great Oculus exclusives.-Comes with built in Headphones-Still works fine with SteamVRIt's up to you, but the Oculus is my clear winner.This amazing product will keep you twisting and turning for hours.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2018

one_reviews_text: I'm not really sure where to begin on a review of this. The rift is a very good system. It tracks well, and gives you some amazing visuals. I've enjoyed playing standing VR games, as well as some games that are simply enhanced by VR and all are better for it. Elite Dangerous is amazing when coupled with VR. Everything feels like solid construction, and the set up is easy. It's a comfortable headset that I've worn for hours at a time when in a gaming session.All I can really say is I highly recommend it.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2017

one_reviews_text: Of course having a virtual reality headset is cool but it is easy to get annoyed and sick of it. My computer easily runs the games and handles the headset but for some reason things still crash, and at first the vr seems really trippy and weird but then like anything your body gets used to it and it dosent feel different or cool anymore.  Also the lenses of the headset constantly get foggy and dirty so you have to constantly clean them, and lastly it easily strains your eyes which alone reduces the amount of time you can actually use it.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2019
review_title: Cool but over time has problems

one_reviews_text: I bought the Oculus Rift a few weeks ago and I only have great things to say about it so far. I will say this though. BUY A THIRD SENSOR. It transforms the experience because once you make it 360 degrees with roomscale shooting zombies, or playing games like robo recall where you actually have to turn around become even more amazing. Something to keep in mind with the set up, watch what kind of lights you use, small lights like Christmas lights will mess with the sensors and you will have tracking issues. I would also suggest getting a replacement headpiece, the one it comes with is fine, but does collect sweat. You can buy a rubber one you can clean with anti bacterial wipes for 30-40 if this is an issue for you. I have only good things to say about this, get one.a
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2017
review_title: ... Rift a few weeks ago and I only have great things to say about it so far

one_reviews_text: Had an ok time when it did work as expected.  It is pretty bad at first getting use to looking at everything through a weird screen door effect, but you get use to that.  However it's near impossible to get a clear image through the full field of view.  The sensors and touch controllers were incredibly finicky with which USB 3.0 ports they'd work on.  Eventually, one of my controllers stopped pairing all together.Do not buy.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2018

one_reviews_text: I tried to temper my expectations because VR tech is still new, but the experience is more polished than I thought it would be. I do feel a sense of immersion, but what I especially enjoy are the small details: the "guardian system" which displays a transparent wall around your play area to help prevent you from bumping into things, and the fact that you can see the location of your controllers even when they are not in your hands (so that you can just reach out and pick them up off your desk). The technology has already come a long way and I can't wait to experience future generations of the Rift.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2017

one_reviews_text: Great product lots of fun but make sure you have the gardian system set up right you will walk into stuff if you don't. Only negative is my left earphone arrived not working. Yes I switched them to make sure it was the actual earphone and not the headset. Oculus customer support is the worst I have ever dealt with!!!! Don't be shocked when after dealing with multiple reps and supplying them with what they asked for they send another email saying sorry we still have to review your situation 10 days and counting. Also no phone number to actually talk to someone.Edit: they sent me a new head phones last week.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2019

one_reviews_text: Oh my goodness! Today is my son’s birthday and this is the only thing he asked for. I have been miserable sick with a sinus infection and waited until almost the last minute to order. To have this item guaranteed to deliver by today would’ve cost an additional $120+ in shipping...which I couldn’t afford. I placed the order with the next inexpensive shipping cost which would have the package delivered somewhere between May 2 -7 which he understood although he was hoping to have it for his actual birthday day. Well FedEx just dropped the package off and I’m gonna have one super excited 13 year-old! Thank you so much for getting our order out to us so quickly. You have no idea what this means to my son but also to me. As a widowed mom, I tend to want to give everything I possibly can to my son and you have helped make this possible. Thank you from the bottom of my heart.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 1, 2019
review_title: Superb Vendor! Highly recommend you order from them!

one_reviews_text: The controllers feel amazing, and the batteries are replaceable with external rechargeable AA's.My friend's year old vive controllers die every  4-5 hours of game play and require recharging.The batteries also last forever, idk how. If you turn vibration off the batteries only need to be changed monthly.Headset is lightweight, easy to setup.I got an extra sensor (3 total) and an 8ft cube of room scale VR.vive controller emulator allows me to play vive exclusive games (fallout4).This thing is kick ass. great price.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2018

one_reviews_text: We LOVE this VR system! Once we got it up and running we were amazed with just the little intro game "First Contact". I did run into some issues with installation but I think it was the fact that my laptop had some bad drivers. After trying everything that came up in the forums, the last option was to do a full factory reset and reinstall windows. Since my laptop has 2 drives (SSD for the OS and a 1TB HDD for storage) this was not a big deal. After a fresh install of windows and re-installation of the Oculus software, we were up and running in under 10 mins.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2018

one_reviews_text: didn't even have this 1 month, already speaking with Oculus Support. Left Lens has failed. Oculus Tech support is a Joke or is the worst I have seen with ANY product.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 28, 2018
review_title: Oculus Tech support is a Joke or is the worst I have seen with ANY product

one_reviews_text: Literally the best gaming experience I have ever had. I have spent my entire life playing video games, and I've never before used something so intuitive and fluid. VR is finally here, and the tech is up to par. Half of the time, I feel like I'm really there because I'm so immerssed.The only drawback of the Rift and Vive systems respectively is the PC required for usage.Setting up the rift was fine, and just as easy as I think Oculus had intended it to be: streamlined and simple. The room mapping with the Guardian line thing was odd to set up at first, but I just think I didn't read the instructions all the way.With all of the tech you get in the box, (Rift Headset, Touch Controllers, and two sensors,) the rift also comes with 6 games. Among them, Robo Recall, Quill, and Medium are my favorites. I purchased SUPERHOT VR and Lone Echo ( which is the best oculus first party game, and an insanely good game on it's own. If you're thinking of picking up a Rift get that game.The reason most people go to Oculus for the games is the price. For $400, (or $380, $350 depending on the sale prices) you get A LOT. before, paying $800 or even $600 as the price of the HTC vive right now, it isn't really worth it, considering that I'd the price of most gaming PC rigs.If you're gonna buy a VR Headset, get the Rift. For the money, you get the same experience as the HTC Vive, but for cheaper, and executed better. The build quality and comfort on the Vive is minimal compared to the Rift, too.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2017
review_title: Oculus Rift: The Best VR headset for the money

one_reviews_text: The Rift system is awesome for us. Bit the Oculus software has issuesSo far I had issues with buying games as the query failsThe updates have made it stop working and has to be repaired to be used again takes a long time to repairHowever when the 4 free games wouldn't show up I contacted Oculus support using email and after they investigated it I was promptly fixed after I sent all info they needed.Great service so far and love the Oculus system.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2019

one_reviews_text: It's a little techie to set up and use.  Need a computer that can handle VR.  Did not work at first until I figured out yo unneeded an HMDI cable from your monitor to the graphics card. I suppose a techie may say that was obvious but it wasn't to me.  Totally transforms you not a new space.  Some of the games are tweaking but they are getting better. Can't really compare it to the competition--not techie enough to know what else is out there, but this is a blast.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 3, 2018

one_reviews_text: The setup process is finicky and somewhat counter-intuitive but the again so was the original two sensor setup. This can be a little more aggravating though as it seems that the setup process occasionally wants you to place the sensor in an area or facing in a direction that may be obscured. I suppose the best option is of course to have as much open space as possible. That being said, tracking is much improved and not be tethered to the forward facing setup in games is great. A must have for those Oculus owners who have the play space.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 7, 2018
review_title: Needed for the Full Oculus Experience, Setup Can be a Pain

one_reviews_text: Really comfortable gestures and controls with these controllers. Its a natural grip that doesn't fatigue your hands. The display is better than vive in my opinion. It has more clarity. Ive had this device for nearly a year and it still works perfect. Clean the lenses with a dry glasses lens cloth or dampen it with one sprits of lens cleaner. (I am not responsible if you ruin your product because you destroy it with lens cleaner lol). Super easy to set up and is lightweight.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2019

one_reviews_text: Honestly I recommend these headphones over the originals. My right ear phone went out and an original replacement was way more expensive. these are not only cheaper and install instantly but they convey better sound. Additionally they make the headset cooler because you no longer have large headphones covering your ears. If you prefer ear buds over earphones I highly recommend making the switch.
