one_reviews_text: Wow this product is absolutely amazing. I have tried the oculus go and a few other vr sets and the rift is the best one by far compared to any other I have tried. So far I have had no issues with it other than a few glitches here and there in game play but I just have to close out the game and reopen and its totally fine. I would recommend to get some lens protectors especially if you have glasses and keep a fan on when playing. Kinda wish they put a cooling foam around the headset cause the foam they use is not great and I over heat. But I will say quality of game play is amazing and would recommend for sure.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 13, 2018

one_reviews_text: First off; these controllers are incredible. At first I got my Rift for seating sim experiences. Always thought motion control would never be my thing. So a friend brought his touch controllers and then I immediately bought my own. They absolutely change the experience in a way that has to be tried to be understood.Though, I wouldn't give this 5 stars just yet. Right now Oculus tracking has issues. 360 tracking and roomscale requires a 3rd sensor and you might have USB issues causing you to buy more stuff to get it working! It's finicky and difficult to setup. BUT when it is set up; it exceeds the Vive experience by a long shot. Vive wands simply lack the comfort and  immersion that these controllers give you.I will only recommend these and give a 5 star review IF Oculus gets their 360 and roomscale tracking sorted out
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2017

one_reviews_text: There aren't many things that make me eager to write a review but this Oculus Rift is by far the greatest piece of technology I have EVER owned.Since it's inception and the subsequent kickstarter by Palmer Lucky I was blown away by the very idea of Virtual Reality. It seemed like something right out of the sci fi movies we all grew up loving and I just had to have it...then came the $600 headset minus the (then) incomplete touch controllers at an additional $200. On top of that I would need at least a $1k pc to run it, the cumulative cost of it all shelved my immediate dream of owning a rift.Then came the sale.At $400 THIS IS A STEAL.Make no mistake about it, at HALF the price it was originally with the touch controllers: this is the best value for money that you can get a complete, professional V.R. experience and believe me it is sooo worth it.The Vive may have better roomscale tracking but its not worth the $200 difference (previously $400 but Vive realized the price diff was suicide)as I have great roomscale with my 2 sensors mounted at opposite corners of my play area and prefer the (slightly) better screen clarity, much more comfortable weight and the single neat cable that runs to the HMD itself. Another win is that the Oculus has access to all the Vive game without the need for any hacks or tech savvy (just download steam vr)All in all, if its archery practice, checking out the solar system or killing rogue robots, I am able to completely immerse myself in other worlds as well as my own (Google earth VR is amazing) VR is the future....right now and there is no better time to get on board.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2017
review_title: By FAR the greatest experience in gaming and not just...

one_reviews_text: This system works much better than I expected.  The immersion is beyond belief and even though you know it's just virtual, it's very hard to step off a virtual cliff.  I'm using a GTX 1080 card, and there is no detectable lag from head movement to image update, so there is no motion sickness. (or VR sickness.)  In my old age, I tend to be more sensitive to that than other people.  I'm an EE, and I'm amazed they can track head movement to such a fine resolution.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2018

one_reviews_text: Oculus nailed it. I didn't realize how incomplete the Rift was until I got the Touch controllers. I've been gaming since I got my first Apple ][ in 1978 and dreaming of VR since I went to work in the CAD industry in 1980. I've lost interest in CGI stuff for the last 10 years or so but the Oculus products have opened up a brand new experience for me.The setup was easy. The tutorial with the robot and the virtual 3D printer was awesome. There were butterflies everywhere. 8}  I can now free up the USB slot from the XBOX controller.My main problem is that I need to rearrange my cozy computer room to get at least a 7x7 play area. Then the decision has to be made to get one or two more controllers, though in my current 5x5 play area I don't really need them.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2016

one_reviews_text: Speaking as a VR skeptic: the Oculus Rift is by far the most exciting thing to happen to gaming this decade! It is 100% worth the price! This package comes with two touch controllers and two sensors, including the headset and all required cables. You can set this up in 30 minutes and get to playing fast. The touch controllers net you 6 free games, including Robo Recall which is an amazing title and possibly the best VR game to date! I recommend looking into a VR headset cover for the facial foam. The base model tends to pick up a lot of sweat and get gross unless you clean it thoroughly. A cover will help with this.

one_reviews_text: An eye opening experience, i'm not kidding. It brings depth to something that never truly had it before and drags you into another world. I put this thing on for the first time and was blown away. Its not something you can see by looking at your computer screen, you have to actually experience it with VR. The best way i could describe it is by compairing it to the first time i drove a car. The controllers drag you in even more, they feel perfect and i've beat mine up a few times on the dresser ... literally not a scratch on the controller haha.

one_reviews_text: Pro's: very lightweight, very comfortable, easy to adjust to your head and the touch controllers are very accurate lightweight.the whole system feels like a very polished product was also very easy to set up. The controllers also seem VERY low on battery consumption. i played for about 6 hours straight on robo recall on the day i recieved this and the battery indicators have yet to even move down a notch.Cons: controllers take just a standard AA battery i would probably invest in rechargeable AA's. the foam padding is a concern because the front of my face gets a little muggy inside of the rift head set when playing a game that gets a bit intense. the padding insert is removable for cleaning but still a little of a hassle, would like to see a 3'rd party or even name brand smooth non absorbent silicone option or something like that.  if you pc game with steam as your platform it is compleatly supported by steam it just takes a bit of research to get steam Vr running on it.overall this i do not regret this purchase one bit. my complaints are practically negligible. out of all of the VR options out there this one is definitely the most polished i highly recommend it, the touch controllers is what really sold me on it they have a much more immersive feel and are closer to the natural positioning of your hands in real life vs waving around a couple big sticks like the psvr or vive. also if you're like me and you live in a small apartment this is a much more practical option for the best experience possible.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2017
review_title: very comfortable, easy to adjust to your head and the ...

one_reviews_text: I like this headset.  The setup was easy.  I only put the sensors on my desk and they work great.  Sometimes the tracking is off, but apparently I can set them up differently to get better tracking.  I have to experiment.  Oculus says on their website to space them apart at separate sides of the room so that one is always facing the headset.  But I haven't tried that yet.  I subtracted a star because I am getting some really bad light artifacts from the lenses.  At first I thought that it was just the game itself, but now I'm sure it's from the lenses.  It's like the lenses were designed to get rid of the barndoor effect, which is not visible, but then caused huge light artifacts, like glare or sun rays, to appear.  This causes dark scenes with bright objects to have some severe light streaks.  This is somewhat annoying and distracting for me.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 16, 2017

one_reviews_text: VR is really amazing! I enjoyed the Oculus Rift for the short time I owned it. I really enjoyed the immersion and the first contact demo had me smiling and screaming like a little kid again! However, I had to return them because it was just too uncomfortable with my glasses. My glasses are around 140mm wide which are just under the recommend 142mm width of glasses that Oculus recommends. While I was able to get the Rift to fit over my glasses by putting the headset on from front to back it was just too uncomfortable for me. My parents were able to use it comfortably because they have much smaller glasses than me. My Dad has big retro plastic glasses and was comfortable but his glasses are not as wide as mine.So, I highly recommend the Oculus Rift to anyone with no glasses, contacts, or glasses under 140mm wide. I highly recommend buying from Amazon only and not a third party seller since Amazon has an awesome return policy. While a third party seller should honor returns since they have to follow Amazon rules it is just peace of mind to know Amazon wont question you whatsoever!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 19, 2017

one_reviews_text: If you're up for the steep price, this thing is amazing! Transports you anywhere in the world. You feel like you're really there, even in impossible places like the top of the Eiffel Tower! However, be careful and maintain this product well. It has some cords and doodads and gadgets, and it helps if you know what you're doing. This is a toy, but a very expensive toy.  Well worth the money.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2019

one_reviews_text: Totally worth it. So much immersion. If you have a system that can run this, which I would definitely double check, but this. Also better deal than the vive right now. The controllers also fit just like a glove (in the sense that they just feel so natural to hold). The headset is of course not full hd, so there will be some pixelation but not enough to ruin the immersion. The vive does have their newer headset that does have hd resolution but for a whopping 1100$. This is a way better deal and a steal.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 17, 2018
review_title: A better deal than the vice right now

one_reviews_text: I got this a couple weeks ago and I've been having a blast playing the included robo recall, medium, and free steam vr games. I also recommend you pick up super hot vr. When I put it on and adjusted it I was a little let down by the image and the perceived point of view, but once I got into a game it all faded away and I was left with an amazing experience! The display is smooth, the controllers are responsive and comfortable, and the setup was pretty painless. I would definitely recommend you use the Oculus compatibility check from their website and run the steam vr benchmark. The Oculus requires 3 USB 3.0 or above ports and an open HDMI port so make sure you have those, I had to use the two 3.0 on the front and one on the back to get it all connected. Additionally for "improved" tracking for 360 room scale they recommend a third sensor, but I haven't had any issue with putting the sensors at opposite corners of my play area (~2mx2m ) it'll give you an error during setup about the sensors being too far apart but just click next anyway and it'll let you continue setup.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2017
review_title: Truly an experience you must have!

one_reviews_text: I have both the Oculus Rift and the Oculus Go and I can say they are both great products at a great price. I originally purchased the Oculus Go and was hesitant on purchasing the Rift because I thought it would be hard to set up. But any gamer should have no trouble. I am using it on the MSI GS65 Stealth laptop and it works great. Highly recommend.

one_reviews_text: All in all everything is ok and is fun to use the only downside is that the cable that plugs in your hdmi that then goes to your headset is faulty. The cord was pinched winched causes it to stop working during gameplay and mess with the wire till the video comes back for maybe 20-40 minutes. Which oculus doesn't sell the replacement cable on there site so I had to spend an extra 150 dollars to buy a replacement. one_reviews_text: The experience is so surreal. I didn't expect to be so immersed but I was wrong. The trackers do an incredible job tracking every movement with no lag what-so-ever. They're also easy to setup and isn't picky about their placements. I live in a small apartment and my room is quite tiny so if I can set it up without fuss, then anyone should be able to as well. Just be careful, you can easily lose yourself in the VR and forget where you are unaware of your surroundings.

one_reviews_text: Returned this twice.  We researched the right laptop specs and bought what we thought was a compatible computer.  Had a blank screen on the first one.  Couldn't not get a response from "tech support."  We were advised to look at the posted messages for a fix.  Really?????  Return the first one.  Same blank screen.  We did a reboot of the computer, updated the graphics card..... we tried every suggestion we found on the boards.  We even had Amazon help call us twice to trouble shoot.  Finally decided to return the hunk of plastic.  How do you put out a product with very new technology and offer no tech support?

one_reviews_text: Before buying this, i had very high expectations. They were exceed by far.I was expecting some gimmick effect, like you have to put some effort to feel it real... but the inmersion is real and it feels incredible. No lag, no latency, you can look around, move,peek around a corner, etc. (Of course you need a high end PC). When you interact with other persons, you feel like they are really there. The inmersion is so real that you can feel sick with fast motions or playing for too much time.Im in my 30s, for my this is like the first time i played nintendo, or the first time i connected to internet. This is a game changer, the next step on entertaiment.There are very great games for free in the store, and some apps only for visual experiences.If i have to name a bad thing, i think is the lack of people for some great multiplayer games, especially those that are not free.Overall, i totally recommend this product, is true that is in some early stage and the amount of games and apps are limited, but the possibilities are endless, i cant wait to know what the future hold for this technology.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 30, 2017

one_reviews_text: VR in 2019 should not be this expensive, not when the headset is nearly as old as Xbox one. That said, the experience is definitely worth every penny. My one complaint is that the sensor cords are way too short for a room setup. I had to use extension cables, which caused the sensors to drop out of connection whenever they feel like it.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2019
review_title: The experience is worth it, but the cable management/extension is a big headache

one_reviews_text: My initial excitement for this product immediately disappeared as soon as I discovered the impossibility of even installing the basic software to run this piece of abandonware. Despite my best efforts, the driver installer simply COULD NOT connect to the Oculus server, rendering this product unusable. The lack of tech support, combined with the fact that this problem is apparently extremely common with this device, which unbeknownst to me has not been remedied by Oculus despite enduring years of complaints by Oculus owners, completely turned me off from this product. I regret wasting my time trying to get this hunk of junk to work. What should be a fun, plug and play experience is instead rendered into a not-so-fun slog through the byzantine third party tech support tutorials. What a disappointment, hard pass.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2019

one_reviews_text: Got this as a third sensor in the back for my Oculus. It comes with an extender cable which provides plenty of room for me to place it behind me when using the Oculus.  These are a little pricey, but I believe you need the 3 sensors to really immerse yourself.  Without the third sensor, it is easy for the headset to drop out when turning your head too far in one direction.  At least it was for me, but that may be my own fault with how I have the front sensors.

Very hard to tell A and B from X and Y especially for a PC gamer that never uses gamepads.  However they are responsive and work great. Very accurate tracking. Comfortable and easy to let dangle when you need your hands. The joysticks work well and the transport scheme is easy to learn. I loved them. They also work passably in Vive apps.

one_reviews_text: I initially got the rift to learn about vr. It’s so amazing. Then I thought we could use this technology to help people. There’s this kid named Jobe who mows my lawn, practically does it for free. he’s what you would call intellectually disabled. He’s been coming around curious about the VR set up I had. I started him with something simple like Beat saver... but I could tell it sparked something in his brain. One minute he can barely write his own name, after a regimen of challenging VR brain productivity apps and some mind enhancing drugs, I think I might have created a monster. As I write this review he’s already absorbed Latin in less than 2 hours, I can’t even understand pig Latin. Oh oh, he’s now telling me that his intelligence has surpassed mine and talking about how he’s touched god.

Would recommend getting a Vive with Audio Strap add-on for best experience for VR and use a tool called ReVive to play Oculus exclusives with the vive.

one_reviews_text: Omg, you people. I am in the future.Seriously, I am a dedicated PC gamer and a sci fi geek, but this... This is the future. From the intro experience, it is a total immersion.Games are pricey but there are frequent special offers and free experiences too. I love horror movies, but let me tell you, this is a whole new level. I tried a "moderate" horror experience and couldn't stay for more than one minute, it was so scary to actually feel inside the experience. Sci fi games are amazing. I am playing Farlands every few days (it is a free experience where you are a "space cadet" researching new species on various planets) and it feels like I am right in there feeding cute aliens for real.Touch controllers are intuitive.I am running this on the following specs: Windows 10 x64, Intel i5 3.10 GHz, 8GB RAM with GeForce GTX 1060 6GB. Runs like magic.Do you get motion sickness from using this: no, not from just using it. Motion sickness can be caused by specific games that imitate motion but fail to do it realistically. Does it cause headaches or vision troubles: not in my experience so far. It is not like 3D glasses in a cinema or those devices you put a smartphone in. The lenses create full immersion with a perception of a "natural" sight. You do not "see" any part of the visor when it is on.The best purchase of the year.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 15, 2017

one_reviews_text: bought this to replace my original ones as I thought I suffered some capacitive touch issues, only to have the same issues surface on these.turns out the capacitive sensors on the controller were improperly calibrated, and editing some configuration files solved the problem for me! just google "CapSenseMin" and "CapSenseTouch" - should bring you to the page on oculus forums that shows the solution.great pair of controllers at a great price :)

one_reviews_text: This product I found to be solidly built and well made. Considering the price drop it is certainly worth purchasing. I believe the little tool supplied is for removing them, I haven't bothered to try as I am quite happy with them. Being a first time VR user I was blown away! There are no words to explain the sensation of being IN whatever game is played. I play Elite Dangerous, and in VR mode it is impossible to explain the feeling of reality, my body actually believes it is moving and is in a 360 deg. environment. The graphics are good but no where near as clear as a good monitor, still it's early days yet, the more people that discover the magic of VR the quicker the development. The bottom line: buy and enjoy!

While I could still run with a USB 2.0 cable, I purchased the additional sensors to ensure I would not have any tracking loss. Using a USB 2.0 cable with the 3.0 capable system was not part of the plan.I'm leaving 4 stars simply because the sensor can work on a 2.0 system as well as the price point of this bundle is priced equivalent to a stand alone sensor so I am not really out any money if I had of bought the sensor on its own. and then purchased extension cables on my own. (Which is what I'll be doing, unfortunately.) It would have been nice to know it ships with a 2.0, so I could buy a separate 3.0 cable. But it's nothing a trip to best buy can't fix.

First, they had me create a VIDEO showing the controller and illustrating that it does indeed have a problem. THEN, they had me send them an error log (from a saved file in my computer). That was over a week ago and I have been told it might be some time before I hear back. In the mean time, the controller is dead.In short, you will have some homework if you hope to get a replacement of any piece of equipment. one_reviews_text: Fantastic product for the price.  You must have a super high end graphics card and powerful PC.  In addition, you really need the Inateck KT5002 Superspeed  USB 3.0 PCI-E card.  It is critical to run your Oculus headset and all sensors thru this independent USB card on your PC motherboard.  The native USB 3.0 ports on your PC will not handle it.  I had all kinds of problems and tracking errors, but once I added the Inateck card, everything worked perfectly.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 21, 2018

one_reviews_text: First let me say the presentation of the oculus is beautiful, the setup was also super fast and easy. With this being one of my first experiences with the oculus I can say this is definitely worth 350$. I’ve tried both the oculus rift and the Htc vive and both are excellent but the oculus touch controllers are just 1 extra step towards a more immersive experience. Everything considered this is definitely a 5/5 product worth the buy. Another thing to add is that buying a few 3.0 usb extensions, another sensor, and a hdmi extender makes the experience a whole ton better in full 360.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2019

one_reviews_text: When you are working with signed code, you update your certificates; any programmer knows this. So how in the absolute heck did they expire, effectively bricking every Oculus Rift on the planet? How did a team of people, presumably of multiple departments with a system of checks to prevent this, forget that? You usually put people in charge specifically of signed code! Usually, you have a system in place to prevent this!But let's try and put this day aside. I've had a month of fun with the games I've played on the Rift. However, I have had zero fun dealing with the Oculus software reopening on me after I've closed it multiple times, or the inexplicable 5 GB download when you download the software, or the way you HAVE to redo the dumb little demo every time you setup your Rift again, or the way so much of the system is still so inexplicably behind HTC.The games are fun; amazingly fun. I have had nothing but fun with VRChat, Holodance, and similar games. But I just can't reprehend Oculus as a company enough.There are too many annoying things about this device to recommend it to anyone yet; just wait. Wait until maybe someone buys it from Facebook and they put actual care into it.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2018
review_title: Game Developers Doing Their Best With An Atrocious Company Like Oculus

one_reviews_text: Wow...  I never imagined it would be this cool.  Impossible to describe, you have to experience it.  400 bucks was the tipping point and I'm glad I did.  Games included are very fun.Gtx 1060 with i5 5200 does pretty well.  Usb 2.0 does just fine too.  Small gripe, God Rays are too distracting on certain things like watching a movie.

one_reviews_text: Amazing product.  I was given this as a gift (although as a serious PC gamer I had previously wanted one but couldn't justify the expense).It is worth it.  On sale at $350, it's a no brainer; then you can grab a 3rd sensor and it almost equals out.When I think back about times in my personal "gaming" history where i thought, "holy ****, this is unforgettable" - the Oculus ranks up there for me with Super Mario Brothers, Doom 1, and Half Life at the top.Think of the 3d that you saw at the movies, think some "VR" game that you played at an arcade - take that x100, and that's Oculus.I'm just starting to delve deeper into more games, but the few that this come with will give you multiple "Wow" moments.Buy it.

one_reviews_text: An absolute must have for VR. Since it comes with an extra sensor and free game I can't say they're overpriced, but it's stupid how much these add to the experience. If you tried a Rift without these and were left less than impressed with being "immersed" these definitely change everything. I've instinctively opened my mouth to "eat" stuff in games on total accident and feel like a proper fool once I realized what I did.It's just crazy what these add to the immersion.I went from only caring about the immersive 3D in VR to caring about touch supported games and VR in general now. These work that well. I also like the form factor better than the HTC Vive. Just be sure to have your sensors set up properly for 360 tracking.

one_reviews_text: I had perfectly fine tracking with just 2 sensors, you just put them on opposite corners of your play area from each-other and that works perfectly fine 95% of the time, but if you have a large play space then I could see how a 3rd sensor would have a dramatic improvement over tracking, but otherwise you really don't need 3 sensors if you're on a budget.

one_reviews_text: So far so good. I used the rift primarily for games. I skipped setting up the rift sensors as my current rift sensors placement is a bit unusual. I did try setting up the rift sensors but the setup won't approve my sensor placement so I actually didn't have a choice but to skip it. But even without setting it up properly, I didn't have any tracking issue when I play a game. I wear eyeglasses while playing. Didn't have any issue wearing the headset with eyeglasses. Headset was comfortable and didn't have any problem playing for a long time. I am not sure how it compares to other VR headsets as I never tried others but for me, this is really worth my money. The only issue i have is with the Oculus Online store, It didn't have many alternatives to its payment methods.

one_reviews_text: Initially had some problems with the Oculus Rift. There support department was outstanding in helping to walk me through the possible solutions. Turns out that I was having a problem with plugging all the USB connections to the same USB controller and overtasking the controller. Once they had me split up the USB devices to different USB controllers to share the load the images got much better. That being said, I still believe that the resolution in the Rift headset is somewhat disappointing. Playing an air combat simulator on the monitor is MUCH clearer than the Rift headset. For now it is a tradeoff between the resolution of the computer monitor and the VR immersion of the Rift. Hopefully in the future the technology will improve enough to get the same resolution as you can see on your monitor.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2019

one_reviews_text: This should have been 4 stars product but I find myself returning it due to failure of the headset after 1 day.Initial set-up stopped in dead in my tracks saying some Windows updates were required.This would have been fine except they were actually installed.Had to resort to reading the Oculus user's forums to find a setting that tells software to bypass this check.After that set up went well.Initial tutorial is fun and nice to use.But you can tell Mr Zuckaman has had his grubby paws all over this and the social media/sales pitch stuff is overpowering.There is no way to just switch it off (without resorting to assorted forum advice I suspect)Managed with a few bumps to get it to work with the game a bought it for which is Elite Dangerous and can report the effect is WOW!BUTI'm returning it due to two failures!Early on one of the positional sensors was showing as warning about it missing a reading. It was ok after first install, but all I did was move computer and had unplugged all connectors and reconnected it in new location.And the headset is now not showing any display at all.  So I bought a very expensive sleeping mask.I can't fault the VR experience, but I feel the discount price is due to a lot of, possibly justifiable, bad reviews.Oculus Support seems reasonably responsive, but I've decide that returning the item is the best choice.May yet replace it with the same or look at the HTC Vive but that is more expensive.

I had already ordered a USB 3.0 extension when I purchased this not knowing that an extension was included with it. The sensor will still function with USB 2.0 so this isn't a huge deal, but it should include the recommended cable. Other than that no issues with shipping or setup. It works great.

one_reviews_text: I am what you could call a "tech-savy" person. If I have struggled with this as much as I have, I can't fathom a "normal" person being able to enjoy this system. If you have windows 7 you're going to have a difficult time with the oculus. They constantly jab at you to "upgrade" to windows 10, because that's the operating system they want you to use. Well if you're like the rest of the gaming community you know that you don't want to use windows 10 for a variety of reasons (that i'm not going to get into now.)But upon immediate use I get an error saying that I need to install certain hotfixes (which I already have). When researching, it's a common issue that has existed with Oculus since it's launch and the developers have just refused to fix it. There is a way to bypass it with using the command prompt and run menu (which im not also going to get into right now).After 3-4 hours of constant issues and trial/error fixes I FINALLY got the program installed. When it was finally tuned in correctly (making sure the sensors and pre-determined height settings etc were configured) the program was amazing. It truly brings you into a different reality and it was as close as my generation will get to truly being able to pilot a ship in space.I take the system off my head and go to bed. I wake up the next morning, and the headset wont connect. Keeps saying there's an issue with the HDMI port. I tried the port with a different device and it works fine. So back again to the drawing board I go to figure out why the darn thing won't connect. As i'm sitting here, I think to myself. No device should take this much effort to use for the price they require you to pay. I am going to give this thing one more hour of effort to get it to work once again. If I fail, I will be returning it and get the HTC VR. I will update as I go.Update: So i've decided to return the rift and hold off on any future VR purchases until technology progresses a little further. The picture (while clear) is still blurry because you're not getting true 1080p per eye. I still have constant disconnect issues and I feel like I spend more time troubleshooting the device than I do enjoying it. So until the tech-world is truly ready to release the VR on a stable user-friendly platform. I will continue to wait.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2018
review_title: When it works it's great, when it doesn't it's infuriating.

one_reviews_text: This is highly recommended so that your games don't skip and freeze when you play because you turned away from the front cameras and gives you a full 360 degree experience. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2021

one_reviews_text: Having started my gaming with an Atari system my uncle had and pretty much experienced every major game system since I can say that nothing has provided the kind of experience VR has.  Being able to move in game, using your hands in ways that, depending on the game, are extremely intuitive and natural is something you simply have to experience to appreciate.  Dual wielding laser swords like light sabers, even reflecting enemy fire back into them (Raw Data) is just about as awesome of an experience as you can get.I've the PC to run this very smoothly - i7-6700k, GTX 1070 in SLI, 16GB DDR, 500GB SSD.  So far a few things I've found.  Some games from the Oculus store require windows 8 or above.  I prefer to run windows 7 still though I have a dual boot SSD that runs 10  as well.  Some of these games you can get off Steam instead and run in windows 7.  So far the only game I've played that uses SLI is Raw Data, the Steam store version.  No game so far as maxed out GPU utlization with running just one of the GTX 1070.  Framerates have been very smooth.  Graphic fidelity is lacking.  The resolution in game is a far cry from the maxed out settings at 4K/HDR I can get playing PC games.  However that is not at all deal breaker.  The immersion value and smoothness of the experience outweighs (to me anyway) the loss of resolution.  The options beyond playing games are cool unto themselves.  VR desktop is basically Minority Report come to life.  You can watch movies in a virtual theater.  You can play 3D compatible games in a virtual theater.  All in all the level of immersion that VR provides is something you really have to experience to fully appreciate.Set up was a breeze.  The headset is not comfortable with my glasses - it puts a lot of weigh on the nose pieces and becomes pretty uncomfortable after more than a half hour and no amount of adjusting has helped.  However if I just wear contacts instead I can wear it comfortably for hours at a time.  The fact that the headset is corded really isn't a big deal, so far I've been able to move around in my designated game space without tripping or stumbling even once - my cats have not fared so well unfortunately.  It would be great if they could implement for the sensors to detect incoming objects and have them show the same way the boundaries for the edges of your mapped out space do.  My cats would be grateful.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2017
review_title: Something you have to experience to fully appreciate this is really a quantum leap in gaming experience

one_reviews_text: I haven't even been able to use it yet. I've had to download the 5gb app 4 times now, and everytime it tells me to delete it and try again. It's made by Facebook, i would think they might have mildly capable software engineers, good enough that the setup.exe works at least, but no. Maybe my experience will be great when it gets going, but water trash software really bothers me, and is part of the user experience.

one_reviews_text: The Oculus Touch controllers are pretty dang sensitive and they pickup on the slightest finger movements better than I anticipated. I thought they were malfunctioning at first, but then I realized it was the way I was placing my fingers close to the buttons. They take some getting use to, but once you understand how they work and figure out the button configuration they will most definitely add to your VR experience in a very big and natural way. I haven't touched the Xbox controller or the media remote since setting these two up. If you're getting an Oculus Rift then Oculus Touch controllers are an absolute necessity!

one_reviews_text: As an early adopter, I understand there will be issues with new technologies.  This one installed well for me (after I read other reviews about installing everything first before the product even arrives).  It took longer to get the sensors set up....go ahead and get a 3rd one and it's much easier and the cords are too short so go ahead and get extension cables for the HDMI and USB30 far sensor.  I recommend an Oculus Rift VR Cover (Green 2 pack).....as you will get a lot of sweat on the interface and the covers make cleaning it easy.  NOW for why I only gave them 2 stars CUSTOMER SUPPORT!.  I did enjoy many of the games I installed....a few crashed my system but I am a self claimed computer guru so that was no big deal.  However, after about a week the left OLED screen died.....first it turned everything to a green hue in the left eye then it just died.  SO I opened (a relatively complicated support system that requires one of those super hard to remember password settings) and opened a ticket to get a return RMA.......they never even responded to the first ticket.  A few days later I tried again....then I started getting the run around.  After each message with Support it takes 1-2 (sometimes 3) days for them to get back to you and they always ask for something different....even when you have given them everything they send you this one..."16, 5:09 AM PDT Thanks for getting back to us with that information.Please give us some time to review your case on our end with the details you've provided. We'll reach out to you once we have an update, or if we require any further information" I still don't have an RMA and it's been over 3 weeks.  There are some alternative systems out there do your research perhaps other options have better customer support.  My guess is with equipment this sophisticated, folks are going to need better support to get this technology to the mainstream.  That all said, some of the VR experiences are really cool. (Although most are not quite ready for prime time).
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2018

one_reviews_text: I was blown away after trying this the first time when it arrived. I had only used a friends ps vr which is no comparison to oculus. I would suggest waiting for oculus quest but I don't reget buying, games are amazing and vr video good too

one_reviews_text: My rift has been collecting dust until I've picked these up. These are seriously a game changer. One to one precision with every game, haven't lost tracking once. The included games dead and buried and the vr sports collection are fantastic examples of how to implement stellar touch functionality into vr games.The controllers are comfy and ergonomic to any hand size. Trigger buttons on the index and middle finger are a bit squishy, but still very comfortable and I've definitely gotten use to them.My only small nitpicky complaint is that they make my hands sweat a good amount after 10 or so minutes of gameplay. Luckily with the wrist straps attached, I'm able to let go of the controllers and let them dangle while I air my hands out. Also they take AA batteries (one for each controller) so make sure you have those...not a problem more so just a heads up.Small nitpicky caveats aside, these are mandatory additions to the oculus rift and are necessary to get the full vr experience from oculus. Just make sure to pay $199 for them if you can, and don't get screwed over by the numerous scalpers selling them for higher this holiday season.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 15, 2016

one_reviews_text: Ok I know the first question most of you will have is Oculus vs Vive. Personally I can't answer this from experience so I will do my best from a research standpoint.The similarities: Both the oculus and vive have identical resolutions so you won't be regreting either in the sense of resolution. Both weigh similar so head strain will be similar and minimal with either. The tracking is really a middle ground. The vive is orders of magnitude easier to set up and works better right away. However the oculus can have very very close room scale with 3 sensors.The differences: For me the largest difference was the controllers. The vive has the wands which, as I have read, are kind of unintuitive to use compared to the oculus and are a bit heavier which isn't nesicarily a bad thing. I can easily say that after 30 seconds with the oculus I had the controllers down. I love the haptic feedback and touch sensitive buttons. Other differences are a shorter oculus cord which is actually hard to extend, you need a few parts. One is a working hdmi cable and hdmi repeater. The oculus also needs many usb ports. It recommends usb 3.0 but I use 2.0 for the sensors and it works fine. However I would highly recommend purchasing a usb expansion card. The oculus also looks a bit better in my opinion. The final difference is the tracking systems. The oculus sensors are a bit of a pain to set up and you really need 3 for room scale however I'm still using 2 because I haven't bought the expansion card yet. Once all done though oculus can keep up most of the time with the vive in room scale.My conclusion on which vr is superior: All articles you read will say it doesnt matter, me, not so much. I think the vive is a better vr. So why did I buy the oculus? Because it is better. Wait, I just said both are best, this spent make sense. Yup that is true and I will explain. The vive is best because the tech inside is much more advanced and easier to use. My one complaint is the controllers which will most likely be upgraded in the future. So why is the oculus better? Two reasons, one the controllers in their current state are far superior and two is the elephant on the table, price. The oculus is $400 and the vive is $600 and I don't know about you but better sensor tech isn't worth an extra $200. So I would recommend the oculus only due to the price drop. If it was still $500 I'd say go with the vive and buy the better controllers in the future. But it is your decision. If you want an easy setup and larger room scale go for the vive but if you are like me and are willing to settle for slightly less complex tracking with better controllers, the oculus is your headset.Now onto the actual product review.Ok I'm writing this in 2017 and in the past vr was always the future of gaming for me and when oculus cut the price I had to jump on it. Along with the rift plus touch I got a 3rd controller which I still need to utilize with the expansion card. First of all I would like to point out oculus' phenomenal packaging. It really makes the product feel premium and well made.The setup: From start to finish the setup probably took me and hour and a half. Much of this time is due to downloading the oculus software and apps so I would say do that before you receive your oculus. After this I had to setup my sensors. These are quite a drawback on the oculus because they must be plugged into your computer so I do have cables running across my ceiling for the third sensor. The positioning of the sensors isn't as crucial as many make it out to be but I would say have both or all three in different vertical positions. I did have some problems with the software recognizing the headset and sensors so I stress this again, just buy a usb 3.0 expansion card and that will make the whole process much easier. Once they were set up I had few tracking issues unless I was faced away from the sensors.The oculus in use: Thankfully with a pc running the vr the high resolution screens really immerse you and it is easy to not notice the picked or "God rays" which are diagonal lines of pixels that run across the screens. Like I mentioned earlier the controllers are very intuitive and easy to use and really make the vr lifelike. Tracking is accurate and if you have the ability for room scale I would recommend it , it is very fun and worth the extra setup.Games: With the touch controllers a few games are free. My favorite is Dead and Buried. However other classics like Super hot and rec room are very fun titles. Along with the oculus app is steam vr which opens up many more games and simulations. One type is racing sims which I have not personally tried but I can safely assume that they are very fun in vr. One miner caveat is standing on your feet can cause some discomfort so I would suggest wearing shoes or buying those padded flooring mats. No matter what the fame library can only grow and I can't wait to see what the future holds for vr.Extra things to note: Vr is fun but if you don't have a pc yo run it, well your screwed. The oculus is $400 but if you don't have a pc be prepared to spend at least $600 on a pc. That's how much I speant on mine. But you may want to spend more if you want to do other things with your computer. This taken into account with a third sensor, expansion cables, a usb expansion card, computer peripherals if you don't have them and a desk vr can cost easily over $1500. If you are prepared to spend that much or if you have a pc then go right ahead but always keep in mind hidden costs.Conclusion: Is it time to get into vr? In my opinion, yes. With the price cut, and considering you have the pc capable of running vr (oh and by the way to all you mac users, well vr can't run on mac, period. So you will need a windows computer) you can experience at home be for the price of many tv's or even plane tickets. Plus if you have never tried vr it is very fun and really a cool way to show how far technology has come in the past ten years. The future is almost upon us folks and vr  is along for the ride. In my opinion vr will be in many homes in upcoming years so if you want to be in on it early or if you want a new and cool way of gaming you are going to be happy.Also here are my gaming rig specs:Intel i7 6700kGtx 107016gb of ddr4 ram1tb hard drive256gb ssd650 watt psu

one_reviews_text: OMFG. Thank you Oculus! I'm not one of those people who want/need the newest model of something the first day it comes out. I hesitated on getting into VR since there weren't that many games available at launch, but more precisely the entry price point. When I saw OR advertised for $399 with motion controllers I just had to try it out. Granted I did spend more than that for accessories, I purchased a 3rd sensor, 3 USB extension cables, 1 hdmi extension cable, a face cover, a secondary HDD, and some stuff to hang the headset's cable on the ceiling, but the extras aren't necessary.The VR experience totally blew my mind away. I've had similar feelings when Super Nintendo came out, then PS and N64, but experiencing VR totally eclipses those by miles.The Oculus Rift is very well packaged and it really surprised me on how well refined it is. Setting it up was easy EXCEPT for the sensors. Ugh. It took me awhile to get them aligned correctly for room scale use, and even moreso when I got the third sensor (received a few days later).This was my first time experiencing VR, but the motion controllers are so well designed and intuitive that I didn't have to think about or look at them after finishing the tutorial.The only complaint I have is that one of the side straps bunches up a little when I put the headset back into the case. Doesn't effect anything at all, but I'm ocd like that. Maybe another one could be that peripherals are lacking, both from OR and 3rd parties: Lens screen protectors, covers for the faceplate, rig to hang headset wire to the ceiling, wall mount headset rest, etc. Yeah there is some stuff on the market, but it's all pretty meh from what I've seen so far.10/10 must try VR.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2017
review_title: I've had similar feelings when Super Nintendo came out

one_reviews_text: The sensor didn't work with the 16 foot extension cable it came with. Too much signal degradation. Wound up buying a 6 foot extension that DID work. Sensor otherwise worked fine. This was my 3rd sensor.

one_reviews_text: Go Rift if you are not sure which way to go.  I have had both.  I know the hype is out there for Vive; I know that no reviewer in the world could give a clear answer on Vive vs. Rift... But it is Rift all the way.1) touch is better than vive controllers have used both!2)  Rift is cheaper!  Less than $700 with room scale and touch.3). You get more free games and and additional $100 toward games on Amazon!!!4). Room scale on Rift requires less space!5). Vive is buggy.  My vive kept having issues staring apps after a few days (why I returned it)6). You can play most if not all of the Vive games on Rift AND YOU CAN STILL ISE STEAM AND STEAM VR APP IF YOU WANT TO.  Does not work the other way (not many Rift games can be played on Vive in many cases).7). Many more, better games on Rift8). Rift hardware is more comfortable by a lot and much easier to use and still has better feel and comfort even if you buy the $100 upgrade for vive (deluxe audio strap)!Where is Vive better):1). I like the steam "home" app better than Rift BUT you can STILL USE THE STEAM VR HOME APP on Rift!2). Rift app has to be used on one windows account, no share across family unless you use the same user!  But u can use the steam games across accounts using family share on steam.

one_reviews_text: I don't have the fastest PC in the world.  It was when I bought it, several years ago, but now it barely met the spec requirements for the Rift.  I did have to upgrade the video card.  With that said, it runs great on my machine.  I can't imagine what it would be like on one of the latest and greatest PC's with a $1000 video card.  The immersion is first rate.  I dropped one of my controllers because I was setting a VR object down on a VR bench and I just let go of it.  Definitely use the wrist straps because it will happen to you.  Also the very first thing you should download is Google Earth VR.  It's free and it would make this device worth the price if it was the only thing that ran on it.  I'm not going to try to describe the experience because if you've seen it I don't need to and if you haven't I can't.  There are no words.I only gave it four stars because I had issues with the setup.  Setup would not run because it said I didn't have 6GB free on my 1TB drive which had over 600GB of free space on it.  Took some digging on the interwebs but I managed to find a work around.  Good thing I had a spare hard drive available is all I can say.When it's working, five stars all the way.  The headaches getting it installed get one star.

one_reviews_text: Honestly, I'm at about 4.5 stars, for this. It needs to be more breathable, and it needs to be higher resolution. It's already very high, but a little further, and not only can the screen door effect can be eliminated, but this could replace multi-monitor setups. You could have two or more 10ft virtual screens some distance from you and eliminate eye strain!I think Oculus and others know this, and will get us there as quickly as the evolution of technology allows. It's in their financial interest to do so. So, I've rounded up to 5 stars.A word of warning: acclimate to this, slowly. If you dive right into some faster-motion VR activities, or try use it for long periods, right away, it's only going to make you nauseous. Ease into it. Let your brain sleep on the experiences for awhile.

one_reviews_text: Touch is a wonderful addition to VR. It really can't be over-stressed just how impressive it is to have a controller setup like this. Even though you're limited to pointing, thumbs up, and grabbing, it really does change the game when you're controlling this for yourself instead of through the traditional gamepad that came with the Rift. It's night and day and, just like with Virtual Reality in general, it's hard to get a sense for the true experience unless you take the plunge and try it for yourself. If you already own a Rift, and you're still on the fence, stop here and just buy it. However, if you're looking to get into VR for the first time and you're comparing the Rift to the Vive, you should read on:The first thing that newcomers need to know is, that despite the price of the Oculus Rift + Touch being the same as the HTC Vive it directly competes with, this isn't a solution for room-scale VR. What this means, practically, is that you shouldn't consider buying this if you want to spin around 360 degrees in a game under your own physical locomotion. The Oculus Touch is designed exclusively for front-facing 180 degree VR experiences, so when you turn away from your cameras the controllers lose tracking and start acting weird. That's not to say that Touch isn't fun or isn't capable, honestly there's a lot of games that support this kind of VR and it's not bad at all, but any game that expects you to spin around under your own power is a no-go. The headset can go around 360 degrees just fine, and even supports something like room-scale with just the one camera and the Xbox controller it came with, but the Touch just can't do it on its own.That said, if you're absolutely certain you want to try room-scale with Touch, it technically is possible. All you need to do is buy into Oculus' very experimental room-scale setup, which starts with buying a third sensor from their store for $85 dollars and likely ends with either complete failure or a lot of extra money being wasted to achieve the same thing the Vive gets out of the box. The problem here isn't actually with Touch, or the Rift, or Oculus for that matter. The problem is, unfortunately, with your computer's USB controller setup. This is a complicated technical issue that boils down to the USB 3.0 standard being unintentionally awful for this purpose, but it also boils down further to the hard reality that your motherboard working with more than two Oculus sensors is luck of the draw at this point. Maybe in the future Oculus will release better sensors intended for room-scale or partner with Motherboard manufacturers to verify whether their USB setups are up to the task with a seal of approval similar to the ubiquitous AMD CrossFire stamp but, as it stands, the Oculus subreddit is littered with the tears of many a hardcore VR enthusiast that desperately tried to get this to work and ultimately failed. I'm not going to tell you not to go down this road, as it's your own choice, but room-scale with touch is not actually currently officially supported because of this and isn't likely to change any time soon.That aside, for what the Touch actually does work for it works extremely well. The official front-facing, 180 degree setup is wonderful, and there's a lot of support for it from developers. The two camera setup is solid and the controllers themselves feel good in the hand. Games with added Touch support feel fundamentally superior to their gamepad VR counterparts and games built from the ground up to support Touch are a ridiculously impressive glimpse into a future that honestly can't come soon enough. For anyone that jumped on the Rift early or simply prefers the Rift for their VR titles of choice, the Oculus Touch is an absolute must-have item that fundamentally changes the games for which it was made.The Oculus Touch easily earns my full recommendation.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2017

one_reviews_text: As an owner of the HTC Vive and Oculus Rift, I have to say I really prefer these controllers over the Vive wands. These essentially feel like console controls in terms of how they feel in your hands and button placement. Add in motion control, and you've got something pretty awesome.As is writing this, they do work on Steam. For room scale and SteamVR, I had a lot of issues getting it setup. I ended up just using the quick setup with SteamVR in which you just place the Rift and controllers on the floor in the middle of the play area and click OK. Setup in the Oculus software (required) was fine though, and didn't have issues with tracking like I did with SteamVR. The tracking issues during setup appear to be related to the Rift headset turning off while it sits unused in setup (or so that was my experience.)While I love these and gave the Rift 5 stars as well, I still recommend the HTC Vive ever so slightly for being easier to setup, the sensors don't need to be wired to the PC via USB 3.0, and you don't need to install the Vive software for it to work (you do NEED Oculus software installed for Rift.) There's also the fact HTC Vive users can use Revive to play Oculus games.If you have the Oculus Rift, you owe it to yourself to get these.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2016
review_title: Owner of HTC Vive and Oculus Rift

one_reviews_text: Read a lot of reviews about issues with the picture and cheaper feeling materials, didn't find those with this; picture was fine, the foam that pads it on your face feels exactly the same as the first gen to me, though the little speaker things are terrible. The controllers work well, I like the 360 view feature, couldn't do that with the first gen. Only things I would change, ditch the earphone things (if you're a real gamer, you'll have a good headset already and it works well with one, center head strap starts to hurt after a while, though), move the center strap attachment farther forward on the screen shell so there's less weight on your cheekbones, make the screen 1080p (small words and numbers up close start to blur, elite dangerous people know what I'm talking about), make more room for those of us that wear glasses. My glasses are within the prescribed dimension limits Oculus gives, but they are still smashed to my face if I try to wear them, will have to try their prescription lense adapter as wearing contacts (for me) gets irritating. Latency from headset or touch controller movement to screen response is so minuscule only a computer could see it. In the end, a fantastic device and well worth the price.

one_reviews_text: Do not expect satisfaction if you deal with oculusvr/support.  Two weeks ago I contacted oculusvr/support with the following request:Feb 5, 2:51 PM PST - "I have never been able to use my Oculus Rift since purchase. I asked my son (who works at Google X) to figure out the problem. He advised that the top left rail of the HDMI plug is bent out of place causing the software not to recognize the headset. I need a new cable!"That simple request has led to HOURS of time wasted in sending emails, photos, part numbers, proof of purchase, etc. back and forth with oculusvr/support.  Two weeks later still no resolution.  If you have a problem work with amazon.com for satisfaction.  oculusvr/support does not know what support means!  When a customer spends about $400.00 for a product that NEVER worked it should not be necessary to BEG for assistance... especially a defective cable!  Do not expect satisfaction if you deal with oculusvr/support!March 2018  I finally received a replacement cable and the Oculus software still will not recognize the headset. I still feel that I have wasted $400.00 with nothing to show for it but a pile of wires and a USELESS headset. I spent hours trying to get it to work but the software does not recognize the headset. My computer expert son was unable to get the headset to work with the new cable and gave up after several hours.  I am not a new to working with computers... I have been assembling my own computer systems long before the Pentium was introduced. The Oculus cable is not a standard cable one can purchase at a local computer store. It is unique to Oculus in that it has two input jacks, an HDMI and an USB and only one output jack into the headset.  I stand by the ONE STAR rating I gave Oculus and wish Amazon would allow ZERO STARS for companies that provide defective equipment to purchasers. Do not waste your time or money with Oculus!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2018
review_title: " That simple request has led to HOURS of time wasted in sending emails

one_reviews_text: Rift is the most cost effective hardware to actually dive into VR. For the price the Rift graphics capabilities is not the different than Vive and very importantly for me is the application. Vive with SteamVR really needs a full size room and the boundary system will confine and limit you if not. I like the Oculus app as it allows me more freedom instead of telling me what I should be doing. I use half my room space which sets it as medium space and Oculus is fine with that especially it's boundary system which I can ignore if need be. Plus I use my Rift on the opposite side of my monitors so I can better utilize my space without having to move my chair or change my furniture. I can sit down and use my headset and gamepad without caring about my sensors which is pointed to the other direction. Vive and SteamVR chokes if I try to do this and main reason why I buy most of my games with the Oculus app instead of Steam. If Oculus allows for sharing of apps in household and allowing multiple profiles then that would kick Steam in needed capabilities. Like in Superhot VR, I have to reset progress so others have have a better playing experience.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2017
review_title: I like the Oculus app as it allows me more freedom ...

one_reviews_text: Wow. I knew this would be fun but it exceeded my expectations for sure. It is such an immersive experience, I honestly did not think it would be this cool.There are a couple problems I see. One the headset seems to get hot after a short while of playing, after 10 minutes or so my face starts to get relatively uncomfortable. I've played max for 20 minutes at a time and it did not really get much worse, but steadily stayed at the same level. Once you take off the headset you can definitely feel it though as cool air hits your face. 2) While not necessarily a problem with the console itself, the games are all so short. Is there a true VR game that is longer than 6-7 hours long? They are great while they last, but so short.The controllers are really cool as well. You can point and it will show this in game. They also feel nice in your hands, unique controllers for sure.I really hope some longer games come out soon and that Oculus keeps supporting the Rift. My biggest worry is with their "1 billion VR users" goal and the release of the oculus go, I feel they might start to focus more on that system and not try to push the boundaries in graphics, etc.This headset takes quite a system to run. I feel a lot of people who get dizzy maybe don't have enough of a system to run this. I got dizzy only one time so far and it was strange, felt like vertigo, when Robo Recall glitched/lagged for a second. I have a 1060, i5-6600, 16 GB RAM, and SSD, nothing too crazy, but a decent ways off from minimum specs.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2017

one_reviews_text: After trying out a HTC Vive at a Gamestop, I knew I was eventually going to be buying a VR system.  The $799 price tag was a bit steep for me though, so I figured I would need to wait a bit.  I was already planning to upgrade my graphics card and snagged a GTX 1070 for a good price, and along came this summer sale for the touch bundle for Oculus.  I was wanting more out of my flight simulators, and after watching videos and reading reviews, I figured I would order.Setup was pretty straight forward, with the headset requiring an HDMI port and a USB 3.0 port, and one sensor needing a USB 3.0 port, while the other can be on USB 2.0.  I initially had both sensors set up in the front of my desk, and it worked pretty well, but I decided to go for a 2 sensor room scale setup, mounting each sensor in opposing corners of my room, on the ceiling.  I did so and have no complaints.  I may get a 3rd sensor later to clean up any rough areas where I sometimes lose tracking, but it's more than adequate right now.So how does it perform?  Like a dream.  For my original intended purpose of flight sims, it is spectacular.  Apart from using a full motion platform, this is the most immersive thing you could do for a flight sim.  You get a sense of position within the aircraft, which also helps give a sense of position of the aircraft, which is extremely useful for me flying helicopters.  The first time I picked up in the Huey in DCS:World, I felt the same butterflies in my stomach I get when I ride in a real helicopter.  Watching the ground drift away from you is amazing.  Looking down and really seeing the depth of everything.Now, obviously I wasn't going to constrain myself to only using the Rift for flight sims, so I have been playing around with different games, both free, and some that I have purchased.  The introductory demo for Oculus was actually pretty fantastic, with quite a bit to mess around with.  Lucky's Tale takes a platformer a la Mario 64, and puts you right above the action, able to move around it freely.  It really shows how VR can be utilized to enhance more traditional games, rather than just for first person experiences.  Robo Recall amps up the action, and makes you feel like you are in a twist between iRobot, the new Total Recall, and The Matrix.  The sense of presence, and the physics make the game a blast to play.  Last, I picked up Onward and Hotdogs, Horseshoes, and Hand Grenades to have some gun play.  Onward is great, and really put me in the game.  Having to actually reload your weapon rather than just pressing "X" adds to the tension, especially when you are running a machine gun that requires a bit more work to reload.  Being able to duck (or even go prone) behind cover, or lean around corners and doors, made everything feel intuitive, though the locomotion controls take a little while to get used to, and cause a little vertigo at first.All in all, I am really happy with this purchase.  Yes, there is some screen door effect, but that is going to be there with any of the current VR headsets.  I doubt it will change much until we have HMD's with a higher pixel per inch count and resolution, which will undoubtedly require more powerful hardware to run.  So this is the perfect point to jump in and see if you are going to enjoy VR.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2017

one_reviews_text: I owned the Oculus Rift for many months before investing in Oculus Touch. While I was impressed by a small number of games, there was no denying that the lack of direct interaction meant that I was only getting half the experience.Now that I have Oculus Touch, that's no longer the case.Oculus Touch is a must-have for any Oculus Rift owner. It transforms the way you play in ways that are fundamentally important. You can feel what it's like to hold a gun in an arcade shooter, or pick up objects in an RPG.I should mention that I previously owned HTC Vive but sold it after learning of a few of its shortcomings. While I very much enjoyed HTC Vive's motion controls, Oculus Touch is on a whole different level. They feel better in the hands, have unique interactions that developers can take advantage of, and have better build quality.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2017

one_reviews_text: As other's have said, the Touch is the rare gen-1 product that achieves near-perfection in it's stated goals.  Simply put, it's a must-have addition to the Rift headset.  Hand (and finger!) tracking is millimeter-perfect.  Your hands appear in the VR realm in the same position as your real-hands, and the position and movement is basically instantaneous and very, very smooth.The computing power and alogorithms behind this tech are jaw-dropping, but you don't have to worry about any of that.  It simply works, and well.  With the excellent Rift headset, I found I was deeply immersed in incredible environs, with enough feedback to fool my brain unlike any video game ever has.  Climbing huge walls in the Grand Canyon, casting spells with intricate hand movements in gritty urban settings, dropping a 3 over a trash-talking opponent, or reloading my six shooter in a knock-out brawl were all experiences I had in the first few hours of using the Touch.This is a breakthrough product, and really does deserve the hype you've heard.  It's rare that electronic entertainment makes this kind of leap.  The original Nintendo, the DVD, and video streaming all changed the way we spend our leisure hours.  Now, VR joins the list.  And the Oculus Rift + Touch is the best-of-the-best in these first generation systems.  If you've not experienced this level of VR, you're in for a treat.  Yes, go ahead and upgrade your PC to handle this beast.  You'll become part of the next great advance in home tech.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2016

one_reviews_text: Update 14.01.2018Overall this helmet is not as bad as the first;) I like this helmet. I want to ask the manufacturer, do you have a conscience? Sell goods of poor quality. It turns out that both helmets contain defects, since the first problem is in the left display, and the second one in the right, so it's not so conceived, but an accidental coincidence.It is a pity that there is no way to contact Mark Zuckerberg, he would not appreciate such work of his employees.Eventually! I overpaid for sending goods that were sent for replacement, and he, too, with a defect.I am the first of my many friends who decided on such a purchase, they know about the problem with which I have encountered and will definitely not buy this product, because it is of poor quality (effect Mura oled matrix).The goods pleased exactly one day. On the second day, the left display began to distort the color. Instead of dark gray (almost black), began to display light gray-green. And on a clean black background, appeared greenish artifacts in the left display. As a result, there is a feeling of discomfort.The right display does not have any complaints.Very long dreamed of the helmet of BP, as a result, I bought this model. And very disappointed. So, after the appearance of this problem, I started looking for information in the GUGLE and found out that this problem occurs quite often. As a result, due to poor quality, I am suffering losses due to the delivery of the helmet back to Amazon. And this is about 25% of the cost of the goods.

one_reviews_text: The sensor works great - I picked up as a fourth sensor for my environment.  The only issue I had with this sensor is that the repeater cable it comes with, seems to have some kind of a weird issue.  The computer sees it as an unknown device, and won't actually connect to whatever I plug into the repeater cable.  Tried it on both USB 2 and USB 3 ports, and tried it on a number of my sensors, not just the new one, and the cable seems to be DOA.  I happened to pick up 2 USB 3 cables that I was planning on using for the two front sensors, but ended up not needing to use the extensions cables, so this worked for now (the fourth and third sensors are hooked up to a second USB controller, using USB 2, and I have no tracking issues).  Beyond the cable issues though, the sensor is great and have nothing bad to add!

review_title: Great sensor, but I guess be careful with the repeater cable...

It ran good for about a week, now the audio cuts out about 10 mins after starting the oculus software, while waiting on oculus support to respond to my support ticket for that issue, the controllers stopped working, until i completely uninstalled and reinstalled the oculus software, which fixed that (but not the audio issue). one_reviews_text: I thought I had experienced VR with the Gear but my first 15 minutes in the Rift with Touch showed me that I hadn't seen anything yet. I finally understood what people meant when they said it felt like you were in some distant world or place. Touch just makes it so much more incredible than without...Unfortunately it only took about 3 seconds for my face to start sweating so after 15 minutes of use I removed it and now have to clean the sweat stained lenses but apart from that it is awesome! The touch controller, however great they are, they definitely make it hard to stick your finger up along your nose to scratch an itch XDThe only real problem with the Rift is one that has been mentioned a number of times elsewhere... you get 2 sensors with the kit but unless you plan on placing them on your desk the cable is just too short for the one that goes the furthest from your PC. It severely limits where you can place the sensor and in my case determined where I had to place my wall mounts. My desk is too full and the cable is just too short to keep things tidy. I definitely recommend you get 1 USB3 extension cable when you buy this.The amount of free content on offer was staggering to say the least and when I went back into the app later on I found that there are even more now than there was before. I have over 50 titles so far and have yet to spend $0.01 on buying anythingI actually wanted the Vive but decided to go with the Rift when I watched the keynote and saw the new Home includes Dash which allows you to run your windows apps in VR but arranged so much better than Windows Home where you have to travel through the virtual space to get to your apps. They keynote said that update would be available for free in December. Imagine my surprise when I put on the headset and went to the store and found 3 free apps that all do exactly that already...Definitely happy with my purchase. Oh, and a word on shipping... a padded box inside a padded box to keep my foam encased products safe... the box I received was almost double the size of the products box. Excellent packaging.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 14, 2017

one_reviews_text: If you own an Oculus Rift and you play games that'd benefit from 360 degree tracking (Onward, Robo Recall, GORN, basically any game where you're in the middle of the action), a third sensor is a fantastic addition. I had previously used 2-sensor tracking (sensors on opposite sides of each other) but still had some jitteriness where the sensors didn't overlap. By adding this guy and setting it straight in the back (so the sensors were at equal angles away from each other) I had perfect 360 degree tracking. Not only that, but if one of the sensors got moved for whatever reason, the system compensated for it much more easily. It's a lot easier to play games developed for 360 degree systems now!

one_reviews_text: This sensor makes using the oculus wonderful. No longer have to worry about losing tracking when I turn around. I have a PSVR and the hardest part is trying to stay facing the camera. With this sensor for oculus, there's no issue when you turn around. These sensors also have a very wide sensing range, despite the size of the face. Only downside is that the oculus setup wants a very sharp left or right angle during setup, meaning one side doesn't necessarily get the coverage you want (it wants somewhat of a right triangle setup instead of an equalateral setup), but that is more of the program forcing that, not the sensor. Also bonus points because when I ordered the sensor, it came with a 10 foot USB extension.

one_reviews_text: Words cannot express how amazing the VR experience is with this model. After playing a friend's Rift for just a few minutes I had to own one, that's how compelling it was to me, and I bought my first gaming system in about 13 years to drive it. Both me and my son (age 8) love the Rift and the games you can play on it. If you consider yourself a gamer at any level, you have to try one sometime and when you do you'll probably come here and buy it. I would recommend purchasing the additional sensor (it comes with two in the box) for a total of three and running roomscale if you have the space. The free game Robo Recall is the most immersive first person shooter I've played in my life. Arizona Sunshine (FPS zombie game) is the scariest zombie game I've ever played. The Rift will take you to space to visit the international space station, or fly around the world in Google Earth VR. If you're wondering how good VR technology is today - it is absolutely here - today. The Rift is a great entry level VR that I would recommend in a heartbeat. It will work on a GeForce GTX 1060, but I really recommend the GTX 1070 to drive it for a flawless experience.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2018
