one_reviews_text: Update on review 9/14/2017After a month of use I can say definitively that this device feels like a beta version of something better. The screen door effect is horrific, it's 2017, my phone has better resolution.  The games all feel arcade style and cheap. The blurriness is just unbearable after a certain while of gameplay, it really makes me feel like vomiting. This device isn't ready for mainstream yet, feels like something one tries once in life but never looks back at it again. Not with the buy until next gen versions are released. My two cents!Just set up the head set! It took me about 15 minutes to get the wires connected, 2 sensors calibrated and headset adjusted.  I didn't have to create a Facebook account like the previous reviewer stated. I created an oculus account to sign into my games and oculus portal. Super easy, if anyone is having a hard time they lack common sense.Make sure you have at least 3 USB 3.0 connections on your pc and an HDMI connection to your Graphics card. You have to have an internet connection to download the Oculus software online, as it does not come with any type of CD rom.Visit the Oculus website to get started as there is no documentation directing consumers to the website for setup. I had to search the web a bit to figure it out.  Download the Application and it will walk you through the whole set up process.Very simple, the only gripe I have is the six free games aren't available for free in the oculus portal. The bundle is supposed to include  these games automatically, I don't know if this is a registration fluke or a common Issue. Make sure you receive your free games.Regardless, this is absolutely an awesome experience. I will revise my review as I tinker with it more.9/3/2017The six games that were bundled with Oculus showed up on my dashboard as purchased the next morning.  The games look great and it's a truly immersive experience. So, I did get the six free games.Two issues I've noticed about the rift is no matter how I adjust the headset there seems to be blurry areas in the field of view. The blurry areas aren't as noticeable when playing games, but when reading text its better to move the head unit to the direction of the text so it comes into focus. Your eyes alone cannot adjust for focus unless the head unit is facing that direction.The second issue I've come across is the screen door effect that many people notice while using the Oculus Rift. It's essentially your eyes being able to pick up the spacing between individual pixels on the OLED displays in the head unit. To get an idea of what I'm talking about, walk up to your TV and stare at the screen, you'll be able to see the individual pixels on screen. Keep in mind my TV is 60 inches, so its easier to see individual pixels on my 1080p TV. In order to fix this problem Oculus would have to modify the displays to a higher resolution OLED display, which would in turn require 800 dollar Graphic cards, (not economical now).  Maybe in a few year newer tech will drop in price for this move to be made.I still like the unit and would recommend the purchase, just make sure you have a descent Graphic card in your PC. AMD rx480 or rx580 would work great for most games. As of this posting, most AMD GPU's have inflated prices, wait for stock to increase and purchase at MSRP.

one_reviews_text: I am anticipating good things, in spite of minimum specs...will update.  This aside, I'm writing this for a heads up.  My husband walked by me carrying a box the other day.  He looked up and said, expressionless, "Your mother's Oculus Rift is here" and went on to deliver it to her.  Here I thought I was being clever by having it sent in her name.  :|  My mother is in her 70s and prefers mystery novels.  Clearly the surprise was foiled.  So if you just bought this for someone for Christmas it may come super fast unexpectedly and have "Oculus" written on the label on the box...run, track, find and hide that puppy.Quick revised update, March 2018:  He was very, very happy, though we did end up upgrading the computer quite a bit (ouch) and we added the extra sensor.  Most importantly, though, he has thoroughly enjoyed his new VR world (and unintended new computer :I), in spite of the limited game content (there are just so many fun ones out there, but they aren't huge like most of us are used to).  That being said, there is still much joy to be found in this limited world AND then there is Elite Dangerous, the go-to VR game, it seems.  This game feels limitless!  It is set in space, after all.I did manage to surprise him with the Thrustmaster T.16000M FCS HOTAS Controller and the recommended Voice Attack at the hcsvoicepacks site, which have been well worth it!  At first he was skeptical of the need for any of it, but then later I found him sitting at a small table in the middle of the room facing an empty wall, away from the computer, looking up toward the ceiling.  Fortunately, his VR headset was on or I'd have been a little concerned, though I admit it did make me chuckle on the inside.  To me, with my husband, sitting at that table that I haven't seen in years, that he must have dug through lots of storage to find, says a lot.  It had only the controller resting on it.  On the monitor he was flying through space.  Many hours later he appeared to me.  I suppose space commanders have to sleep, too.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2017
review_title: Box Gives Away Surprise!  --  Also, Updates From a Gift Perspective

If you don't care about 360-degree play you don't need a 3rd sensor otherwise with a 3rd one it becomes very accurate and much fun to play. So, it's debatable whether Occulus is better than VIVE or vice versa, for me yes, I'd prefer sharper image. Besides, there's NO way you should pay another $300 for HTC, it is NOT worth it.These VR sets are still evolving their v2 will probably much better. Occulus WILL do, the way it is.

one_reviews_text: I bought it because I had a bunch of amazon gift cards to turn in so it cost me $16 out of pocket.  I thought it would be a gimmick at best.  I was wrong. Paired with my laptop that has a I7 7820k and GTX1080, this is the most intense gaming experience I've ever had.  Playing "Robo Recall" is an adrenaline rush and the level of detail is unbelievable.  You forget about real life when you are immersed in VR.  Also played Skyrim with the VorpX driver and it becomes a whole new game (after tweaking the settings of course). For $349 (comes with headset, 2 sensors, controllers) this is well worth the price.  It will change your gaming experience. Also, so great boxing games that really make you break a sweat and good for practice

one_reviews_text: My most recent e-mailIt appears as though there may be no resolution to the issues I'm having with the Oculus rift, which render the product useless.  Therefore I am requesting a phone number to speak with a support person to resolve these issues or  an RMA number that I may use to return the Rift for a full refund.To summarize the problems:1.  Unable to download games from  Oculus via the Oculus app2.  Third party games (purchased on dvd) work with external display w/o issue, but the oculus display halts and displays an oculus menu within the headset. The external display continues properly.  To re-enable the Oculus Rift display, a complete restart of Oculus and the third party software is required.3.  Third party games (purchased from SteamVR) start normally in Oculus rift, but terminate after a few minutes and require restart, and resume w/o restarting oculus.Efforts to resolve this issue to  point.:We have been using chat and e-mail sessions for 4 days (starting on 10/13/2018) with no progress or change in the status or any anticipated resolution date.10/13/2018We encountered issues with downloading Oculus software and opened a problem ticket.Opened a chat session and e-mail session with tech support team members Lloyd and Peter.Provided detailed system log files to the Oculus support teamI was asked to wait a couple of days for possible resolution.10/16/2018 -Checking the status of the problem tickets, one appeared to be "resolved"Opened a chat session and was advised Oculus is experiencing a large volume of calls, indicating a widespread problem.Chat Log from 10/16/2018:(03:46:40 PM) Ezekiel: It does appear that everything that could be done via chat was covered though, so there isn't anything else I can suggest to you. All I can suggest is waiting for us to get back to you via email, as we are investigating, but if you have anything that you'd like me to add to the ticket before taking this back to email then please let me know.(03:48:48 PM) Richard: Yes.. It has been a few days, with no progress. I would like to get an RMA to return the rift. if the problem can be resolved before tomorrow... I'd be delighted, but my confidence to this point is shaken. I'm not pleased with this outcome, but I need to try the HTC.(03:50:54 PM) Ezekiel: I am sorry that we have yet to get back to you Richard, we have been experiencing high ticket volumes over the past week, we typically will get back to you within 1 to 2 business days once it has been sent to email for investigation.(03:51:43 PM) Ezekiel: Now, as for the RMA part, that is not my call, but I will add that as a note to ticket 614589 when I update the ticket(03:52:24 PM) Richard: Please send me the contact info I need to discuss an RMA.(03:54:53 PM) Ezekiel: I don't have any contact info to provide to you Richard, as there isn't a RMA specific point of contact, but I have added said note to your active ticket (613376).(03:55:25 PM) Ezekiel: You could also reach out via ticket 613376 with your RMA request as well.

one_reviews_text: I hadn't done much research on VR and bought it only after a friend mentioned they bought one (Always was one for bad decisions so thought why not?) Main videos i had seen of VR were the army simulator games with the clunky graphics so that's what I was expecting. Boy was I surprised to find out it was actually great graphics and pretty decent gameplay. I can't play it for more than an hour or two but it's an hour or two of being completely engrossed in whatever game or environment I'm playing in. I will say I bought it without thinking about my glasses. The headset isn't extremely glasses friendly. You need a smaller pair of glasses and even then it's going to be pretty close to the internal glass of the headset. I also found the internal glass will fog up unless the room of your house is above 75ish. Most of that is due to the headset pushing down over your nose forcing air back up onto the glass. It's minor in the long run tho. Great buy and don't regret it. Been having alot of fun with friends and family.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2017
review_title: ... friend mentioned they bought one (Always was one for bad decisions so thought why not

one_reviews_text: I actually enjoy the Rift quite a lot but there are some issues to be aware of beyond technical problems (not including or sickness, which I'll cover later).The Rift itself is made with quality and there really doesn't appear to be anything terribly cheap about any of it. Even the headphones that come with it are pretty nice. The touche controls are very comfortable and responsive. All in all, it works very well. I have not had issues with sensors (I bought a 3rd sensor which pretty makes that go away). And as far as motion sickness, that's just common with intense VR games, the fault isn't the Rift, it;s our own senses not handling VR well - simply put, don't play games rated as "intense."My issues may not be specifically Rift related, but they're very real issues that prevent me from enjoying it.1. The screen-door effect. Seriously, what's up with the graphics? Many games are grainy, and the headset itself give them that effect like you're looking through a screen door. That's a huge letdown.2. Very, very few quality games are out right now for VR. I tried several, and returned several. Most of them suck, or have been adapted For VR and just don't function right. A lot of what's out now isn't made by AAA studios so there are a lot of games with cutsey-kiddie graphics.3. Damn headset gets itchy, itchy itchy. I dunno but my nose is always so itchy, it's like the foam just makes me wanna scratch, which really breaks immersion.4. They don't have many reliable ways for movement that don't induce motion sickness so you stand in place spinning in circles. What's wrong with that? Spinning in circles means that darn cord isn't as easy to avoid as you might think. Yes, there are ways to hang it overhead, but I don't want to go drilling holes or attaching stuff to my walls and damage the paint. I've found myself tangled up from spinning around more times than I can remember.All in all, the product itself is excellent. All 3 stars are for the product. But I will likely refund the Rift, as much as I like it, it doesn't have the support of solid graphics in many games, and what games are out there just look like they're made for kids, in an attempt to hide the poor graphics and/or studio quality. They're definitely on to something, but it has a long way to go.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2017
review_title: Headset & Controls are Good Products, But Support And Graphics Aren't There Yet.

one_reviews_text: Summary review:At $400, for gamers that aren't struggling to pay bills this is an awesome purchase!Setup and use was simple and the learning curve to the touch controllers almost intuitive. Fully comfortable headset even with neck issues. And the immersion is shocking.Though, probably NOT a great gift for your na-na that prefers playing Bridge over AAA PC games.Full review:I started on the Atari 2600 circa 198x. From there I followed as close as I could afford to gaming tech. Atari 5200, Nintendo, Genesis, Game Gear, Saturn, N64, Dreamcast, PS1, Xbox, PS2, Xbox360, PS3, 3DS; Commodore 64, 386, 486, 486 (with Turbo!!!,) dual, quad, hexa, octa-core and all peripherals needed. These let me feel like I was playing a video game and real life was right beside me.I held out on VR only because I couldn't justify spending more than my first car on hardware with a nearly singular function. With that I can't compare the Oculus against the Vive, VPL Tech (see Lawnmower Man,) or anything between. (except Google Cardboard which is a neat experience, but shouldn't be included in the same conversation.) I also couldn't see myself buying something from Facebook over a company whose primary focus is hardware tech. Then, after the recent Summer sale, I couldn't see myself spending twice as much on equally compared products.So I got the Oculus, and found immersion I haven't experienced in my 30+ years of gaming. There have been moments I had to pull away only to catch my bearings. Knowing intellectually that I'm looking at a computer generated world, yet feeling my palms sweat looking over the edge of a multi-story building.It still feels like studio's are only exploring the capabilities and limitations of VR. But with a strong sense that the games and applications out now are only a hint of what's to come.For supporting hardware I'm running this on MSI x370 mb, AMD Ryzen 1700 modestly OC'd to 3400, 1x Evga GeForce 970 4gb, Corsair Vengeance LPX 16GB DDR4 3000MHz (with BIOS issues on bringing it down to 2300mhz). So far I've seen zero stutters, low FPS or tracking issues.If you're considering getting into VR, all things considered the Oculus is currently the best choice.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2017

one_reviews_text: I run a university lab for emerging technology. We have been experimenting with Vive, HoloLens and Oculus in the VR/AR/MR space. All three are pretty great (though Oculus and Vive are far more complete products than HoloLens, which is a different kettle of bits), but the Vive was emerging as the consensus winner, mostly because the controls were better. The Touch controllers changed the game, with the Oculus now perceived as the clear winner at this time. These controllers are essential for the Rift. They enhance the experience significantly. The action is very natural and the "hands" give you an anchor point in VR which I find helpful in reducing motion sickness, which is an issue for me. Despite how awesome it is this technology is still fairly primitive- we liken the current state of the technology to the "suitcase cell phone" of the 70's- clunky and cumbersome, but so compelling that it's worth dealing with the limitations. Coming innovations such as wireless headsets, smaller headsets, and real-time feedback- see Occipital's Bridge for an early example- along with higher resolution will have this technology wowing us for years to come!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2017

one_reviews_text: If you are contemplating buying a third sensor just do it. It's definitely worth it. I bought a third and then 4th. I have an Asus X99 deluxe U/3.1 motherboard with 2 USB 3.1 pci cards so I have a ton of USB ports. You have to make sure you have enough bandwidth to handle 4 but 3 should be fine if you have limited USB ports if you use your USB 2.0 port instead. I had to buy 2 USB 3.0 extensions because it only comes with USB 2.0. Probably not a huge issue but I wanted to make sure there were no issues with lag or latency and USB 2.0 is slow in comparison.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2017

one_reviews_text: I really liked the VR when I first got it.  Shipped quickly.  Not too bad to set up if you just follow the instructions.  But the system is very glitchy.  I bought a brand new gaming PC and have put nothing on it except VR.  Games fail to start.  Have to unplug and replug the headset in.  Games are fine one minute and the jerky the next.I was putting up with all that because its still fun, but after 2 months, a button quit working on the left controller and the trigger got sticky on the other.  I contacted Oculus support.  Took several days to respond and when the did, they made me get them a bunch of information like error logs, serial numbers, etc.  Took like 20 minutes.  Then days went by, and the asked me to take a video of a game in action and demonstrate that it didn't work.  Try to do that with a cell camera to show what your fingers are doing while looking through the headset and trying to show on the screen what's going on at the same time.  They also wanted pictures of the serial numbers.  Why do they need all this?  They have my registration.  And why didn't the ask several days ago with the other info.Here's where it gets really petty and frustration.  After two weeks, they say they will send me refurbished controllers despite mine were only 2 months old.  I complained.  They said too bad, the fine print in the warranty says they send refurbished.  And they guaranteed it would be be indistinguishable from new.  So I put them in a box (no choice anyway) and sent them off.What did I get in return now on week 3?  ONE controller, not two.  And it looked like the previous user was eating pizza in between games and then not washing his hands.  It was greasy and full of crumbs.  Hardly indistinguishable from new!  So I write back asking where my other replacement is.  Days go by. They ask for my address, tracking number, etc. again as though they've never heard of me and have no record of my issue.  I give them this info, days go by, and they ask for more information.  I look it up on THEIR system, put it in an email and sent it to them.  I keep getting notes saying "thank you for your patience, you're issue will be handled in the order it was received." NO, its not being handled in that order!  I keep going to the end of the line.A month later, I finally get a second controller after pleading with them to just put one in a stinkin' box and send it to me.In summary, your money will gladly be taken upfront to buy a new system.  It will probably be glitchy, but its still fun.  God help your patience if you have to deal with support.  Its very petty and unethical they way they treat a customer who just bought a brand new system.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2018
review_title: Terrible customer support - better hope it doesn't break!

one_reviews_text: The first time stepping into VR in Oculus is such a memorable experience! I literally squealed from excitement being transported into another world, seeing my hands and fingers replicated in the VR world and then interacting realistically with objects in your environment is a downright joy to behold. I absolutely love the Oculus and don't regret buying it at all over the HTC Vive (more expensive) and Windows Mixed Reality (less expensive, but currently less supported by developers).My only complaint is that the right headphone stopped working. I used the included Oculus screwdriver to gently tighten/loosen the right headphone and the sound came back, but it intermittently cuts out and it has gotten worse over time. I suspect a bad wiring connection so I am returning my set for a replacement. Hopefully there will be no issues with the replacement.*UPDATE* I received the new Rift which has been working for several months without any issues at all. It's sturdy and built like a tank--I don't know how many times I've hit the headset with the controllers or run into something LOL, but keeps working with no issues. I'm revising my rating to 5 stars, I LOVE the rift!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2018
review_title: Makes me feel like a kid again!

one_reviews_text: I can't recommend this at this time.  With the default settings the image as a fixed pattern noise at low light levels.  This is best seen in the IPD calibration tool or the lost demo.  It is possible to correct this using a registry key (search for usespud=0 - there are large reddit posts about this).  This removes the noise.  For me the noise was like varying random grey transparent specks.  For others it is green.  The reg key above may introduce other issues (red tint or more god rays) on my unit it did not seem to.  However give the registry key is unsupported. Plus their support teams are not taking anyone seriously who reports this - i have spent a month sending mails back and forth with oculus I am left in a situation where i cannot recommend due this issue and their poor support.  To be clear this issue is because they are not correcting for mura correctly.  Turning off the correction actually improves the display.  However at any time oculus could remove this reg key and we would be left SOL.This issue, should not be confused with the screen door effect - this is a uniform pattern caused by the gaps between pixels being visible, while present in bright scenes it is IMO minimal and is non-intrusive.  This incorrect MURA correction results in a non uniform pattern, that is different in each eye, visible in darker scenes.  The difference in eyes can cause motion sickness for some.On the upside the controllers are absolutely fantastic (better than the MS mixed reality ones i have played with)  and i was more than impressed by the experiences, the tutorial demo is one of the best i have seen, the new integration with steam is great.  For now i am going to wait to v2 when the have ironed out their issues and the product and support practices have become more mature.  (oh and one again thanks for amazon return process and policies - easy and awesome!)
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2017
review_title: Great unit, great controllers, spoilt by bad MURA correction issues and poor support.

one_reviews_text: Buy this at your own risk.  If you can keep this thing running it is a pretty cool novelty but it is a very buggy application and piece of hardware.  Any update by Oculus or Nvidia or Windows can crash this and make it unusable.  There is no support from Oculus.  Its all email based and very slow. You cannot talk to anyone and they will give you only basic trouble shooting. Third sensors are a nightmare for keeping connected as well as the Headset and blank screen issues.  Check their forums, they have rampant problems with this item.  If your thinking about VR I would very sincerely think about waiting until new and better systems become available with much better support for both the software and customer service.  I will never buy another Oculus product and will likely wait for something from Sony or Microsoft that is worth it.

review_title: Be Careful  and do research before you Buy

one_reviews_text: The hardware and software is stable and it works.You'll need at least one (1) powered USB 2.0 port for a motion sensor and one (1) USB 3.0 port for the headset, in addition to an HDMI port for the headset. Ideally you'd have an extra USB 2.0 port so you can have a total of two (2) sensors for better tracking, but one works fine for sit-down experiences.You'll also need a relatively powerful machine. At least a GTX 980/1060. Each eye in the headset is rendered at around 1080p, so it's the equivalent of a dual-monitor setup in terms of performance requirements. VR games need to run smoothly or else the tracking gets unresponsive and you can get motion sickness, so the standards for framerate are a bit higher (90fps is recommended).VR is awesome. You don't really "get it" until you try it out for yourself.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2017
review_title: It works. It's awesome. Some tips...

one_reviews_text: I loved the initial experience, 3 sensor room scale is great! However I have 20/20 vision and I feel like a legally blind man in virtual reality. Screen technology and resolution needs vast improvement. Until then I am going to have to hold off. In some games it didn't seem like such a huge deal like in Luckys Tale (Though the screen door/pixilation was still noticeably annoying). Lone Echo was a good game though it really made the screen door effect impossible to overlook (pun intended?) and it stole quite a bit from Halo (which isn't a terable thing really I loved the early Halo games).Bottom line screen tech needs an upgrade, until then I couldn't recommend this for anything but casual short spurts of game play.This being said I am extremely optimistic to what the future of VR and AR will bring and I cannot wait until their is an option for immersive experiences that doesn't make you feel like a legally blind man fumbling around the interwebs.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2017
review_title: Immersive ability packs an incredible wow factor but the poor screen quality will leave you wanting...

one_reviews_text: Was not happy with it. The screendoor effect was worse then I was hoping it would be and the glow effect was really bad. Could not watch bigscreen app that a glow would hit the lens and cover what you were watching, like nails on a chock board. They call it godrays but its not just that... You got god rays that adds a glow to the dark background that is reflecting off a bright object of any kind (text and such) and then you got a glow that reflects on the lens that covers what you are watching/looking at and that's whats annoying. I did get sick playing Luckys Tale but not Robo Recall but oddly I did in other stand still app's but I think the screen door effect plays a big role on motion sickness because I get the same effect when I lookout a screen window and move my head side to side. When I played Luckys Tale I was sick puking for a good full day and that was when I put it back in the box and sealed it... I'm glad I did not buy the Vive.If you are like me or simply picky, do not buy. If you think you may get sick, test it first and play luckys tale and if you can play that and don't care about the other stuff I said then buy but if you do get sick, do not buy, even if it was $100 its still not worth getting sick. Wait till VR gets to V2 and then invest.My pci7 4790kGTX1080ti16gb ram
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2017

one_reviews_text: Waited till the price went down and save up the money for the headset. But when I've first tried it out. I've couldn't believe how realistic it was when I've tired the Oculus Touch demo. If I where you I recommend buying a third sensor for 360 room scale.But on the other hand my parent don't know how to use the touch controller very wells. Because my parents are old and don't know how to use technology very well. The only issue I had playing the rift was accidentally pressing the pause button with my Palm because I have big hands.But I did let my parent tryout the roller coaster simulation instead and my step dad said,  "it felt like you where in a roller coaster and I almost felt like falling out of the chair short of."But all in all it worth the $400 I've paid for. one_reviews_text: Insanely difficult setup.  So much so that I never did get it set up and had to send it back!  I bought a new ASUS gaming computer.  thinking it would be an easy setup.  It fought me every bit of the way.  First it wouldn't even run the setup program.  I finally found the problem affects lots of WIN 7 machines and Oculus was notified of this bug back in January of 2017.  it still hasn't been fixed and the solution?  reinstall windows!!then it wouldn't recognize the HDMI and USB cables that were plugged in.  It turns out the HDMI problem is caused by a "certain amount of" bad HDMI connectors that are on the Oculus headsets.  The Occulus HDMI connectors will actually ruin your graphics card connector too so you have to buy a new graphics card!  There is NO warning anywhere in your package to check this .  I found it buried in a forum.  Then the USB 3 connection wouldn't work.  Apparently Oculus needs a certain manufacturers brand of USB3.  I was told to buy a new USB3 card for my machine!Oculus get your act together!!

one_reviews_text: Make sure to research and test this item at a local electronics store before buying.Unfortunately for me I didnt bother testing first and was unable to use this device due to my physical facial features basically not meeting the requirements... I did find info about 3rd party companies that make parts for issues such as this but its just not worth it. Having to buy this device at full price and then buying 3rd party lenses and parts was just to costly.I attempted to reach out to the Oculus Support team but that was a total miss as they never responded. This caused me to reach out to general support from other users on their public forums. That was a total mistake as I instead was receiving nonsense and bullying from immature gamers and fanboys of the device.In the end I returned this for a refund. I hope that a future release/model that will support and resolve the issues I experienced. So again, make sure to research and test this item at a local electronics store before buying.

one_reviews_text: The controllers are the only redeeming feature of this. The lenses have less swirls than a vive, but they are blurry as all heck, looks like there is Vaseline on the lenses. The head set cannot be used if you have a bigger head than a 5 foot 2 100 pound person. If you have bad vision you cannot use this at all with out your glasses, and your glasses aren't going to fit. I had to bend mine to the point of braking them to get them in there. I have really small glasses and a small head also. Even with doing that, there is 0 protection from the glasses, and they rubbed and started wearing 2 circles in the corner of the rift lenses.It is less heavy than the vive, so there is that. Also it is not cheaper than a vive. In order to get close to vive room scale, you need 4 sensors. This requires over 50 feet of usb cable, and 2 usb controllers. So make sure you have 3 usb 3.0, and 2 usb 2.0. Make sure you use nothing else usb, unless you buy a pcie usb card.Also this is not going to work with anything less than 16gbs of ram. Just to run the Oculus bloat ware program costs you around 3-4gbs of ram. So I had the Oculus bloat program up, and just steam home, and I was at 7gbs ram usage. When I loaded Elite it went to 8.5-9 gbs. It uses serious ram for these cameras, and the bloatware it self.As I said the only good thing about it is the controllers. The only way I could recommend buying this, is if you want to play a game where you sit and stare straight, like elite dangerous or something like that. You are very skinny between 100-145 pounds, and have perfect vision or wear contacts. Room scale is worse than vive, even with 4 cameras. The cameras are damn near impossible to get mounted to the wall right, unless you have some high powered glue, or drill holes through them, which you need them mounted on the ceiling if you want it to be any where near vive.  It took me over 6 hours to get these set up right to even come close to vive tracking. Then you gotta deal with running 50 foot of usb cable.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2018

one_reviews_text: So a fast review of the Touch controllers. For the longest time the oculus rift has been a let down for me.  I bought the Rift about two months back and for the most part its been a system that was fun but just felt like it was just a demo. Facebook/rift dropped the ball badly by releasing the rift unfinished. Lots of friends played with the system and had a blast, but I had to explain the novelty was not even close to being worth the asking price.With that little down vote for the rift why are the touch controllers a 5 star? They make the rift worth the price, it is that simple. I only have my controllers for a single day now and honestly it changes VR. All the crap the vive owners have been giving the rift people? totally justified, I have messed with a vive a few times and room scale/free motion of the body is what makes VR. After you try it once you can not go back really. If you own a rift there is no question, this is a must buy. It took around 20min for me to set up the 2nd "eye" and controllers. I spent the better part of the day and night just messing around with games on steam and the few free ones that came with the pre order. It really does expand VR beyond being a fun toy to a real experience. The main questions that I have been asking myself now are1)Is the rift worth buying without the touch? No.... don't think about buying the rift without the touch.2)Is the rift/touch worth buying? Yes, if you have the money and want to make the jump it is worth the price.3)Is it worth buying over the vive/PSVR? Yes/No...You had to see this coming. The vive does room scare far better and at a lower price point, PSVR is far cheaper and there are millions of PS4s on the market already(and they have lots of AAA backing)However the rift does in my experience far better at the standing system and is more comfortable and the touch seem to be far better controllers. So my answer is this.-If you have the money and have limited space The rift is better. Touch is a must buy alongside the rift otherwise forget it-if you have the money and have large space 5x5 to bigger, the vive is better.-if you have limited money/space and already own a ps4 the PSVR is better.there is no clear winner yet so its hard to say what system is worth your money in the long run. This is early tech, if you don't have money to take a risk on something that might be gone in a few years don't buy any VR yet. So far I am really impressed with the Touch controllers, they just feel better if your hands then the vive's and have just as good tracking.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2016

one_reviews_text: Preeeetty gooooood
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2018

one_reviews_text: I've got mixed feelings on the Rift. Having lived through VR in the 90's (and playing Doom or whatever was out then on a 640 screen...), this is definitely a step ahead of where we were 20 years ago. Some games made me giddy and some things left me scratching my noggin.On the plus side, for games that were written for VR, it's really an incredible experience. Graphics look good, sound was surprisingly better than I expected and the sensors do an excellent job tracking you. The headset is fairly light, all things considered. The touch controls feel light and comfortable for extended periods of time. Oculus Home software works pretty good and with the recent update, Steam games show up after you've played them once.I was going to get the third sensor for the full room setup and didn't end up needing it at the moment as I was able to space out the two sensors wide enough to cover me at the desk and standing up. If I were turning completely around and kept facing away, I would have some spotty movement since I don't have the third sensor. Hasn't been an issue for me up to this point. I'm not too crazy about the price of the third sensor and some links on their site indicate that this is still experimental. Either say you can and support it or say you can't and don't allow it. Really rough here Oculus.On the negative side, I personally stay a bit warm and live for air conditioning. There's a small amount of heat generated from the headset and it's just enough after closing off my face inside the mask that it makes me pretty warm, to the point of sweating a bit at times if I'm dodging killing robots. Heated face leads to fogged up lenses. Fogged up lenses lead to a blurry visual experience. I've played around a bit trying to figure out how to position and try to leave a bit of a gap at the bottom to let some air in and it hasn't helped any yet. This doesn't happen every time, so now I try to make sure I take a break every so often to cool off and crank down the air before I get all worked up over those robots. It is rather aggravating though.Another negative I found was figuring out the sweet spot to look through the lenses. I'm borderline needing glasses, so that doesn't help any. For me, the lenses are very specific to the angle you need to look. If you like to turn your eyes more than your head, you'll have plenty of fuzzy looking things. If you don't position the mask up/down just right, you'll have plenty of fuzzy looking objects when you look straight ahead. I'm also borderline whatever it's called on the distance between your eyes. The rift allows you to adjust out to something like 71. I apparently could stand to be out another notch or two. So if you have a fat head like me, you may experience some blurry because you can't adjust the lenses out far enough.Game-wise, I didn't find as many things out there that I wanted as I hoped. There's plenty of games out there. Look on Steam and you'll find pages and pages of them. There's some cool ones that I can play standing. Found myself down on my knees a couple times hiding behind cover even. Luckily I found a few that allow me to rest my butt in the chair when I'm worn out. SteamVR is a mixed bag for me as it didn't always stay centered. I'd find myself facing backwards at some point and without the third sensor, I enter unknown (by Rift) territory on movement. Overall, most every game I tried out looked good and worked well as long as I made sure it was designed for Rift *and* the touch sensors.My biggest disappointment was with virtual desktops. I'm a dba/architect/nerd and live in things like VS and SSMS. My grand hope was that with Steam's Bigscreen or one of the other virtual desktops, I'd be able to sit there and play John from Minority Report, not to mention have large windows to witness all the glory of C# spewed all over the place. Well, that didn't work out as well as I hoped. From what I read, the Rift's graphic capabilities prohibit it from showing text in a non-pixelated way. If I kept the windows small enough, I didn't see the pixelation, although then I couldn't see the screen. If I made the window larger, I could see the text and then I ran back into the issue of turning my eyes instead of my head to look around (blurry vision out the sides). I'm not sure there's anything with this generation of hardware that can change this. Watching Netflix and Bluray did work well and made my 75" TV feel kind of small afterwards.Overall, it's a great experience. Maybe in another 20 years they'll have more of it worked out. I looked at the Vive and at the time, it wasn't discounted yet. Mixed bag on which to pick. I like how Vive doesn't have USB sensors and I read they have wider eye adjustments (didn't realize that fact when I purchased). One big thing that ticked me off is how this is packaged now. This is the same hardware as the previous package that *also* included the little remote and an xbox controller. I wasn't so worried about the controller as I live on a PC for a reason. Having to spend an extra $30 or whatever for the remote though seems cheap on their part. If you are looking to purchase, find the package that includes those items for the same price (at time of this writing anyway). Even though it doesn't say it, it includes the same free games as well (no code entered, you get them when you create your Oculus account and set up the Rift). I almost returned this to get the other. I haven't tried the third party face plate replacements yet.Final notes. If you can, make sure you try this out somewhere to see if it fits like you need it to. Pay attention to eye width distance and play something besides the great looking games (not as noticeable on blurry in games). Also make sure you have the space to set this sucker up (it recommends 5x7' min).
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2017
review_title: VR has come a long ways in 20 years

one_reviews_text: I can only give it two stars, and I'm compelled to comment, just because I can't believe how much stuff doesn't work in their titles.  About half of the titles I've downloaded actually work - the rest of them leave me staring at a black void until I back out of it. The hardware is really finicky, sometimes it needs a reboot for no reason because of USB tracking issues.  I've added a USB3 card along with the hub on my mainboard to make sure I've got the bandwidth it needs and it still jitters and stutters and I have to reboot for no reason to clear tracking errors. Fogging of the lenses is a problem, and they are constantly getting oils on them from I guess my eyelashes and eyebrows but they mentioned somewhere not to clean them with anything beyond a microfiber cloth.When it works, it's quite an impressive immersive experience. I just can't believe the number of titles rushed out the door and pushed to the library that won't load past the intro screen.  It's pathetic frankly.

one_reviews_text: I purchased this Oculus sensor to setup full 360 degree tracking along with the Oculus Headset and Touch controllers. It works great so far, and I have had no issues setting it up. However, in order for it to work optimally you must set it up in a certain spot of the room adjacent from one of the other sensors. This is fine, but it did hinder my original plans for the setup.This device is not wireless and must be plugged into your PC/Mac directly in order for it to work. The package from Amazon does come with an USB extension cord that extends the sensor quite far. I do wish these sensors performed the same way as the Vive sensors, though (those don't need to be plugged in the PC and only a wall outlet, reducing wire clutter).Overall, I'm glad I purchased it and I'm happy that I can finally expand my play area to take full advantage of every Oculus game and app.

one_reviews_text: First off, let me say that the Oculus Rift is truly next level stuff. The VR experience you get with this product is mind blowing. I thought it would be good, but this product will definitely blow your hair back! That being said, the only issue I have with it is that it requires 3, 3.0 USB A type inputs which, when you run the compatibility checker (which I strongly suggest you do BEFORE purchasing as the hardware requirements for this product are astronomical) it DOES NOT MENTION THIS FACT!!!! I ensured that my son ran the compatibility checker prior to ordering. It said we were all A-OK. No problem! Imagine my surprise when my son went to install it on Christmas morning and his 3 Trillion dollar AlienWare laptop (which we ran the compatibility checker on) only has 2 USB 3.0 A type inputs! Talk about a huge bummer! We had to wait until the 26th to go to our local Staples to get a 3.0 USB type C to A converter (around $14). While not a big deal, Oculus really should say how many USB ports are required (and for 3 Trillion dollars, AlienWare can afford to add another USB port…) All in all a solid 5 star rating.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2018
review_title: Awesome next level tech with one small complaint….

one_reviews_text:
Video Player is loading.Play VideoPlayMuteCurrent Time 0:00/Duration 4:20Loaded: 20.27%0:00Stream Type LIVESeek to live, currently behind liveLIVERemaining Time -4:20 1xPlayback RateChaptersChaptersDescriptionsdescriptions off, selectedCaptionsCaptions off, selectedAudio TrackFullscreenThis is a modal window.


 
 Having used the Oculus Rift for some time I was really looking forward to getting hold of the Touch controllers and see just what they could do.They arrive well packaged and in the box you get two controllers, one sensor, a Rock Band adapter and two AA batteries.Each controller takes a single AA batter and they feel very comfortable in the hand.  They have an interesting design with a circular band you slip your hand into.  I assume the band is a safety feature as it's already stopped me from smacking my hand on a wall while in game!Setup was fairly simple.  You'll need an additional USB port to plug the extra sensor and then you start the Oculus setup guide.  It shows you what to do, checks sensors are positioned correctly and gets you to setup a guardian zone.This zone is important to setup as it throws up a virtual wall when you're Rift approaches the boundary to stop you from walking into a real wall.Once setup is completed you're dropped into a brilliant tutorial that really shows off how good the controllers are.  It's a brilliant demo and it's amazing just how immersed you become, quickly picking things up, putting them down, interacting with them, it's a fantastic showcase.It's great to see software bundled with the controllers so you don't have to go and spend more right away.Medium is a creative package that lets you sculpt in 3D.  Not being especially creative I've not put a massive amount of time into this.Dead and Buried is a brilliant introduction to how different gaming with touch controllers is.  Draw your six shooter and take on other players in western style shoot outs, ducking behind tables and throwing dynamite.  For a really intense game swap to horde mode and hold out for as long as you can while waves of creatures come charging at you, they attack from all around and can get right up in your face, it's amazing!Toy Box isn't so much a game, more a technical demo that lets you play in a...toy box!  Great way to demo the Rift and controllers to friends and family.The Unspoken has you casting spells against other players, chucking fireballs, deflecting incoming attacks, summoning help, it's a brilliant idea and is much easier to get the hang of than you might first expect.The games I've tried as multiplayer and I've had problems finding others in matchmaking, hopefully that problem will ease as more people get the controllers.The only problem I've found so far is in long term comfort.  After a particularly intense session I found I had slightly sore hands from gripping the controllers, but I suspect that's just me over doing things and I'll take more breaks in between games from now on.Even with that in mind I can't recommend these enough.  If you've splashed out on the Rift the touch controllers are a must have addition to your VR setup.  Now I just need to rearrange my house to build a dedicated large VR room!UPDATE: Just tried out Bullet Train and it is AWESOME!  It's not a full game, more like a short concept game, but it's the closest a game has ever gotten to giving you a Matrix like experience, picking up guns, firing until the clip runs out, casting them aside and grabbing another set.Since my original review I've also managed to get some player on player action in the Unspoken, it's really good fun but I've discovered a bit of a problem.  In the game you stand on pillars, most are a little off the ground but some are really high up.  I didn't consider that being stood on a pillar high up in a VR world would trigger vertigo!  That's how immersive the Rift is and being stood up really enhances that.  Incredible bit of kit!

one_reviews_text: Honestly, after owning the Oculus, I feel as though I should have got an HTC Vive. I really don't like the motion tracking that the Oculus has, because it's really easy to block the camera's line of sight with your body and lose tracking. The headset itself works great, and I like that it comes with built in speakers. The controllers are also easy to use, and very ergonomic. I don't like that the Oculus has it's own DRM, and that the product is owned by Facebook. It makes me wonder whether or not a Facebook account will be required to use this device in the future, but I digress. I bought this product because it is cheaper than a Vive, and it works fine. But if you have the option to between the two VR headsets, my recommendation is for the Vive.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2018
review_title: I really don't like the motion tracking that the Oculus has

one_reviews_text: Great controllers for a great price. These are great, however the tracking is poor. USB compatibility is terrible. When you buy an Oculus Rift and Touch controllers there are too many hidden costs. You may have to buy a USB card. You WILL HAVE to buy a third Constellation camera (if you want decent tracking). You may buy a 4th Constellation camera (If you want great tracking similar to the Vive). You have to buy USB extension cables. And you might have to buy (or 3D print) brackets for your camera because the best setup is to invert the cameras and place them high. I returned this and the headset and bought the HTC Vive.

one_reviews_text: After several days of using it, I would recommend you wait for the next generation of VR headsets or look into other manufacturers that offer larger field of view at higher resolutions. The field of view distracts from the immersive experience but the real downer is the resolution. It's just not there yet even with supersampling. One final observation is how abrasive the padding that forms around your face feels.The setup was easy enough and the handheld controllers feels pretty natural. The audio is very good. Packaging excellent.Even with the lackluster execution of this product, VR is a unique experience worth checking out!

Sonst reicht die Bandbreite nicht (Lt. Kundendienst von Oculus). Die USB-Controller dürfen aber auch nicht auf einer ominösen Blacklist stehen, dann funktionieren sie nämlich überhaupt nicht.Vorr.: I5 oder gleichwertiger oder besserer Prozessor.Ein deutlich besserer AMD Octacore reicht offensichtlich nicht zum Betrieb aus, steht nur nirgendwo.Das Ganze ist nicht ausgereift und eine Riesenfrickelei.

one_reviews_text: Works great, lots of fun to be had. Changes the VR experience quite a bit when you can suddenly interact. Highly recommended for all creative individuals considering the software offerings (including free ones) for drawing and modeling.Unfortunately, the product has seemingly had some initial teething issues. It seems there is damping pads in the trigger buttons, in short time those can get unstuck from the original positions and get jammed somewhere else within the trigger button. This will manifest itself as a trigger button getting stuck in the pressed in position, a "sticky" feel to the trigger button or sudden loud clicking noises. Not sure if they've implemented a fix for this yet, I will be returning my Touch controllers for replacement with hope of better results (although other customers previous experience seems to suggest that the root cause hasn't been fixed and you're likely to experience the same again with the replacements...). Google "oculus touch sticky trigger button" for more references.

review_title: Great when it works, sticky trigger button issue (widespread issue seemingly)

one_reviews_text: For something that you don't get to try in advance of purchase they should fully describe what you will see in VR. Pixelation, especially on text would be a good thing to include in the description to fully prepare someone dropping $400+ on the system. Also a warning stating that the lense adjustment may not fit everyone would be good to know aswell. I have near to perfect eyesight and the slider maxed out won't let me get an any clearer picture resulting in having to deal with a blurry image, which along with some pixelation makes it upsetting for something I spent $400. Price fluctuations aswell has been irritating, if it's Amazon or Facebook/ Occulus controlling this... I'm not sure, but I paid $400 a month ago and now it's $500.... Why the steap jump in price? I guess you can say it was good for me but I'd be pissed if I just spent $500 and realised it was $400 just a month ahead. I will be returning mine and will also be keeping a closer eye on prices to see if it is Amazon or the products company that is ripping people off with the wild price fluctuations and will base future purchases accordingly.

one_reviews_text: The Oculus Rift is more than just an entry point into the VR world of gaming, it is top quality.  Between this and the Vive - both do extremely well.  There are reviews that state there are issues with both the Rift and Vive on 360 degree support, tracking, and more; however, a bit of research and education (easily found on the interwebz) will take you a long ways.A few tid bits: - Setting up for 360 degree support is easily done ON TWO SENSORS, do some interwebz lookups.  Simple to find.  You don't need a third sensor (YET!).  It's experimental as well, per Oculus. - The controls are much better than the Vives current. - It is supported by Facebook.  This means huge financial backing and wanting it to work well (quality and performance).  This is huge compared to the Vive. - Vorpx can allow you to run a lot of games not VR supported natively. - The more powerful your home PC the better any VR system runs.  Steam has a Steam VR test to help you if you are unsure. - Couch party games are hilarious and very enjoyable.  Such as...  - Playroom  - Black Hat Cooperative  - VR Diner Duo  - Ruckus Ridge  - Late For Work

one_reviews_text: It's clear that VR is in the very early stages of development. The fact that the Rift retails for more than $100 is absolutely mind blowing given how cheaply made it is, how buggy the software is, and how bad 95% of the games are. I'll try to be as far as I possibly can in this review.The Good:When it works it is a pretty amazing experience. Putting the headset on and being transported to another world is something that will impress anyone. I mostly enjoyed Robo Recall. It's a great game with easy to understand controls and a movement system that won't make you barf. My only regret for returning the Rift is this gem of a game.The Bad:Sadly that is all the enjoyment I could get out of it. The fun of the games would be ruing about 10 minutes in when the sensors decide that your left hand is not where it's supposed to be. The tracking on the Rift is pretty bad. So bad that I'm still unsure if I just didn't have a bad sensor. I tried various configurations. Nothing really fixed the issue. It just made the tracking behave wrong in different ways. The tracking issues, while bad, can be tolerated to a small degree. You can still mostly get the full experience.The Ugly:I'll start here with the game library. With the exception of maybe 10 games, everything is unfinished, buggy, shovel-ware garbage. It is a joke how bad a majority of the games are. Even some of the hits are okay at best. Some of the games, while not inherently bad games, had movement controls that would make you immediately vomit after 5 minutes of play. I won't cherry pick the obvious barf inducing games. I'll use Dreadhalls as my example. You only control the camera with the headset and nothing else. You walk with the left thumb stick and can move the camera with the right tumb stick. The combination of the movement and camera controls leaves for a dizzying experience. Even the comfort mode with the camera snapping didn't really help.The worst part about the Rift would have the be the god awful Oculus Home software that is required to be running in order for everything to work. There is no turning the Rift off. You just close out of the software. The Rift is sort of always on. Closing out of Oculus home doesn't really kill all of the Oculus stuff as there are multiple applications that run in the background. Coming from the same company that stole and sold personal data you can why one would not be okay with that.Privacy issues aside, there is more wrong with Oculus Home. Installing the software takes about an hour. I'm not talking about downloading anything either. The first issue I came across is that it would not let me use my second drive. Despite the 1000s of games that rung just fine on it, Oculus requires that the drive be formatted as NTFS. I guess the Oculus games will run on the same drive that Windows is utilizing. It's not like performance is required for VR.The next issue was that the Oculus Home wouldn't install any software after I had installed about 3 games. Trying to install software would result in a notification that the installation just failed. It didn't tell me why. Just that it failed. A quick stroll down google came up with all sorts of solutions:>Reboot your PC>Run as Admin>Run in compatibility mode>Update graphics drivers>Downgrade graphics drivers>Disable anti virus>Reinstall (2 hour endeavor)You want to know what fixed the issue? Seriously, I don't know. I never got it to work. If you know how to fix it please post a comment and help other's out.Conclusion:I want to say that VR isn't ready for the consumer, but that would be unfair to the competitors. I can say that the Oculus Rift is a product that should have spent a couple more years in development. The software required to use the Oculus needs to be built from the ground up. In its current state it's pretty much unusable. It requires too much overhead on top of an already demanding product. Unless you can pick this up for $100 or less I say wait until something more stable comes out. I returned mine and I suggest, if you can, to do the same. At the $400 price tag, It's not worth the broken, buggy frustration.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2018
review_title: Overpriced for what is an alpha product

one_reviews_text: Do NOT buy the Rift to play old video games in VR!!!!I bought this mainly to play some of my old games in VR after seeing videos online of people doing just that,  this will not work with the Rift as it no longer supports using the HMD as primary monitor.A few words on the Rift. Great fun, great immersion, not much content available. Set up is easy and your first few moments are amazing, (after about half an hour i nearly fell over trying to lean on a table in VR! lol) Unfortunately there really isn't a great amount of content that interests me personally, (i am into MMORPG and JRPG games... those of you who love FPS and other shooters will have more luck than me). Because of the lack of content the Rift will probably spent alot of time in a drawer only brought out for company or to play on a lark.The good: A unique and fun experience.THe bad: Not much variety in content. Games seem more like rushed/ incomplete Proof of Concept rather than actual games. Can not be used as a monitor making it impossible to play old games in VR, (you can play them on a simulated giant screen tho).Bottom line:The Rift looked like the future of gaming and home entertainment, the cost and lack of polish on available games and lack of backward compatibility to play games you already own, (lets face it HMD's are basically a second monitor/ set of control inputs) in VR are crippling the rift and with the current business model, (feel free to blame FB) i don't have high hopes for the future of VR.Honestly, this reminds me of Microsoft's XBox One launch fiasco. I hope Occulus stops trying to appeal to 1/10th of a wider audience and gets back to what made it so fascinating in the first place.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2017

one_reviews_text: I had the DK2 back in the day and now I bought this. Again, disappointing.Why?- VR has a fundamental problem: You can't move in the game naturally since you're restricted by your physical space. That already eliminates 99% of the games. You CAN move using a controller but it makes you feel sick and feels strange.- Terrible resolution again. Can't read text unless it's very big.- This seems to be something with Oculus itself. Tracking keeps freezing every few minutes for a few seconds. I think I had this same problem with the DK2 and it's happening again on Oculus Rift.- Again, no good titles. The demos are amazing, but there are no actual good games that are playable in VR that don't make you feel sick.- Even the software is buggy. Couldn't install more games in the Oculus store, it downloads fine then keep trying to install but the game is still not installed. Tried with different games. Steam VR games are fine tho.Trust me, don't buy this thing. If you have a big room and can afford to pay more, the Vive is probably better although I would just stay away from VRaltogether, it's overhyped extremely. If you think I'm just some random guy, I have been a geek my whole life, studied CS and have been working in tech for years.Once you try the great demos and start playing some games with it, you'll quickly realise it's a waste of money.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 19, 2018
review_title: Immature, buggy, unusable product. Don't waste your money

one_reviews_text: This product is garbage.  Took 3+ hours to install initially because it is poorly designed and is picky about everything (from hard drive to USB drives)... if you have your USB 3.0 from your motherboard, expect right-off that it will not be compatible.  I purchased USB 3.1 slots and finally got the USB working.  Also, if you have SSD and your main drive is dynamic, enjoy setting it up an an alternative drive (has to be installed on a basic drive) because the setup program is too stupidly-designed to recognize the difference between disc drives (It'll give you a "you don't have enough space" error and shut down).I finally got piece of garbage working and it worked great for a few months.  When it works, it is a very awesome experience.  However, this morning I wanted to play on it and the piece of garbage decided it needed a firmware update on one of the two sensores and will not work without it.  I tried all the "stupid" troubleshooting it tells you to do (unplug and re-plug in, updating all my graphics and USB cards, windows, etc...)... still would not install.  The only thing I can figure is the garbage sensor tried a firmware update without telling me and "bricked itself" by being in the middle of an update when i shut down.  Now I have to buy a new sensor if I want to use this... and they are not inexpensive.I have a great PC that I built myself.  gets higher benchmarks than 80% of the other computers that run benchmark tests.  This is a terrible piece of hardware riddled with issues.  Had to uninstall, and then go through the hassle of reinstalling again (I have 4 SSDs and the main windows is on a dynamic harddrive and it will only install on basic hard drives).Do yourself a favor if you do get this.  When you are done playing, shut down the app, and unplug everything so none of the compents brick themselves (essentially when you are in the process of modifying the bios and you remove power, it "bricks" the device... essentially turning it into a paperweight).
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2017
review_title: Finicky and poorly designed hardware that will run itself

one_reviews_text: The oculus itself is amazing. I have no complaints about the experience.The mediocre review is about the order itself.For once, the box was torn to hell when I received it. (It was inside a shopping box which was up damaged, so this happened pre shipping.)The right touch sensor has a squeaky trigger as if it’s been heavily used.When activating the touch sensors to get the free games, I didn’t get the free games. I’m jumping through hoops with oculus support trying to get them, but I haven’t yet.As someone whos worked in the warranty department for major computer companies for years, it’s apparent that what was shipped is a refurbished unit, which is why the wear and tear is there, along with the products not activating as they were supposed to.As for the inside of the package, their is a contents list, everything was there other than the lens cleaning cloth. There was a cardboard holder for it; but no cloth itself.There are Velcro straps that hold all of the components into the molded case. Upon arrival, the Velcro was not strapped for one of the sensors, and it was loose rolling around in the case.On the topic of the 6 free titles, 2 of them can’t really be counted, as they are free regardless of how you purchase your rift, 2 of them are tools for creators, and 2 of them are free when you activate new touch sensors, regardless of what package you get.This isn’t to say the bundle isn’t worth the value, but I do think claiming it comes with 6 free titles when some of those are free to begin with is shady.Overall, get a rift, they’re great, I’ve barely taken it off since I got it.Don’t be fooled by shady marketing tactics, and I would highly recommend ordering from a different distributor, as amazon dropped the ball heavy on this order.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2017

one_reviews_text:
Been looking to get into virtual reality for quilt a while and with this package with the Oculus Rift, two sensors, and touch control for $399 (at the time of purchased), went ahead and go for it knowing my rig is capable of VR. After downloading the setup program, plunging in sensors and headset, follow the given instructions and strapping on the headset and then immersed myself in the experience, messing around with the 6 games and creative software included.Now, I will say there was a issues with setting up the sensor. The main thing finding a set of USB 3.0 ports that is capable of running the sensors and this has been a known issue in the VR community, which generally recommending the Inateck USB pci cards. Unfortunately my motherboard USB ports (Gigabyte GA-Z77X-UD3H) didn't meet the required bandwidth or whatever. I tried for the heck of it even though I bought and installed a QICENT 2 port USB 3.1 pci card and fortunately that worked. The other thing that I have a bit of an issue with is understanding the setup guild when its telling me to get in center the sensors, but after a bit of trail and error, it eventually start giving me fine tuning intrusion fo the sensors then good then go from there.Also beware for those who wears glasses, small frames maybe able to fit but isn't a lot of space for them. I figure that since I'm nearside and that the screen is really close to my eyes that I can use them without needing my glasses. Nope, far objects and texts are just as blurry as much real life perspectives.After pointing out the negative aspects, the immersion of being in a cockpit of a 737 in Flight Simulator X (with FlyInside) is such an amazing experience. Also Touch works with FlyInside so the ability flip the switches inside the cockpit is so cool thing to me. Also looking forward to try out other games like racing and driving games once I switch out my flight simulator peripherals with my G27 Racing Wheel.Link to the USB 3.1 Pci card that works with the sensors for me (2 Type A ports)
Express Expansion Card PCI-E to USB 3.1 2-Port Hub Controller Adapter for Windows 7 / 8 / 8.1 / 10 Linux Kernal Desktops- Black
Gaming RigIntel Core i5-3570K (Ivy bridge Quad Core, even though Oculus recommending forth gen i5 Haswell CPU or newer)Asus Strix GTX 1070 (able to pass Steam VR test with a solid 10)Gigabyte GA-Z77X-UD3HWindows 10 64-bit
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2017
review_title: VR getting more affordable and is such a awesome experience!

one_reviews_text: I received this product almost two weeks ago. Even though I had a USB 3.0 (that's a STANDARD right?) controller, Oculus didn't work with mine, I had to go out and get the specific chipset controller they wanted me to get. I installed that, which was a pain (likely conflicted with my controller which I had to disable), but I did finally get it installed. Then I ran their setup program, which told me I first needed to install two windows updates that were not even on my list of optional updates to install. So I exited the setup program, and set to installing updates. Thereafter, when I ran their setup program again, it "Look's like we can't connect to the Oculus server. Check your internet connection.(which worked perfectly with all other websites). Even after 11 days! of working with their support team, they could not get it fixed. Their best guess was that exiting their installer caused some type of corruption in my registry! They wanted to know if I wanted to do a complete reinstall of Windows to try to fix it!! Their setup file didn't write any log at all, they tried everything to find it! They have no stand-alone installer to install without an internet connection! I told them, this was (HONESTLY) the most terrible experience I have EVER had during an install, in over 30 years working with computers.<to Amazon, I am not attaching the screenshot of the correspondence with the Oculus support team, as I am assuming that you judged it was that, that was against your guidelines? (your first rejection of my review did not give a specific reason, so that is my best guess). I don't believe there was anyone's personal email in it, and I'm not sure why that image would be against your guidelines, but I am not attaching it this time.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2017
review_title: Steep and Finicky system requirements, and a terrible installer (software)

one_reviews_text: I have a 300Mb/s down 300 Mb/s up internet connection but the setup is taking forever since it requires downloading 1.70GB at kB/s speeds. This is from within the setup program itself. I've verified that my internet connection is good by running speed tests on the same machine while waiting for this stupid download and left and came back. So far this product is unusable. If you're going to purchase I'd suggest trying to download ahead of time to avoid getting frustrated after you've taken it out of the box, but I don't know how well that will work if you don't have the product yet. I'm very disappointed that they would skimp on their bandwidth like this and it makes more wonder about what other corners they've cut.Update:Installation was a pain due to USB driver problems (hint: unplug all USB devices other than mouse and keyboard from your machine and disable windows from automatically installing drivers if you're adding the recommended Inateck card because of ASRock USB controller incompatibility). But once I got the driver situation straightened out and was able to get started the experience was absolutely amazing. It really feels like you're moving around in this virtual world. I primarily purchased the device for flight sim and with FlyInside and XP11 landings finally feel like real landings - this was never the case with my three monitor setup with TrackIR. I'm on an overclocked i7-4930K and an overclocked 1080ti so you're milage may vary but I'm very happy. SIX stars but minus two for the very painful install especially since I ended up having to uninstall and reinstall various times and had to wait for this thing to redownload each time.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2017

one_reviews_text: Pros:* Low cost.* 90% of me lost myself in the new world.Cons:* Google Tilt brush, my main reason for getting this, would not let me record audio or record a video of me talking while I made things.* The apps presently made are touching on about 5% of their potential to be really useful. When photoshop can allow me to use an actual pen in VR sitting down and do all the menu items with the addition of 3D and allow me to record a narrative of me making things that would be worth thousands of dollars. As it was, I could not change the size of my pen, it was tiring to stand as I drew, and it was not easier to share the object with another.* My main deciding point is the fact that my hands are sensitive to wireless technology. As a result, they burned after 20 minutes. The same thing happens for me with cell phones so I prefer using wired objects. These transmit more signal, based on my hands burning at the joints than cell phones so people sensitive to that would want to avoid Oculus for now.

one_reviews_text: Go Rift if you are not sure which way to go.  I have had both.  I know the hype is out there for Vive; I know that no reviewer in the world could give a clear answer on Vive vs. Rift... But it is Rift all the way.1) touch is better than vive controllers have used both!2)  Rift is cheaper!  Less than $700 with room scale and touch.3). You get more free games and and additional $100 toward games on Amazon!!!4). Room scale on Rift requires less space!5). Vive is buggy.  My vive kept having issues staring apps after a few days (why I returned it)6). You can play most if not all of the Vive games on Rift AND YOU CAN STILL ISE STEAM AND STEAM VR APP IF YOU WANT TO.  Does not work the other way (not many Rift games can be played on Vive in many cases).7). Many more, better games on Rift8). Rift hardware is more comfortable by a lot and much easier to use and still has better feel and comfort even if you buy the $100 upgrade for vive (deluxe audio strap)!Where is Vive better):1). I like the steam "home" app better than Rift BUT you can STILL USE THE STEAM VR HOME APP on Rift!2). Rift app has to be used on one windows account, no share across family unless you use the same user!  But u can use the steam games across accounts using family share on steam.

one_reviews_text: I really wish someone had told me the hard truth about VR: anything below a 4k screen right in front of your eye looks like crap. Less crappy the closer it is but exponentially more the further away. Such is the case here, where after the initial wow of your brain being confused for 10 seconds and then adjusting to VR forever thereafter, everything looks like an eyesore of very, very noticable pixels. This means things in the distance to you are huge pixels. There's a lot of points I could make, but this isnt fixable with software. When we can run 2 4k screens simultaneously and still make that affordable, we'll have VR.

Schliesslich hat es dann doch funktioniert und ich bekomme in der Inbox den Bestätigungslink.Draufgeklickt und..."Entweder deine E-Mail-Adresse oder dein Bestätigungscode sind ungültig. Solltest du den Link aus deiner E-Mail in deinen Browser kopiert haben, stelle sicher, dass du ihn richtig kopiert hast."Oculus / facebook, entweder ihr baut funktionierende Software oder liefert einfach Hardware ohne Registrierungszwang.Wenn's bis heute abend nicht funktioniert geht das Ding zurück und ich kaufe mir die Vive.
