one_reviews_text: Zuerst ein Lob an Amazon. Top Service wie immer. Haben es ohne Probleme zurück genommen und mir mein Geld erstattet.Nun zur Oculus.Ich habe sie mir gekauft weil ich schon lange VR ausprobieren wollte, und dachte das es mittlere Weile ja Reichlich an Material zum Spielen geben müsste.... hätte ich mich mal vorher Informiert.Man Installiert alles usw. das Funktioniert alles Einwandfrei, dann spielt man zuerst eine Demo die einem ein wenig die Steuerung und Möglichkeiten Aufzeigt....dort dachte ich mir noch verdammt ist das GEIL!Nach dieser ca. 15min langen Demo kommt man in die App und kann dort nun Spiele kaufen usw.....Und dort liegt das Hauptproblem.Wirklich Spiele sind das nicht. Es sind TECH-DEMOS. Und zwar für 40€.Es gibt keine Spiele die man lange Spielen kann und richtig viel Spaß machen.Ich kaufte also ein Spiel für 25€. Ein Rätsel Spiel. Es hat wirklich Spaß gemacht bis... naja es gibt 6 Level und jedes dauert 10min.Also 25€ für 60min Spielzeit.Andere Spiele wie der Roboter Shooter der beim Kauf dabei ist, sind zwar auch nicht perse schlecht aber :- man erkennt immer das Raster der Pixel- es wird einem nach kurzer Spielzeit wirklich immer übel- es ist unglaublich Repetitiv man macht immer das gleiche- da die Augen so nah an den Linsen sind fangen die auch schnell an zu brennen und Kopfweh entstehtSo wenn also jemand wirklich viel Geld hat, dann kann er sich die ganzen Games zwar Kaufen und Kurzzeitige Unterhaltung haben, aber es gibt im ganzen Store dann vielleicht noch 2-3 Games für 40-50€ und das war es dann auch mit den "Blockbuster".Noch lauter weitere Tech Demos die einem nur Aufzeigen was alles möglich ist, aber nichts wird wirklich in einem guten Spiel realisiert.Nichts was in einem die Lust erweckt weiter zu spielen o.ä.Es werden einfach viel zu wenig Inhalte für VR Produziert als das es sich für Privat Personen Lohnen würde sich VR anzuschaffen.Ich Persönlich hatte nach meiner 5 Stündigen Erfahrung mit der Oculus absolut kein verlangen mehr jemals wieder damit zu Spielen.Ich hoffe ich konnte ein paar Leuten Helfen die mit dem selben Gedanken gespielt haben :)
review_date: Reviewed in Germany on February 26, 2018
review_title: Warum VR noch absolut nichts bringt....

one_reviews_text: From the onset this device attacks the consumer with bloatware and required "subscription" software- else you can't even use the $400 device.Not only was I required to install an app that asked me umpteen times to log into FaceBook but had to warn me that it was "not good" if I don't share my antics with the world online.The installed app makes you watch a video where they take time to show you how "zen-like" their animated Ken-doll can be if he uses his Rift comfortably. It made me wonder how much of the cost of the Rift is tied to their motion graphics (which aren't even in 3D) budget?I think what annoyed me the most is that all I wanted to know was where to position the sensors- which they don't even tell you by step 7 of the application! However, I've had the opportunity to choose an avatar from a wide-array of aliens, dogs (even a balloon dog), and selection of white avatars. For a half-white, half-black person that kinda sucks....The Oculus software (which needs an active internet connection) is required even to use SteamVR. That doesn't make sense to an end-user which implies its real motive is data metric gathering and other privacy invasion behaviors. If you want to collect my data don't charge me $400.I imagine, when the MR devices like the Lenovo Explorer become ubiquitous I will come back and downgrade my review to 1 star.Without the software the device might have been a three or higher.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2017
review_title: Apparently Only Aliens, Dogs, and White People Are VR Users....

one_reviews_text: Believe it or not I've condensed this review...I've tried everything from from head mounted far-from-vr cartridge games in the 90's to Google Cardboard. The former probably shouldn't even be compared to and the latter was neat for a few minutes but no one is ever going to carry that thing around all the time. That and very basic games combined with half a low-res cell-phone screen just doesn't cut it. This means it gets put in a drawer and forgotten about.In steps Oculus and you finally have something that people want to play over and over. When friends come over there's even a bit of social aspect to it when I put the video up on the projector as someone is playing. Everyone laughs when the robots jump you in Robo-recall and you scream or the first time someone tries to lean on a table in the orientation demo. You have to play referee and pull people out of the immersion so everyone can try: describing the experience is nothing compared to being in it. Flying around in Google Earth is just beautiful. Holding VR items up to your face to see detail is uncanny.I mention immersion because that's what set's this generation apart. I'll say right now that 1. The field of view is less than a human's normal view and 2. The resolution is still low enough that you get the so-called screen door effect be being able to see the individual pictures. Guess what? It doesn't matter. The field of view and resolution are enough. The good news is enough is finally the right amount and the only time you notice these things is when you're looking for them. Otherwise you're sucked right in and your biggest worry is reacting to the guardian system so you don't punch a real-life wall. That system is a map you outline in a room beforehand so when you are dodging bullets you know when to snap yourself out of said immersion to recenter yourself. Little details like this are seemingly small but all work together to make a well rounded experience.Hardware wise you get a good amount of adjust-ability in the head mount though when my two-yr-old wants to get in on it there's not a small enough size for her. Big head's need no worry; it gets big enough. Weight is good an I tend to find myself getting motion sick after long play periods before the headset itself feels uncomfortable. Take breaks. The speakers seem pretty simple but like the field of view they are enough that your brain doesn't care when you're in a game. I LOVE the touch controllers. The just feel so comfortable in your hand with controls that are in the natural position of your fingers. Touch sensitivity on everything is a nice touch so you get things like lifting your thumb in the more social games to give a thumbs up. I wish the cords were just a touch longer everywhere. I have a ~7x7 play area with the sensors mounted 8ft off the ground a little over 6 feet apart. The headset is just long enough that it isn't a bother unless you turn over 360 once and the sensor lines have little slack. Some wiggle room would be nice. Good news though, the headset cord is easily replaceable if you get a little rough with it.There's no denying there are improvements that can be made. The good news is the current state is a whole lot of fun and the technology to make the improvements exists. Until that time we finally have replay-ability. I play the same games a lot but active development means there is always something new coming out. You know it's good when friends are asking to play "just one more level" over and over.Things to try: Robo-recall, Google Earth VR, Projects Cars, Elite Dangerous
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2017
review_title: VR is no longer a gimmic

one_reviews_text: It’s hard to beat the unique experience of virtual reality, and this offering from Oculus Rift is a great chance to begin yours.I’m not a huge gamer, but my adult children are, and they were knocked out by this device. Just the same, my first experience was equally breathtaking. The sense of reality you get is amazing, as you grab, shoot, push, turn, spin, etc., the various objects in the games. I can think of no other way to describe it other than to say that you are truly lost in the game. It is a very wild experience! Prior to this, the most interaction I had was with a Wii. If you can imagine that as the acorn, then this Oculus game is the oak tree.To that end, this can be disorienting for some folks, especially those with tendencies toward vertigo and motion sickness. I liken it to riding a roller coaster in that sense, particularly felt when you doff the headgear and have to readjust to the room. You might feel a bit woozy, but oh wow – what a fun time while you’re “in” the game.As far as set-up, it took my tech savvy daughter about forty-five minutes from box to play, mostly for the calibration of the hand equipment. Also, this game requires some room, not only to move about and not strike things, but also to give the sensors space for optimal performance. Lastly, this game requires a desktop with some game-compatible settings and a monitor. Most of you will know this going in, but for those who wouldn’t (I count myself in that group), it’s good to know that the price only includes the virtual reality equipment/software and not the means to actually “play” the games.Some of the games included are samples; wherein you may play a short mission or chapter and that’s it, but there are plenty of titles to choose from, so you will have a lot of games to browse, from simple manipulative art platforms to futuristic worlds battling robots, and so much more. No matter what game you play, the movement, interaction, and intensity of the audio-visual simulation make it impossible to embrace your inner jaded self. In short, you WILL be dodging items coming at you, reaching out to try and grab or strike things, and shouting with glee as you thoroughly succumb to the thrills and chills of action. It’s simply that intense, and there is nothing else even remotely like it in the gaming arena. Virtual reality is the future of gaming.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2017

Not because of the device itself, But because of the extreme difficulty trying to get the drivers for the device on a website that will not allow you on it to download said drivers! Why like so many other hardware vendors they couldn't just put the drivers on a dvd disc so that you could have them at your fingertips then once on the site you just update the software as needed. Getting the device running is crucial if the process is to progress! Once the compatibility program gives you the green light no other compatibility actions should be needed,  especially the extreme actions people were instructed to do. It's a given about hard drive space for virtual memories sake. My computer is fully compatible based on the list of just the minimal hardware required which i exceeded and by the compatibility program itself. The software available runtime Sdk 0.8. 0.0  has an win.exe file for execution and install of said file, runtime 1.0.0 thru 1.17.0 do not have executable files so cannot be installed . Way to many obstacles involved when trying to install  simple drivers that should get the VR experience on the road. What a waste!!!

one_reviews_text: Facebook hat 4 Mrd investiert und die haben nicht herausgefunden das die Menschen kein Licht durch die Nase sehen wollen. Bei der PSVR Brille ist absolute Dunkelheit garantiert, somit empfehle ich die PSVR. Vl. lesen das Team von Oculus diese Bewertung und optimieren das bei der nächsten Generation. Zudem kann ich nicht wie bei der PSVR meine Kopfhörer direkt beim Kopf anschließen. Also man merkt Sony denkt mehr an das was die Kunden wollen, die haben aber auch mehr Erfahrung mit Endkunden
review_date: Reviewed in Germany on September 30, 2017

one_reviews_text: Boo what a nightmare this whole process has been. You need to buy so many extra components that they don't even explain you need in the first place. Im buying one more piece of equipment and if it doesn't work after that I'm returning this piece of junk.

one_reviews_text: You are required to have a pc And windows 10 AND a streaming app to be able to play anything on Xbox one. When ordered this it wasn't clear at all. Only saw this stated after digging through member questions. Back in the box it goes.
